div0.head: *n
div0.entryFree: n, nu=, to/, indecl., fourteenth (later thirteenth) letter of Greek alphabet; as numeral, n/ = 50, but n' = 50,000.
na=as, Dor. acc. pl. of nau=s (q.v.).
nabaisatreu=, barbarous word in Ar.Av.1615 (expld. as a term of commendation); v.l. babakatreu=.

na/bla, h(,
a musical instrument of ten or (acc. to J.AJ7.12.3)
of twelve strings, cj. in S.Fr.849, cf. LXX 1 Ki.10.5, al.:—also na/blas, a, o(, Sopat.16, Philem.44, Str.10.3.17; cf. nau=lon 1. (Semitic word, cf. Hebr.
nēbel; Phoenician, acc. to Ath.4.175b.). dub. sens. in acc. to\n na/bla, OGI175.9 (Egypt, ii B.C.).
nabl-i/zw, = ya/llw, Gloss.

nabl-isth/s, ou=, o(,
player on the na/bla, Euph.Fr.Hist.8.
nabl-istoktu^peu/s, e/ws, o(, = foreg., Man.4.185.

nabou=s, o(,
camelopard, IG14.1302 (Praeneste). (Ethiopian, acc. to Plin.HN8.69.)

na^geu/s, e/ws, o(, (na/ssw)
pestle, Tz.adHes.Op.421.

na/gma, atos, to/,
anything piled up, as a stone wall, J.BJ1.21.7.
na/erra: de/spoina, Hsch. nae/teira (nai/t- cod.): oi)kode/spoina, Id.
na^eth/r, h=ros, o(, = sq., AP7.409 (Antip. Thess.), D.P.455, etc.

na^e/ths, ou, Dor. na^e/tas, a, o(,
inhabitant, Simon.57, Ephipp.5.1 (anap.), AP9.535, Limen.41, IG5(2).474 (Megalopolis): asfem., AP 6.207.10 (Arch.).
nae/twr, = na/twr, Hsch.

na_eu/w, (nao/s)
take sanctuary in a temple, Leg.Gort.1.39.

nahlei=s: pro/sfatoi (Thess.), Hsch.; cf. nealh/s. naqmo/s, o(,
reef, Id.
upright threads in a loom, Id. na/qrac, = na/rqhc, Id.

nai/, Adv., used to express strong affirmation,
yea, verily, in Hom. mostly folld. by dh/, n. dh\ tau=ta/ ge pa/nta . . kata\ moi=ran e)/eipes Il.1.286, al.; n. mh/n Emp.76.2; n. ma/n Theoc.27.27; n. me/n A.R. 2.151; n. me/ntoi Luc.Astr.14: used alone, se\ kri/nw, n. se/
yea thee, S.El.1445; a)pokri/nasqai n. h)\ ou)/ Arist.Top.158a16, etc.; to\ e_ ou)k e)/sti xarakthristiko\n . . , to\ de\ a_ nai/ Choerob.in Theod.2.85. freq. in oaths, n. ma/
yea by . . , v. ma/; n. alone, n. ta\n *ko/ran Ar.V.1438, cf. E. Ba.534 (lyr.); n. to\n *potida=n Epich.81; n. tw\ siw/ X.HG4.4.10; n. pro\s qew=n a)rh/cat' E.Med.1277. in answers,
yes, tou=t' e)th/tumon; Answ. n. A.Pers.738 (troch.), cf. S.El.845 (lyr.), Pl.Tht.193a, Grg. 448b, etc.; doubled, Ar.Nu.1468, Call.Fr.1.56 P., Ev.Matt.5.37. n. folld. by a)lla/, etc., to mark a qualified assent,
yes, but . . , Aeschin. 3.84; n., kata\ sxolh/n ge i)/sws: ou) mh/n . . Pl.Sph.226e, cf. R.415e.
na_t, Dor. poet. dat. of nau=s.
*na/i+-a [na_], ta/, festival of Zeus *na/i+os, at Dodona, IG5(2).118.21 (Tegea); written *na=a ib.2.1318.

*nai+-a^ko/s, h/, o/n,
of the Naiads, lime/nes AP10.21 (Phld.).

*nai/+-arxos, o(, perh.
warden of temple of Zeus *na/i+os, SIG1206.7 (Dodona).

*nai+-a/s, Ion. *nhi+a/s, a/dos, h(, (na/w)
Naiad, river-nymph, spring-nymph, Od.13.104,356 (pl.): in sg., A.R. 1.626:—also *nai/+s, Ion. *nhi/+s, i/+dos, h(, in sg., nhi/+s *)abarbare/h Il.6.22; nu/mfh te/ke nhi/+s 14.444, cf. Pi.P.9.16, E.Hel.187 (lyr.): pl. *nai/+des, Str.10.3.10, Paus.8.4.2, etc.

naida^mw=s, Com. form of nai/,
yes certainly, opp. ou)damw=s or mhdamw=s, Com.Adesp.1086.
na_i/+dion [i^d], to/, Dim. of nao/s, Plb.6.53.4, Str.8.6.21.

naieta/w, in pres. forms, -a/w Od.9.23, -a/ei Hes.Th.775, -a/ousi Il. 4.45; freq. in part. naieta/wn, Od.6.245, al., acc. -a/onta 4.96, etc., fem. -a/wsa (v.l. -a/ousa) Il.2.648, 3.387, 6.415, Od.1.404, 8.574 (-o/wsa Aristarch.ad Il.6.415): Ion. impf. naieta/askon Il.2.841, etc.: (nai/w): of persons,
dwell, freq. in Ep.; toi\ e)pi\ xqoni\ naiet a/ousi Od.6.153, cf. Hes.Th.564; h(=| e)/ni naieta/aske Od.15.385: c. dat. loci, *lakedai/moni n. Il.3.387; *krh/th| Od.17.523; u(po\ xqoni/ Hes.Th. 621; u(po\ o(/rois, a)mfi\ . . qe/meqla naieta/ontes, Pi.O.6.78, P.4.180. c.acc. loci,
dwell in, inhabit, *la/risan, *)iqa/khn, etc., Il.2.841, Od.9.21, etc.; dw/mata Hes.Th.816. of places,
to be situated, lie, Il.4. 45, Od.9.23; of buildings, 2.400, al.: hence,
exist, *)iqa/khs e)/ti naietaou/shs 1.404.—Ep. and Lyr. word, once in Trag., in part. naietw=n cj. Dind. metri gr. in S.Ant.1123 (lyr.).
naie/tis, idos, h(, fem. of *naie/ths, = nae/ths, Call.inPSI9.1092.58.
nai/ki, barbarism for nai/xi in Ar.Th.1183, 1218.

naikish/rhs, es,
one who sneers or
carps, Pherecr.222, Hermipp.90.

naikissoreu/w,
disparage, Hsch.

na_i+ko/s, h/, o/n,
of a temple, eu)/qunoi GDI1370 (Dodona).
naineu/rh: nh\ to\n *)/arh, *)attikoi\ de\ podoka/kh, Hsch. nai=on, v. na/w.
na/i+os, a, on, Dor. for nh/i+os.
*na/i+os [a_], o(, epith. of Zeus at Dodona, GDI1567,al., Sch.Il.16.233:—also *na=os, GDI1563,al.; also at Carthaea, IG12(5).551 (cf. p.329).
naio/s, = nao/s, Clinias ap.Sch.A.R.2.1085, cf. Hsch.
nai=ron, to/, a plant used in perfumery; prob. f.l. for ma=ron (q.v.) in Thphr.HP9.7.3.
*nai/+s, v. *nai+a/s.
naisieli/a, h(, = a)poplhci/a, e)mbronthsi/a, Hsch.:—also naish/mata, Id.
na_i+sk-a/rion, to/, Dim. of nai/+skos, PMag.Par.1.3145, Sch.Aeschin. 1.10, Gloss.

na_i/+sk-ion, to/, = foreg., *)osei/ridos POxy.521.4 (ii A.D.). name of various
bandages, Sostratus and Apolloniusap.Gal.12.496 Chart.

na_/i+sk-os (parox.), o(, Dim. of nao/s,
shrine, Str.14.1.4, J.AJ8.8.4.
nai/xi^ (on the accent v. Hdn.Gr.1.9), Adv., for nai/, like ou)xi/ for ou), mh/xi for mh/, S.OT684, Pl.Hipparch.232a, Men.Sam.81, Call.Epigr. 30.5.

nai/w, poet. Verb, Act. (intr.) only in pres. and impf. (Ep. nai/eskon Il.5.708), fut. and aor. in causal and Med. and Pass. forms, v. infr. 11, 111: of persons,
dwell, abide, mostly folld. by a Prep. of Place, e)n *(/lh|, etc., Il.l.c., etc.; r(oh=|s e)/pi *saggari/oio 16.719; e)p' a)/krwn o)re/wn S. OT1105 (lyr.); kata\ pto/lin Il.2.130; a)n' ou)/rea Hes.Th.130; pa\r potamo/n Il.2.522; u(po\ *pla/kw| 6.396: c. dat. loci, ai)qe/ri nai/wn 2.412, Hes. Op.18, etc.; n. meta/ tinos S.Ph.1105 (lyr.): metaph., th\n sh\n d' o(mou= nai/ousan [o)rgh/n] Id.OT338; ta\n a)reta\n nai/ein e)pi\ pe/trais Simon.58: with Adv., [kako/ths] e)ggu/qi nai/ei Hes.Op.288; i(/na ai( *forki/des nai/ousi A.Pr.794. b. c. acc. loci,
dwell in, inhabit, oi)ki/a, dw/mata, Od.20.288, Hes.Op.8, cf. Pi.P.7.5, al.; a(/la, pla/kas o)re/wn, E.Hel.1584, Ba. 719; freq. with place-names, Il.2.615, Alex.22, etc.: metaph., *peiqw\ nai/ei kai\ *xa/ris ui(o\n *)aghsi/la dub. in Pi.Fr.123.10; of the statues of gods, pro/pula nai/ousin ta/de S.El.1375:—Pass.,
to be inhabited, Id.Fr. 1125 (in aor. e)na/sqh), etc.; poli/tais Theoc.16.88; u(p' a)ndra/si A.R.1.794. of places,
lie, be situated, once in Hom., nh/swn ai(\ nai/ousi pe/rhn a(lo/s Il.2.626; w)= kleina\ *salami/s, su\ me/n pou nai/eis a(li/plaktos S. Aj.598 (lyr.). causal, in Ep. aor. e)/nassa or na/ssa, Med. e)nassa/mhn: c. acc. loci,
give one
to dwell in, kai/ ke/ oi( *)/argei+ na/ssa po/lin I would have
given him a town in Argos
for his home, Od.4.174;
make habitable, build, nho\n e)/nassan h.Ap.298;
settle, *eu)/boian e(/lon kai\ e)/nassan Pi.Pae.5.36:—in Med.,
found, muri/a d' a)/sth na/ssat' e)poixo/menos A.R.4.275:—in Pass., of places, like Act.1.2,
to be situated, poli/wn eu)= naiomena/wn Il.3.400, al. c. acc. pers.,
let one
dwell, settle him, e)n *)/argei e)/nassen *(hrakle/os e)kgo/nous Pi.P.5.71:— in Med., na/ssato kou/rhn A.R.4.567. Med. and Pass. in act. sense, fut. na/ssomai Id.2.747: Ep. aor. 1 na/ssato Hes.Op.639, Dem.Bith.6, Philet.24; later 3pl. naih/santo D.P.349: pf. ne/nastai IG14.1389i8; part. nenasme/nos D.P.264: aor. Pass. e)na/sqhn, path\r e)mo\s *)/argei+ na/sqh my father
settled at Argos, Il.14.119.—More freq. in Compos. with a)po/, kata/.
na/kafqon, v. na/rkarqon.

na/kh [a^], h(,
woolly or
hairy skin, a)\n de\ na/khn e(/let' ai)go/s Od.14.530; also of sheep, Lyc.1310; ai)gw=n na/kai kai\ proba/twn Paus.4.11.3. (Cf. OE.
næsc 'leather'.)
na^ko-dai/mwn, onos, o(, = sq., with a play on kakodai/mwn, Ath.8.352b.

na^ko-de/yhs, ou, o(, (de/yw)
currier, Hp.Vict.1.19, Ath.8.352b.

na^ko-kle/y, o(, h(,
fleece-stealer, Hdn.Gr.1.246.
na/kolon: to\ a)ka/qarton, Hsch.
*na_ko/reioi, oi(, a guild at Camirus, IG12(1).701.12.
*na_ko/reion, v. newko/rion. na_ko/ros, v. newko/ros.

na/kos [a^], eos, to/,
fleece, n. kriou= Pi.P.4.68, Hdt.2.42, cf. Simon.21, Berl.Sitzb.1927.170 (Cyrene), Theoc.5.2, SIG560.41 (Epidamnus, found at Magnesia, iii B.C.), Luc.Am.34.

na^ko-tilte/w,
pluck or
shear off wool, Archipp.32.

na^ko-ti/lths, ou, o(,
wool-plucker, shearer, Philem.14.

na^ko/-tiltos, on,
with the wool plucked off, Cratin.41.

nakto/s, h/, o/n, (na/ssw)
close-pressed, solid, a)/mmou xw/masi nakth=s Plu. CG7; ta\ nakta/
felt, Hsch. dub. sens. in CRAcad.Inscr.1930.213 (Susa, i B.C.).
na^ku/rion, to/, Dim. of na/kos, Hsch.

na=ma, atos, to/, (na/w)
anything flowing, running water, stream, spring, n. *mnamosu/nas cj. in Simon.45, cf. A.Pr.806, S.Ant.1130 (lyr.); *kastali/dos na/mata Pae.Delph.1.6; dakru/wn qerma\ n. S.Tr.919; na/mat' o)/sswn E.HF625; n. puro/s Id.Med.1187; n. *ba/kxion Ar.Ec.14; ma\ na/mata Antiph.296 ( = Timocl.38); n. qugate/rwn tau/rwn, i.e. honey, Ph. Tars. ap. Gal.13.269; fle/gmatos, xolh=s n., Philostr.Gym.42: freq. in Pl., as krhnw=n kai\ potamw=n na/mata Criti.111d: metaph., lo/gwn n. Ti.75e.
wooden conduit, Hsch. na/mata: probolai/, Id.

namara=s, a=, Semitic word of uncertain meaning, Roussel
Délos Colonie Athénienne p.424.

na_ma^si^ph/c, ph=gos, o(, h(,
crystallized by evaporation from water, a(/ls Aglaïas 22.

na_ma^t-iai=os, a, on,
flowing, u(/data
spring water, Aeschin.2.115, cf. Thphr.HP4.2.9, prob. in Alciphr.3.13.
na_ma^/t-ion, to/, Dim. of na=ma, Thphr.Ign.29, Phylarch.65J.

na_ma^t-w/dhs, es,
full of springs, Thphr. CP3.6.3.

na_merth/s, na_me/rteia, Dor. for nhm-. na=n, Dor. acc. of nau=s. nanei=: i(/ptatai, and nanh=sai: i(/ptasqai, Hsch. na_ni/on, to/, Dim. of na=nos,
puppet, doll, Gloss. na/nion: a)mni/on, sfa/gion, Hsch. na/nnazon: paizo/menon, Id.

nanna/r-ion, to/,
prodigal, Hsch.: *nanna/rion, pr. n. of a courtesan, Theophil.11.
nannar-i/s: ki/naidos, Hsch.

nannar-isth/s, ou=, o(,
prodigal, Phot. (nanar- cod.).

na/nnas, o(, or na/nna, h(,
maternal or
paternal uncle or
aunt, Hsch.; cf. ne/nnos. na/nnh, h(,
maternal aunt, Id.
*nanni/on, name of a courtesan, Amphis 23; cf. nanna/rion.
nanoka/ka: dia\ r(inw=n lalou=sa, Hsch.

na=nos, o(,
dwarf, Ar.Fr.427, Arist.HA577b27, Longin.44.5;
one whose limbs are too small for his body, Arist.PA686b10.
cheese-cake, Ath.14.646c. (Freq. written na/nnos in codd.; cf. sq.)

na_nofu^h/s, e/s,
of dwarfish stature, Ar.Pax790 (nanno- codd.).

na_nw/dhs, es,
dwarfish, ill-proportioned, Arist.PA686b3.

*naciourgh/s, e/s,
of Naxian work, ka/nqaros Ar.Pax143.

*na/cos, h(,
Naxos, h.Ap.44, etc.:—Adj. *na/cios, a, on, Naxian: oi( N.
the Naxians, Hdt.5.30, etc.; *naci/a a)ko/na a Naxian whetstone, Pi.I. 6(5).73, Dsc.5.149; N. pe/trh AP15.25.4 (Besant.); N. li/qos Phot.; ge/rra *na/cia (v. ge/rron v. 2) Epich.235: *naciaka/, ta/,
a work on Naxos, by Andriscus, Parth.9tit.

nacos (accent unknown), h, on,
solid, not hollow, n. pagxru/seos . . kolosso/s Epigr. ap. Phot.s.v. *kuyelidw=n a)na/qhma (s.v.l.).

na_o-do/mos, on, (de/mw)
temple-building, te/xnh Epigr.Gr.409.4 (Arycanda).

na_o-eidh/s, e/s,
in the form of a shrine, pasth=on SIG996.23 (Smyrna).
na_o-ko/ros, v. newko/ros.
na_o-le/kths, ou, o(, dub. sens. in PLond.3.982.2 (iv A.D.).
na_o-poie/w, na_o-poii/a, na_o-poi+ko/s, na_o-poio/s, v. new-poie/w, -poii/a, -poi+ko/s, -poio/s.

na_o-po/los, Ion. nhop-, on,
dwelling or
busied in a temple, ma/ntis Pi.Fr.51 Schroeder, cf. Man.4.427. as Subst.,
overseer of a temple, Hes.Th.991.

na_o/s, o(, Dor., Thess., etc. form, Leg.Gort.1.42, IG9(2).517.45 (Larissa, iii B.C.), etc., used also in Trag. (even dialogue) to the exclusion of new/s, S.El.8, E.Hipp.31, al., exc. A.Pers.810, rare in Att. Prose and Com., Pl.R.394a, Lg.738c, 814b, Arist.EN1174a24, Posidipp. 29.1, more freq. in X., HG2.3.20, An.5.3.9, al., found in Att. Inscrr.from iii B.C., IG22.1314.18, 1315.28, etc., and in Hellenistic and later Gr. (along with new/s), SIG277 (Priene, iv B.C.), 214 (Phanagoria, iv B.C.), 494.3 (Delph., iii B.C.), LXX 1 Ki.1.9, al. (new/s only in
2 Ma.), UPZ6.22 (ii B.C.), Plb.9.30.2 (new/s Plb. 10.4.4), etc.; Ion.nho/s, always in Hom. and Hdt. (v. infr.), but gen. ne[w/] IG12(7).1.4 (Amorgos, v B.C.); dat. neiw/| Michel832.38 (Samos, iv B.C.); Att. new/s (Attic Inscrr. of v-iii B.C. (v. infr.), once in Trag. (v. supr.), freq. in Prose authors and found in Com. (v. infr.)); declension, nom. new/s X.HG 1.6.1; gen. new/ IG12.4.9,80.6, Ar.Pl.733, IG22.1524.45, SIG1219.32 (Gambreum, iii B.C.); dat. new/| IG12.6.122, 256.4, Antipho6.39, Alex.40.3, IG22.1504.7; acc. new/n ib.12.24.13, al., X.HG6.5.9, Ar. Nu.401, Pl.741, Philem.139, f.l. in E.HF340, later new/ IG22.212.35 (iv B.C.), al., LXX 2 Ma.6.2, al., D.S.16.58 (v.l. new/n), SIG877A10 (ii/ iii A.D.), v.l. in D.H.4.26, but new/n Aristid.Or.27(16).19 (v.l. new/), Ach.Tat.3.6 (v.l. new/ Bast Epist.Crit.p.176), etc.: pl. nom. new/| X. HG6.4.7; acc. new/s A.Pers.810, Isoc.5.117, Plb.10.4.4; dat. new/|s IG12.384; on the accent v. Hdn.Gr.1.8: Aeol. nau=os Alc.9, IG12 (2).60.27 (Mytil.); Spartan navo/s ib.5(1).1564 (pl., found at Delos, v/iv B.C.):—
temple, Il.1.39, al., Pi.O.13.21 (pl.), etc.
inmost part of a temple, shrine containing the image of the god, Hdt.1.183, 6.19, X.Ap.15, UPZl.c.; e)n panti\ i(erw=| o(/pou nao/s e)sti PGnom.79 (ii A.D.).
portable shrine carried in processions, Hdt.2.63, D.S.1.15, etc. metaph., of Christians, n. qeou= e)ste 1 Ep.Cor. 3.16; of the body of Christ, Ev.Jo.2.19,21. [na^o/n and na^w= Orph.Fr. 32biv (Phaestus, ii B.C.); elsewh. a_.] (Perh. fr. na^s-vo/s, cf. nai/w.)
na_o/s, Dor. and Att. poet. gen. from nau=s. *na=os, v. *na/i+os.

na_ourgo/s, o(,
temple-builder, n. te/ktones Ephes.3.75.

na_ofu/lac [u^], a^kos, o(, （nao/s)
keeper, warden of a temple, E.IT1284, Arist.Pol.1322b25, BGU362 (iii A.D.); cf. naufu/lac 11. (nau=s)
master or
pilot of a ship, S.Fr.143.

na_o/w,
bring into a temple, ta\n a)ge/lan GDI5100.24 (Crete). naoi=: i(keteu/ei, Hsch.; cf. naeu/w, nau/w 11.

na^pai=os, a, on,
of a wooded vale or
dell, n. e)n *kiqairw=nos ptuxai=s S. OT1026; pla/kes E.HF958; n. qeo/s a
sylvan god, Ael.NA6.42, cf. 7.2.
na/peion [a_], to/, = na=pu, Nic.Al.430.

na/ph [a^], h(,
woodland vale, dell, glen, Il.8.558; *)apollwni/a n., of Delphi, Pi.P.6.9, cf. SIG546A11 (Delph., iii B.C.), GDI5016.9 (Gortyn); na/pai ka/llistai pleasant
valleys about a town, Hdt.4.157; xei/marros na/ph a torrent
glen, E.Ba.1093; h)\n a)po/rois na/pais e)ntugxa/nwsi X. Eq.Mag.4.4, cf. Cyn.9.11; o)/rh da/skia kai\ na/pai petrw/deis bre/montai Ar.Th.998 (lyr.), cf. Av.740 (lyr.), Pl.Lg.761b; cf. na/pos.
napo/as, napoi/as, napoo/s, v. newpoi/hs.
na/poinos: ma/taios, Hsch.

na/pos [a^], eos, to/, post-Homeric form, = na/ph, koilo/pedon n., of Olympia, Pi.P.5.39, cf. I.8(7).68, S.OC157 (lyr.), Tr.436, E.Andr. 284 (lyr.), etc.; of a
grove or
thicket, S.Aj.892 (lyr.); also,
ravine, gully, e)ge/nont' e)pi\ na/pei mega/lw| kai\ duspo/rw| X.An.6.5.12, cf. 22, Cyr. 1.6.43.
napta/lion, to/, or na_o-a/lios, h(, = na/fqa, Ph.Bel.90.18.

na=pu, to/, Att., = si/napi (cf. Phryn.255, Plin.HN19.171; on the accent v. Hdn.Gr.1.354),
mustard, n. *ku/prion Eub.19; n. ble/pein Ar. Eq.631: gen. na/puos Thphr.HP1.12.1: dat. na/pui+ IG42(1).126.17, 21 (Epid., ii A.D.), Luc.Asin.47.

na^pw/dhs, es,
woody, Eust.277.32, St.Byz. s.v. *bh=ssa.

nardi/zw,
resemble nard, Dsc.1.11,12.

na/rdinos, h, on,
of nard, n. mu/ron oil
of spikenard, Men.274, Plb.30.26.2; e)/laion n. Edict.Diocl.Troez.27, al.; ta\ n. Antiph.35.

nardi/ths [i_] oi)=nos,
wine flavoured with spikenard, Dsc.5.57 tit.
nardi=tis bota/nh, a variety of na/rdos, Gal.10.911.

nardoli^ph/s, e/s, (li/pos)
anointed with nard-oil, AP6.254 (Myrin.).
na/rdon, to/, = sq., Thphr.Od.12, Poll.6.104.

na/rdos, h(,
spikenard, Nardostachys Jatamansi, Thphr.HP9.7.2, Nic. Th.604, LXX Ca.1.12, Ev.Marc.14.3; n. *)indikh/ Dsc.1.7, etc.; na/rdou sta/xus Gal.12.84, al.; cf. sq. n. *keltikh/
Celtic nard, Valeriana celtica, Dsc.1.8, cf. Plin.HN14.107. n. o)reinh/ or o)rei/a
mountain nard, Valeriana Dioscoridis, Dsc.1.9 (cf. Thphr.HP 9.7.4). n. *suriakh/
Syrian nard, Cymbopogon Iwarancusa, Dsc. 1.7, cf. Plin.HN12.45. na/rdou r(i/za
ginger grass, Cymbopogon Schoenanthus, Arr.An.6.22, cf. 7.20. n. a)gri/a, = a)/saron, Dsc. 1.10; = fou=, ib.11.
oil of spikenard, PSI6.628.7 (iii B.C.), AP6.250 (Antiphil.), Aret.CD2.2, etc.; n. *babulwniakh/ Alex.308. (Semitic word, cf. Bab.
lardu.）
nardo/sta^xus, uos, o(, = foreg., Dsc.2.16, Gal.6.339.

nardofo/ros, on,
bearing nard, li/mnai Dsc.2.8.
narei=: threi=, Hsch. (cf. narou/s). na/rein: ku/ein, kru/ptein, zhtei=n, kui/+skesqai, a)me/lgesqai, Id. na/rh: h( a)/frwn kai\ mwra/, Id.
narqhk-i/a, h(, a plant allied to na/rqhc, Thphr.HP6.1.4, 6.2.7.

narqhk-ia/w,
beat with a na/rqhc or
rod, Hsch.

narqhk-i/zw,
splint a broken limb (orig.
with pieces of na/rqhc）, to\ sfuro/n Sch.Ar.Ach.1176, cf. Heraclas ap. Orib.48.2.2, Paul.Aeg.6.106.
splint planks
together with laths, in Pass., Apollod.Poliorc.159.4.

narqh/k-inos, h, on,
made of na/rqhc, Arist.Aud.803a41.

narqh/k-ion, to/,
small splint, Antyll. ap. Orib.44.23.74.
small rod used in e)pi/krousis 1, Gal.10.998. = a)sfo/delos, Ps.-Dsc.2.169.

narqh/k-isma, atos, to/,
splint, Apollod.Poliorc. 159.13.

narqhk-ismo/s, o(, prob. = e)pi/krousis 1, Dsc.Eup.1.233.
splinting of planks
with laths, Apollod.Poliorc.160.6.

narqhko-eidh/s, e/s,
like the na/rqhc, Dsc.3.81.

narqhko-plh/rwtos, on,
filling the hollow of the na/rqhc, puro\s phgh/ A.Pr.109.

narqhko-fa^nh/s, e/s,
looking like na/rqhc, Archig. ap. Orib.8.2.3.

narqhko-fo/ros, on,
carrying a wand of na/rqhc, like the *ba/kxai (cf. qursofo/ros), Plu.2.1107f; of Dionysus, Orph.H.42.1; prov., polloi/ toi n., pau=roi de/ te *ba/kxoi, i.e. there are many officials, but few inspired, Zen.5.77, cf. Pl.Phd. 69c, Orph.Fr.5.
rod-bearer, X.Cyr.2.3.18.

narqhkw/dhs, es,
like a na/rqhc, Thphr.HP1.6.10, Gp.5.8.2.

na/rqhc, hkos, o(,
giant fennel, Ferula communis, Thphr.HP1.2.7, Dsc.3.77, etc.; kle/yas . . puro\s thle/skopon au)gh\n e)n koi/lw| n., of Prometheus, Hes.Th.567, cf. Op.52; of the stalk used as a qu/rsos, E.Ba. 147 (lyr.), al.; as a schoolmaster's
cane, X.Cyr.2.3.20, cf. Arist.Pr. 948a10; as a
splint for a broken limb, Hp.Off.12, Gal.10.437;
singlestick for military exercises, Onos. 10.4.
casket for unguents, etc., Luc.Ind.29; h( e)k tou= n. dio/rqwsis, of Aristotle's recension of Homer, carried by Alexander in a n., Str.13.1.27, Plu.Alex.8. title of medical works by Heras, Cratippus, and Soranus, Gal.12.398,959, Aët.8.45.
fore-court of a church, EM597.48.
na/rka, h(, = na/rkh 1, Men.498, Sor.2.17, M.Ant.10.9.

na/rkafqon or na/skafqon, to/,
a fragrant Indianbark, used as a spice, etc. (perh. the same as la/kafqon), Dsc.1.23:—written nao/kafqon and na/kafqon in most codd. of Paul.Aeg.7.3; na/kafqon in one cod. of Id.7.22.4 (v.l. la/kafqon).

nark-a/w, fut. -h/sw LXX Da.11.6:—
grow stiff or
numb, xei na/rkhse Il.8.328; th
 yuxh
 kai\ to\ sto/ma narkw= Pl.Men.80b; yuxh=s narkw/shs Democr.290; to\ h(suxa/zon narka=| Epicur.Sent.Vat.11; to\ neu=ron o(\ e)na/rkhsen LXX Ge.32.32(33); xei nenarkhkui=a J.AJ8.8.5; of the numbness caused by the fish na/rkh, Arist.HA620b19, cf. Pl.Men. 84b; narkw=, nai\ to
 *pa=na Theoc.27.51.

na/rk-h, h(,
numbness, deadness, caused by palsy, frost, fright, etc., Hp.VM22, Aph.5.25; n. kata\ th=s xeiro\s kataxei=tai Ar.V.713, cf. Arist.HA515b20, Pr.867b29, 954a23 (pl.).
torpedo, electric ray, which
benumbs any one who touches it, Antiph.132.2, Anaxandr.41.52, etc.; h( platei=a n. h( qalatti/a Pl.Men.80a, cf. Arist.HA620b19; n. potami/a the Egyptian
electric eel, Malapterurus electricus, PMag.Osl.1.284, cf. Ath.7.312b: in metapl. acc. na/rka^ Opp.C.3.55.

na/rk-hsis,
torpor, Gloss.
narki/on: a)sko/n, Hsch.; cf. larki/on.

narki/ss-i^nos, h, on,
made of narcissus, Cratin.344, Dsc.1.53.
of the colour of na/rkissos, PRyl.154.8 (i A.D.).

narkiss-i/ths [i_], ou, o(,
like the narcissus, [li/qos] D.P.1031, Plin.HN37.188.

nark-o/w,
benumb, deaden, o)du/nhn narkoi= Hp.Liqu.6; nenarkwme/noi ib.1: c. acc. pers., Phld.Rh.1.380 S., cf. Hp.Epid.6.2.1.

nark-w/dhs, es,
numb, torpid, Id.Art.48 (Comp.), Dsc.3.101; to\ n. neu=ron, in the elbow, Hp.Mochl.1, cf. Prorrh.1.139, Art.19; baru/thtes n. Plu.2.
647b; po/nos n. Gal.8.70;
sluggish, o(rmai/ Phld.D.1.13. Ion. Adv. nark-wde/ws Hp.Prorrh.1.120, Mul.2.145.

na/rk-wsis, ews, h(,
a benumbing, gnw/mhs Id.Aph.5.16.

nark-wtiko/s, h/, o/n,
benumbing, narcotic, fa/rmaka Gal.10.862, al., Eust.1493.5.
na/rnac: kibwto/s, Hsch. (cf. la/rnac).

na_ro/s, a/, o/n, (na/w)
flowing, liquid, *di/rkh A.Fr.347; nara\ kai\ krhnai=a pota/ S.Fr.621; cf. nhro/s.
narou/s: tou\s fu/lakas, Hsch. (Perh. Dor. contr. from na_or（v)-, cf. narei=, nauro/s.)
na/rth, h(, plant used in perfumery, Thphr.HP9.7.3.
na/rfh, h(, a fancy loaf, = masitri/s, Hsch. na=s, h(, Dor. for nau=s. na/sqh, v. nai/w. na_siw/tas, a, o(, Aeol. and Dor. for nhsiw/ths. na/skafqon, to/, v. na/rkafqon.

nasmo/s, o(, (na/w)
flowing: stream, spring, E.Hipp. 225 (anap.), 653; foinissome/nhn ai(/mati . . , nasmw=| melanaugei= Id.Hec. 153 (anap.); eu)dro/soisi *kastali/as v. Aristonous 1.43.
nasmw/dhs, es, = namatw/dhs, Hsch. na/ssa, na/ssato, v. nai/w. na=ssa, Boeot. for nh=ssa, nh=tta.

na/ssw, Att. na/ttw, fut. na/cw Hsch.: aor. e)/naca (v. infr.): pf. Pass. ne/nasmai and ne/nagmai (v. infr.):—
press, squeeze close, stamp down, gai=an e)/nace Od.21.122; oi( pai=des e)/natton ei)s ta\s spuri/das Hippoloch. ap.Ath.4.130b:—Pass.,
to be piled up, h( ko/pros h( nenagme/nh Hp.Nat. Puer.24; e)n de\ [th=| stiba/di] ne/nastai . . de/rmata Theoc.9.9: c. gen., kli=nai sisurw=n nenagme/nai （nenasm- codd.)
piled up with . . , Ar.Ec. 840.
stuff quite full, na/ttw to\n qu/lakon Epict.Fr.23:— Pass., pa=sa oi)ki/a o(plitw=n ne/nakto
was crammed with . . , J.BJ1.17.6.

nasth/r, h=ros, o(, (nai/w)
inhabitant, Zonar.
na/sths, ou, o(, = foreg., Hsch.
nasti/skos, o(, Dim. of nasto/s 1.3, Pherecr. 130.7.

nastoko/pos, on,
cutting up cakes, Pl.Com.246.

nasto/s, h/, o/n, (na/ssw)
close-pressed, firm, Hp.Gland.16; ka/lamos, i. e.
archer's reed, Arundo Plinii, Dsc.1.85; of a tumour, Aët.15.8; sfugmo/s Archig. ap. Gal.8.931: Comp., Id.ib.509.
solid, opp. keno/s, Democr. ap. Arist.Fr.208, cf. Ph.1.330, Simp.in Cael. 295.5. nasto/s (sc. plakou=s), o(,
well-kneaded cake, esp. used in sacrifice,
cheese-cake, Pherecr.108.5, Ar.Av.567, Pl.1142, Metag.6.3. c. gen.,
filled full of, po/lis nasth\ a)ndrw=n J.BJ6.9.4.

nasto/ths, htos, h(,
solidity, absence of void, Alex.Aphr.in Metaph. 35.27, Simp.in Cael.609.18,
in de An.64.3, Phlp.in Ph.506.6.

nasto-fa^ge/w,
eat cakes, Poll.6.75, Hsch.

nasto-fa/gos [fa^], on,
eating cakes, Poll.6.75.
nath=res: u(phre/tai, h)\ kerami/des, Hsch. nattare/on: polu/rroun, Id. (leg. na=tor: r(e/wn, polu/rrous).

na/twr [a_], oros, o(, （na/w)
flowing, *)/inaxe, na=tor pai= . . *)wkeanou= S.Fr. 270 (anap.), cf. foreg. and nae/twr.

naua_g-e/w, Ion. nauhg-, pf. nenaua/ghka Hdt.7.236 (-hg-), Eub.76: (nau=s, a)/gnumi):—
suffer shipwreck, Hdt. l. c., X.Cyr.3.1.24, D.34.10, etc.: metaph., of chariots, Id.61.29; of an earthen vessel, A.Fr. 180; of persons, n. e)n toi=s i)di/ois Thphr. ap. D.L.5.55, cf. Phld.Vit. p.33 J.; e)n tw=| bi/w| Ceb.24.2; peri\ th\n pi/stin 1 Ep.Ti.1.19; xw( me\n e)naua/gei gai/hs e)/pi AP5.208 (Posidipp. or Asclep.); nauagei= sumpo/sia mh\ tuxo/nta paidagwgi/as o)rqh=s Plu.2.622b.
naua_g-hsmo/s, o(, = sq., Hdn. Epim.180.

naua_g-i/a, Ion. nauhgi/h, h(,
shipwreck, Hdt.7.190,192, al., E.Hel.1070, etc.; nauagi/a| xrh=sqai, peripi/ptein, Luc.VH2.35, Tox. 2: in pl., Pi.I.1.36 (s. v. l.); e)n xeimw=ni kai\ nauagi/ais Ar.Th.873.

naua_/g-ion, Ion. nauh/gion, to/,
piece of wreckage, Men.536.9, Arist.Pr.932a1: mostly in pl., A.Pers.420, Hdt.7.191, 8.12, al., Lys.2.38, Th.1.50, etc.; pollou\s a)riqmou\s a)/gnutai nauagi/wn, i. e. is shivered into a thousand pieces, E.Hel.410: metaph., n. i(ppika/
wreck of an overturned chariot, S.El.730, 1444; a)ndrw=n daitumo/nwn n. the
wreck of a feast, Choeril.9; ta\ n. th=s po/lews Demad. ap. Plu.2.803a; n. oi)/kwn ib. 517f. later, = nauagi/a, nauagi/w| peripesei=n Str.4.1.7.

naua_g-o/s, o/n, Ion. nauhgo/s (also in late Prose, Alciphr.1.18),
shipwrecked, Hdt.4.103, E.Hel.408, Philem.213.3; nauagou\s a)nairei=sqai pick up
shipwrecked men, X.HG1.7.4; n. ta/fos, i. e. a watery grave, AP7.76 (Diosc.); n. mo/ros ib.9.84 (Antiphan.). Act.,
causing shipwreck, a)/nemoi ib. 105. (a)/gw) = nau/arxos, Euph.158.

nauarx-e/w,
command a fleet, Hdt.7.161, X.An.5.1.4, IG12(8).183 (Samothrace), Phld.Rh.2.209 S.: c. gen., n. [ploi/wn] Philipp. ap. D. 18.77. in the cult of Isis,
preside at the festival of the ship (ploiafe/sia), *)arx.*delt. 1.152, al. (Eretria).
naua/rx-hs, ou, o(, = nau/arxos, Lyd.Mag. 1.27.

nauarx-i/a, h(,
command of a fleet, Th.8.20,33;
period of such command, X.HG1.5.1: pl., Arist.Pol.1322b3.
naval supremacy, ib.1274a12.
fleet, Lyc.733.

nauarx-i/s (sc. nau=s), i/dos, h(,
admiral's flagship, Plb.1.51.1, D.S.11.27, Plu.Alc.27, Longus 2.28; n. trih/rhs D.S.20.7.
mistress of a fleet, epith. of cities, e.g. Laodicea ad Mare, IG3.479; of Tripolis, ib.622; of Tyre, ib.14.830.

nau/arx-os, o(,
commander of a fleet, admiral, A.Pers.363, Hdt.7.59, 8.42, Eub.67.11, IG12(3).103.12 (pl., Nisyros); ou)/te strathgou\s ou)/te n. S.Aj. 1232; esp.
the Spartan admiral-in-chief, Th.4.11, 8.6,20,23, X.An. 1.4.2, etc.; used of an inferior naval officer, Decr. ap. D.18.73;
nauarchorum coetus circiter provincias Orientis, Cod.Just.11.2.4. as Adj., e)pi\ naua/rxw| sw/mati . . tw=| basilei/w| A.Ch.723 (anap.).

nauba^re/w,
weigh down a ship, Ph.2.465.

nauba^t-e/w,
serve as nauba/ths in the cult of Isis (cf. nauarxe/w 11), CIG2955 (Ephesus).

nauba^/t-hs, ou, o(, (bai/nw)
seafarer, seaman, Hdt.1.143, A.Pers.1011 (lyr.), S.Ph.301, 540, Th.1.121, Rev.Bibl.14.290 (Megiste), etc. as Adj., n. strato/s A.Ag.987 (lyr.); o(plismoi/ ib.405 (lyr.); n. sto/los S.Ph.270; n. lew/s E.IA294 (lyr.); n. a)nh/r collective for nauba/tai, A.Pers.375.

nau/bion, to/,
cubic measure in Egypt, with side = two royal cubits (in Roman times, three cubits), used with application to earth as a unit of labour, in pl., PLille 1r.11, Wilcken Chr.385.8, PPetr.3pp.80,290, Ostr.Bodl.i 244 (all iii B. C.), Arch.Pap.6.132 (i A. D.), POxy.669.11 (iii A. D.):—written naou/ia ib. 1053 (vi/vii A. D.). in sg., tax paid by landholders in lieu of digging so many nau/bia, PTeb.5.15 (ii B. C.); n. katoi/kwn, e)nafesi/wn, BGU662 (ii A. D.), PTeb.352 (ii A. D.). perh. another tax, Ostr.1396 (i A. D.), Ostr.Bodl.iii 84 (i A. D.).
*naudamhno/s, o(, epith. of Zeus at Sinope, AJP9.303.

nau/deton, to/, (de/w A)
ship's cable, E.Tr.811 (lyr.).
nau-hge/ths, ou, o(, = nau/arxos, Lyc.873.
nau-hge/w, nau-hgi/a, nau-h/gion, nau-hgo/s, Ion. for nauag-.
nau/klaros, = nau/kraros, Hsch.

nauklhr-e/w,
to be a shipowner, Ar.Av.598, X.Lac.7.1, Lys.6.49; *)erasiklh=s marturei= kuberna=n th\n nau=n h(\n *(ublh/sios e)nauklh/rei Test. ap. D.35.20: c. gen., forthgo\n h(=s e)nauklh/rei *(rwmai=os a)nh/r Plu.Pomp. 73. metaph., n. po/lin
manage, govern, A.Th.652, S.Ant. 994.
to be manager of a tenement-house (v. nau/klhros 11), n. sunoiki/an e)n *peiraiei= Is.6.19, cf. Alex. 138.

nauklh/r-hma, atos, to/,
voyage, Tz.H.9.60 (pl.).

nauklhr-i/a, h(,
life and calling of a nau/klhros,
ship-owning, Lys.6.19, Pl.Lg.643e, Arist.Pol.1258b22, etc.: in pl., And.1.137, Vett.Val.73.6. poet.,
voyage, S.Fr.143, E.Alc. 112 (lyr.).
adventure, enterprise, Id.Med.527.
ship, Id.Hel.1519, Plu.2.87a.

nauklhr-iko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for a nau/klhros, Luc. DMeretr.2.2; n. di/aita Moschio ap.Ath.5.207c; n. a)/nqrwpoi
Peripl. M.Rubr. 21; ta\-ka/, = nauklhri/a, Pl.Lg.842d.

nauklh/r-ion, to/,
ship of a nau/klhros, in pl.,
property in ships, D.23.211, Plu.2.234f: sg., POxy. 87.7 (iv A. D.). = nau/staqmos, E.Rh.233 (lyr., pl.).

nauklhro-ku^bernh/ths, ou, o(,
pilot of a nauklh/rion, Wilcken Chr.434.4 (iv A. D.), etc.

nauklhro-ma/xi^mos [ma^], o(,
sailor in the fleet of the Ptolemies, PTeb.5.46 (ii B. C.), UPZ110.22 (ii B. C.).

nau/klhr-os, o(,
shipowner and merchant (opp. e)/mporos, q. v.), IG12.127.34, 128.4, Hdt.1.5, 4.152, S.Ph.128, 547, E.Fr.417, Ar.Av.595, Th.1.137, X.Mem.3.9.11.
skipper, sailing-master, OGI344.4 (Delos, ii B. C.), Act.Ap.27.11, POxy.63.4 (ii/iii A. D.). generally,
captain, commander, A.Supp.177: as Adj., n. pla/th S.Fr.430; n. xei/r
the master's hand, of a charioteer, E.Hipp.1224; n. po/lis Philostr.VS2.26.2. at Athens,
one who rented and sub-let tenement-houses, Sannyr.6, Hyp.Fr.37, Diph.37, cf. Hsch., Poll.1.75. = nau/kraros, Id.8.108 (s. v. l.); cf. nau/klaros.

nauklhr-w/simos, on,
to be sub-let to lodgers, ste/gai Hsch.
nauko/ros, v. newko/ros.

naukra/r-ia [kra_], ta/,
registry of the nau/kraroi, Ammon.Diff. p.94 V.; naukrarei=a in Thom.Mag.p.246 R.

naukrar-i/a, h(,
naucrary (v. nau/kraros), Arist.Ath.8.3, Clidem.8, Phot.

naukrar-iko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for a nau/kraros or naukrari/a, a)rgu/rion Lex Solonis ap.Arist.Ath.8.3, cf. Harp.s.v. naukrarika/.

nau/krar-os, o(, in early Athens,
the chief official of a division (naukrari/a)
of the citizens for financial and administrative purposes, Lex Solonis ap.Arist.Ath.8.3, etc.; oi( pruta/nies tw=n n. Hdt. 5.71; [*kleisqe/nhs] kate/sthse dhma/rxous th\n au)th\n e)/xontas e)pime/leian toi=s pro/teron n. Arist.Ath.21.5; cf. nau/klhros 11.2, nau/klaros. （-kraros prob. = 'chief', cf. pr. n. [*l]akrari/das IG7.1931: from -kra_sros, cf. ka/ra.)

naukra^t-e/w,
have the command of the sea, Th.7.60:—Pass.,
to be mastered at sea, X.HG6.2.8.

naukra^t-h/s, e/s,
master or
mistress of the sea, naukrate/es th=s qala/sshs Hdt.5.36.

naukra^/t-hs (parox.), ou, o(,
holding a ship fast: name of a fish, th\n e)xenhi/+da naukra/thn e)/graye/ tis Eust.1490.19, cf. Cyran.31.

naukra^t-htiko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for victory at sea, shmei=on D.C.51.21.

naukra^t-i/a, h(,
naval victory, And.Fr.3, D.C. 49.7, etc.

*nau/kra^tis, ios or ews, h(, Naucratis in Egypt, Hdt.2.97; *naukrati/ths [i_], ou, o(, <*> Naucratite, Call.Epigr.40, Str.17.1.33; ste/fanos N., = sa/myuxos, Anacr.83:—Adj. *naukrati_tiko/s, h/, o/n, D.24.11.

naukra/twr [a^], oros, o(, h(, = naukrath/s, Hdt.6.9, Th.5.97,109.
master of a ship, S.Ph.1072.
nau=la, h(, later form for na/bla, Aq.Ps.32(33).2, Sm.Ps.91(92).4.
naulai=on, to/, = nau=lon 1b, Sammelb.4425iv32 (ii A. D.).
nau=llon, to/, = nau=lon 1a, IG11 (2).165.55, al. (Delos, iii B. C.), Sch. Ar.Ra.272:—also nau=llos, o(, Sch.Ar.l.c.; acc. nau=llon (gender indeterminate) IG22.1128.13.

naulodo/kos, o(,
receiver of freights, Ostr.1477 (ii A. D.).
nau=lon, to/, later form for na/bla, Hsch.s.v. na/blas. v. sq.

nau=los, o(, Ar. (v. infr.), IG22.1672.126,159, SIG1262.6 (Smyrna, i A. D.), Com.Adesp.286; also h(, acc. to Sch.Ar.Ra.272; and nau=lon, to/ (v. infr.), cf. nau=llon:—
passage-money, fare or
freight, e)/kbain', a)po/dos to\n n., says Charon, Ar.Ra.270; th=s po/lews nau=lon telou/shs toi=s a)/gousi tou\s li/qous IPE12.32B50 (Olbia, iii B. C.); nau=lon sunqe/sqai to agree upon one's
fare, X.An.5.1.12; to\n. tw=n cu/lwn parasxei=n D.49.26, cf. IGll. cc.; to\ n. a)posterei=n Din.1.56; parapo/llumi to\ n. Arisipp. ap. Plu.2.439e; e)/dwke to\ n. au)tou= LXX Jn.1.3; lalw=n ta\ n. Diph.43.21; e)/dwka au)tw=| ta\ n. Sammelb.3553; to\ de\ n. diwrqwsa/meqa u(pe\r au)tw=n PCair.Zen.52.13 (iii B. C.); sune/bh nau=lon h(mi=n prosa/gesqai tou= . . ploi/ou we were charged for the
hire of the boat, ib.368.27 (iii B. C.). n. ploi/ou name of a tax paid for the use of state-provided boats, BGU 645.16 (ii A. D.), PSI8.960.15 (iv A. D.); a)podiagra/yein to\ sunaxqhso/menon n. e)pi\ th\n basilikh\n tra/pezan PTheb.Bank 12.7 (ii B. C.), cf.
Sammelb.6954.
freight, cargo of ships, to\ n. sfeteri/z<*> D.32.2.
rent of a tenement, Poll.1.75. nau<*>la, ta/, e)fo/dia, Hsch. (ascribed to Aeschylus by Cyr. in cod. Laur.57.39).

naulox-e/w,
lie in a harbour or
creek, esp.
lie in wait in order to sally out on passing ships, abs. in Hdt.7.189, 192, 8.6, E.IA249 (lyr.):— Med., nauloxei=sqai/ tini D.H.1.44 (s. v.l.). c.acc.,
lie in wait for, Th.7.4.

naulox-i/a, h(,
anchorage, esp. of pirates, App.Mith.92.
naulo/x-ion, to/, = nau/loxos 11, Ar.Fr.78.

nau/lox-os, on,
affording a safe anchorage, epith. of a harbour, lime/nes d' e)/ni n. au)th=| Od.4.846; n. e)s lime/na 10.141; n. lipw\n e(/dras S.Aj.460; w)= n. kai\ petrai=a qerma\ loutra/ ye hot springs
by the haven and from the rock (unless nau/loxa is Subst.), Id.Tr.633 (lyr.); *)axaiw=n nau/loxoi periptuxai/ E.Hec.1015: Sup. nauloxw/tatos limh/n Ph.1.181, cf. 352. Subst.,
station for ships, haven, Suid.: also neut. pl. nau/loxa Plu.2.984b; cf. supr.

naul-w/simos, on,
for hire, ploi=on POxy.276.7 (i A.D.); kth/nh, o)/noi, PRein.54.4 (iii/iv A.D.), PFlor.238.7 (iii A.D.).

naul-wtiko/s, h/, o/n,
for chartering of ships: -kh/ (sc. suggrafh/), h(, POxy.643 (ii A.D.).
nau=ma, = polu/gonon, Hsch.

nauma^x-e/w,
fight by sea, Hdt.7.143, al.; tini
with one, Id.2.161; e)nanti/a th=| po/lei And.1.101; pro/s tinas X.HG2.1.14; peri\ patri/dos Hdt.8.57; n. th\n peri\ tw=n krew=n, i.e.
to be in the battle of Arginusae (v. kre/as 2), Ar.Ra.191; ma\ tou\s e)n *salami=ni naumaxh/santas D.18.208, cf. Pl.Mx.241b, 241d. metaph.,
do battle with, kakoi=s tosou/tois Ar.V.479.

nauma^x-hsei/w, Desiderat. of naumaxe/w,
wish to fight by sea, Th.8.79.

nauma^x-hte/on,
one must fight by sea, Arist.Rh.1376a2.

nauma^x-i/a, Ion. -ih, h(,
sea-fight, Hdt.6.14, al., Th.1.13, etc.; n. poie/esqai Hdt.8.49; naumaxi/h| krath/sas, e(sswqe/ntes, Id.3.39, 6.92; naumaxi/a| nika=n X.HG1.6.2; naumaxi/as nenikh/kate ib.1.1.28; naumaxi/an a)pw/sasqai/ tina
in a sea-fight, Th.1.32; polla\s n. nenaumaxhkw/s Lys.7.41; th\n peri\ *salami=na n. tw=n *(ellh/nwn pro\s tou\s barba/rous Pl.Lg.707b.

nau/ma^x-os, on (proparox.),
of or
for a sea-fight, custa\ n. pikes
for sea-battles, Il. 15.389, cf. 677; do/rata n. Hdt.7.89, cf. D.Chr.11.117, Opp.H.5.301, C.2.62. parox. nauma/xos, Act.,
fighting at sea, AP7.741 (Crin.), Ath.4.154f, IG3.1202.146 (iii A. D.).
nau=on, to/, perh. an Egyptian measure of length, PCair.Zen.383 (iii B. C.).
nau=os, v. nao/s.

*nau/paktos, h(, (nau=s, ph/gnumi)
Naupactus, on the north of the gulf of Corinth, Th.2.91:—Adj. *naupa/ktios, a, on, A.Supp.262, etc.

nauphg-ei=on, to/,
shipyard, D.S.19.58; cf. nauph/gion.

nauphg-e/w,
to be a shipbuilder, build ships, Ar.Pl.513, Pl.Alc.1.107c:—more freq. in Med., ploi=a, ne/as nauphge/esqai,
build oneself ships,
get them
built, Hdt.2.96, 6.46, cf. Pl.l.c.; e)pi/ tini against others, Hdt.1.27; e)nauphgou=nto new=n sto/lon Th.1.31; trih/reis e)nauphghsa/meqa And.3.5, cf. Th. 6.90, D.17.28: pf. nenauph/ghmai in med. sense, D.S.20.16:—Pass., of ships,
to be built, Th.1.13 (v.l. e)nnauphghqh=nai); o(po/sa a)\n oi)kodomhqh=| h)\ nauphghqh=| X.Vect.4.35, cf. HG1.3.17, Plu.2.321d. metaph. in Med.,
contrive, 'engineer', ta\ pa/nta nenauphghme/nh e)pi\ tai=s *(rwmai/wn tu/xais J.AJ19.2.4.

nauphg-h/s, e/s,
shipbuilding, te/xnai Man.4.323.

nauphg-h/si^mos, on, also h, on Pl.Lg.705c, Str.14.5.3:—
useful in shipbuilding, of timber, i)/dh Hdt.5.23; cu/la Th.4.108, 7.25, X.HG5.2.16, SIG135.10 (Olynthus, iv B.C.); u(/lh Pl.l.c., Str.l.c.; xw/ra Philostr.Her.19.20.
nauph/g-hsis, ews, h(, = sq., Sammelb.6994.30 (iii B.C.), Asp.in EN143.13, Hsch. s.v. culodwni/h.

nauphg-i/a, Ion. -ih, h(,
shipbuilding, Hdt.1.27; n. a(rmo/zein to practise
shipbuilding, E. Cyc.460; nauphgi/an trihrw=n paraskeua/zesqai Th.4.108, cf. D.S.19.58.

nauphg-ko/n Plu.2.571f;
contract for building a ship, PLond.3.1164h14 (iii A.D.).

nauph/g-ion, to/,
shipbuilder's yard, dockyard, Ar.Av.1157, Inscr.Délos 363.41, 365.20 (iii B. C.).

nauphg-o/s, o(, (ph/gnumi)
shipbuilder, shipwright, Th.1.13, Pl.R.333c, al., PPetr.2
p.61 (iii B. C.), PCair.Zen.270.8 (iii B.C.):—written navuphgo/s IG12.672; naphgo/s ib.428.

*naupli/a, Ion. -ih, h(, Nauplia in Argolis, Hdt.6.76, etc.; *nauplieu/s, e/ws, o(,
a Nauplian, Str.8.6.14:—Adj. *nau/plios, a, on, E.Or. 369; or nauphg-i/eios, ib.54.

nau/plios, o(, a kind of
shell-fish, Peripl.M.Rubr.17; f.l. for nauti/los, Artem.2.14.
nau/poda: makro/poda, Hsch. (false division of tanau/poda).

nau/-poros, on, = nausi/poros,
ship-frequented, a)ktai/ A.Eu.10; li/mnhs sto/ma A.R.4.1546. parox. naupo/ros, = nausi/poros 11.2, pla/th E.Tr.877.

nau/-prhstis, idos, h(, (pi/mprhmi) Adj.
burning ships, EM 598.43.

nau-pru/ta^nis [u^], ios, o(,
ruling ships or
the sea, dai/mwn Pi. Pae.6.130.
nauro/n: o)/gkos, Hsch. nauri/zein: katamwka=sqai, Id.

nauro/s, o(,
temple-guard, IG14.401 (Messana). (Cf. narou/s: prob. from nao/s and -horvo- (e)ru/w B), cf. qurwro/s, etc.)

nau=s, h(, (v. infr.)
ship, Hom., etc. (but rare in non-literary Hellenistic Greek, once in
NT, Act.Ap.27.41, ploi=on being generally used); e)n nh/essi or e)n nhusi/n at
the ships, i.e. in the camp formed by the ships drawn up on shore, Il.2.688, 11.659; nh=es makrai/
ships of war, built long and taper for speed, Th.1.41, etc.; opp. nh=es stroggu/lai round-built merchant-
ships, Hdt.1.163, etc.; ne/es alone, = trih/reis, opp. penthko/nteroi, Id.8.1; nh=es kenai/, i.e. without fighting men in them, D.3.5; nau=s makra/ collective for makrai/, A.Pers.380.— Att. d<*><*><*> new<*>n （nhw<*>n is v.l. in Lys.13.15), nauoi/, nau<*>s; in later writers, <*>m. pl. nau=s, acc. pl. nh=as, D.S.13.13, Plb.5.2.4, etc., cf. Phryn.147:— Ep. nhu=s, nho/s, nhi/+, nh=a, pl. nh=es, nhw=n, nhusi/ or nh/essi, nh=as (but also gen. and acc. sg. neo/s, ne/a [the latter as monosyll. in Od.9.283], pl. ne/es, new=n, ne/essi, ne/as); Ep. gen. and dat. pl. nau=fi, -fin, Il.2.794, 16.281, Od.14.498; in late Ep., nom. nh=us dub. l. in Mosch.2.104, cf. EM440.17; acc. sg. and pl. nhu=n, nhu=s, A.R.1.1358, Herod.2.3, Dem. Bith.4.6: Hdn.Gr.1.401, 2.675,553 also gives neu=s, nei/+ (v.l. in Hdt. 7.184), and neusi/ (Hp.Ep.27, Sammelb.5829):—Ion. nhu=s, neo/s, nhi/+, ne/a, pl. ne/es, new=n, nhusi/ (nhusi/n Epigr. in IG12(8).683 (Thasos, vi/v B. C.)), ne/as (but nho/s Archil.(?) in PLit.Lond.54; nho/s is freq. in codd. of Hdt., nhw=n 7.160):—Dor. nau=s (na=s Hdn.Gr.1.400), na_o/s Pi. P.4.185, al., na_i/+ Id.O.13.54, al. (na=| perh. to be read in Alcm.23 iii 27), nau=n Pi.P.4.245, Fr.234 (na=n Hdn.Gr.1.328, na=a B.16.89); pl. na=es Pi.O.12.4,al., naw=n Id.P.1.74, nausi/, nausi/n, Id.N.7.29, P.3.68 (na/essi ib.4.56), na=as f.l. in Theoc.22.17:—Aeol. sg. gen. na=os, dat. na=i+, pl. dat. na/essi, Alc.19,18,79, gen. na_/wn Id.Supp.12.9, Sapph. Supp.5.2:—Trag. commonly use Dor. forms in lyr., Att. in dialogue (but sts. nao/s, naw=n, A.Th.62, Pers.340, etc.); the Ep. forms nho/s S. Fr.761, nhw=n E.IT1485, nh=as A.Supp.744 (lyr.), nhusi/n Id.Pers.370 (cod. M) are prob. corrupt. (Cf. Skt.
naús, Lat.
nāvis, etc.)
nau=sqlon, to/, = nau=lon, IG4.823.12 (Troezen), Hsch.

nausqlo/w,
carry by sea, e)k ga=s E.Tr.162 (lyr.); e)s gh=n patri/da nausqlw/swn nekro/n Id.Supp.1037:—Med.,
take with one by sea, nausqlou=sqe pai=da Id.IT1487:—Pass.,
go by sea, nausqlou=mai Id.Tr.677; pela/gesin nausqlou/menos Id.Hel.1210; ou) nausqlw/somai Ar.Pax 126. Pass.,
to be visited by ships, gh= nausqlwqh/setai Lyc.1415.
nausi/a, Ion. -ih, v. nauti/a.

nausi/-a_sis [i^], ews, h(,
squeamishness, Hsch.
nausi-a/w, = nautia/w, pf. nenausi/aka BGU1097.4 (i A. D.).
nausi-ba/ths [a^], ou, o(, = nauba/ths, Lyr.Alex.Adesp.33.7, Man.1.323, Hsch.s.v. baruda/nin.

nausi/-bi^os, on,
living by the sea, Alciphr.1.12 (pr.n.).

nausi/-dromos, on,
ship-speeding, ou)=ros Orph.H.74.10.

nausi-kleito/s, h/, o/n,
famed for ships, famous by sea, kou/rh| nausikleitoi=o *du/mantos Od.6.22, cf. h.Ap.31, 219.
nausi-klu^to/s, o/n, = foreg., *fai/hkes, *foi/nikes, Od.7.39, 15.415; fem. nausikluta/n Pi. N.5.9.

nausi-o/eis, essa, en,
feeling nausea or
disgust, Nic.Al.83 (v.l. naut-), 482.

nausi-pe/dh, h(,
anchor, Luc.Lex.15.

nausi-pe/ra_tos, Ion. nhusipe/rhtos, on,
navigable, Hdt.1.189,193,5.52, Arist.Mete.351a18, D.H.3.44.

nausi/-podes, oi(,
ship-footed, of islanders, Hsch., Eust.1515.27.

nausi/-pompos, on,
ship-wafting, au)/ra E.Ph.1712 (lyr.).

nausi/-poros, on,
traversed by ships, navigable, of a river, X.An.2.2.3, Arist.Mir.846b31, Hld.10.5, Philostr.VA3.1. parox. nausipo/ros, on, Act.,
passing in a ship, seafaring, stratia/ E.Rh.48 (lyr.).
causing a ship to pass, pla/tai n.
ship-speeding oars, Id.IA172 (lyr.).

nausi/-stonos u(/bris, the
lamentable loss
of the ships, Pi.P.1.72.

nausi-fqo/ros, on,
ship-destroying, au)=rai Tim.Pers.144.

nausi-fo/rhtos, on,
carried by ship, seafaring, a)/ndres Pi.P.1.33.

nausi/-wsis, ews, h(, = nausi/asis,
vomiting: hence flebw=n n.
gushing of blood from the veins, Hp. Fract.11 (pl.).

nausoi/khtos, on,
occupied by ships, Sch.Opp.H.5.461.
nau=sson, to/, name of a tax, SIG4.6 (Cyzicus, vi B.C.), 1000.1 (Cos, i B.C.).—In SIG4 -ss- is written T.

nau/-staqmon, to/, (staqmo/s)
harbour, anchorage, roadstead, Th.3.6, E.Rh.602 (pl.):—more freq. nau/-staqmos, o(, Plb.5.19.6, D.S.27.12, Plu. Nic.16, etc.; hence of
ships assembled in a roadstead, Id.Arist.22, Lys.5.
nau/sths, ou, o(, = nau/ths, Sammelb.1207.
naustilei/a, h(, late form, = nautili/a, PGrenf.2.80.16,2.81.16 (v A.D.).

naustol-e/w, fut. -h/sw. E.Supp.474: pf. nenausto/lhka （sun-) S.Ph. 550: trans.,
carry or
convey by sea, da/marta E.Or.741 (troch.): metaph., i)/dia n. e)pikw/mia
providing matter for their own praise, Pi. N.6.32, cf. Luc.Lex.2:—Pass., with fut. Med. -h/somai,
go by sea, E. Tr.1048; ta\ naustolou/mena Id.Fr.492.6; thlikou=ton pe/lagos naustolhqei/s D.S.4.13.
guide, steer, metaph., kuma/twn a)/ter po/lin sh\n naustolh/seis E.Supp.l.c.; tw\ pte/ruge poi= naustolei=s; whither
pliest thou thy wings? Ar.Av.1229; o( naustolw=n . . ei)m' e)gw\ ta\s sumfora/s the enterprise is mine, E.IT599. intr.,
go by ship, sail, e)c *)ili/ou S. Ph.245; pro\s oi)/kous a)p' *)ili/ou E.Tr.77: metaph., dia\ po/nwn e)nausto/loun Id.Fr.821.2. c. acc. loci,
approach by sea, i(/ppoisin h)\ ku/mbaisi n. xqo/na; S.Fr.127 (by zeugma), cf. E.Med.682, Hipp.36, Cyc.106.— Poet. and later Prose.
nausto/l-hma, atos, to/, in pl., = sq., po/ntou naustolh/maq' E.Supp.209.

naustol-i/a, h(,
going by sea, naval expedition, Id.Andr.795 (lyr.), Str.16.2.23.

nausto-loge/w,
takeas a passenger, metaph. of *)axe/rwn, CIL8.21445 (Caesarea Mauret.).

nausto-lo/gos, o(, =
navis dispositor, Gloss.: also, in pl.,
pilotage dues, ib.

nau/stolos, on,
dispatched or
equipped as a ship, crossing the water, A.Th.858.

naut-ei/a, h(,
naval affairs, su/llhyis tw=n ei)s th\n n. OGI90.17 (Rosetta, ii B.C.), cf. PRev.Laws85.6 (iii B.C.).

nau/t-hs, ou, o(, (nau=s)
seaman, sailor, Il.19.375, Sapph.Supp.9.8, Pi.P.4.188, Pl.Plt.302a, etc.: as Adj., n. o(/milos E.Hec.921 (lyr.);
by sea, opp. pezo/s (by land), A.Pers.719 (troch.).
passenger by sea, nau/thn a)/gein tina/ S.Ph.901: metaph., sumposi/ou nau=tai
mates in the drinking bout, Dionys.Eleg.5.

naut-i/a, Ion. nausi/h Semon.7.54, h(:—
seasickness, or generally,
nausea, Arist. PA664b13 (pl.), Aret.SA1.5,2.2, Alciphr.2.4, Jul.Or.6.190d: pl., Porph.Gaur.8.1. generally,
disgust, Semon.l.c.

naut-iasmo/s,
o(, = foreg., Hippiatr.130.

naut-ia/w, mostly in pres. and impf. (aor., Luc.Tox.19, Gal.16.665, Phryn.172: fut., Aristo Stoic.1.89):—
suffer from seasickness or
nausea, Ar.Th.882, Pl.Tht.191a, Lg.639b, Arist. Pr.868a6, D.Fr.30, Plu.Per.33; tau=ta d' e)sti\ plei=n h)\ nautia=n Com.Adesp.637; e)nauti/wn Luc.Nec.4. generally,
to be disgusted, Demetr.Eloc.15, Phryn.l.c.
naut-ieu/s, derivative of nau/ths, sine expl., EM63.55.

naut-iko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for a ship, seafaring, naval, o( n. strato/s Hdt.7.100,203, etc.; opp. o( pezo/s, Id.8.1; n. lew/s A.Pers.383; sto/los S.Ph.561; n. e)rei/pia wrecks
of ships, A.Ag.660; e(dw/lia S.Aj.1277; ska/fh ib.1278; n. po/lemos And.4.12; n. a)strologi/a Arist.AP0.79a1; e)/ggaia kai\ nautika/
property on land and
sea, PEleph.1.13 (iv B.C.); n. a)narxi/a
among the seamen, E.Hec.607; to\ n.
crew, Hp.Ep.14; but usu.
navy, fleet, Hdt.7.97, 160, Ar.Eq.1063, Th.1.36, etc.; h( -kh/ Hdt.7.161. of persons,
skilled in seamanship, nautical, nautikoi\ e)ge/nonto became
a naval power, Th.1.18, cf.7.21; nautiko/s, o(, = nau/ths, POxy.929.8 (ii/iii A.D.). h(-kh/ (sc. te/xnh)
navigation, seamanship, Hdt.8.1, etc.; ta\ -ka/ Pl.Alc.1.124e: ta\ -ka/, also,
naval affairs, sea-power, Th.4.75, X.HG1.6.4. nautiko/n, to/, perh.
pilot's fee, POxy.522.15 (ii A.D.); but usu.
money borrowed or
lent on bottomry, in full, n. xrh/mata Lys.32.7: mostly in pl., n. e)kdedome/na ib.6; nautiko\n a)nele/sqai to take
it up, borrow
it, D.50.17; nautikoi=s e)rga/zesqai Id.33.4: in sg., X.Vect.3.9; also n. to/kos D.L.6.99. Adv. -kw=s, danei/zein Id.7.13.

nauti^l-e/w|, dat. sg., perh. Coan form of *nauti/lw|,
The Sailor, as place-name, SIG1000.11 (Cos, i B.C.).

nauti^l-i/a, Ion. -ih, h(,
sailing, seamanship, Od.8.253, Hes.Op.618, Pl.R.527d, al.
voyage, Hdt.4.145, Hp.Aph.4.14: and in pl., nautili/h|si makrh=|si e)piqe/sqai Hdt.1.1, cf. 163; nautili/h|si xre/esqai Id.2.43, cf. Pi.N.3.22, I.4(3).57.
ship, polu/skalmos n. AP7.295.4 (Leon.).

nauti/llomai, only pres. and impf. (exc. aor. subj. nauti/letai [i_] Od.4.672 (prob.), inf. nauti/lasqai [i_] D.C.56.3):—
sail, go by sea, nauti/letai ei(/neka patro/s Od.l.c., cf. 14.246, Hdt.1.163, 2.5, al., S. Ant.717, E.Fr.793; n. th\n [qa/lassan]
sail on, navigate, Hdt.1.202; nautili/an nauti/llesqai Pl.R.551c. of the nautilus, kenw=| [tw=| o)stra/kw|] n. Arist.HA622b9. metaph., of water-fowl, Philostr. Im.1.9.

nauti/los [i^], o(, poet. for nau/ths,
seaman, sailor, Hdt.2.43, A.Pr. 468, S.Aj.1146: rare in Com., Nausicr.1.2, 2.10. as Adj. nau/ti^los, on,
of a ship, n. se/lmata A.Ag.1442; n. pla/th E.Fr.846. the
paper nautilus, Argonauta argo, a cephalopod mollusc fabled to sail by spreading its membranous arms, Arist.HA525a21, 622b5, cf. Call.Epigr.6.3, Opp.H.1.340, Ael.NA9.34.

nauti^lofqo/ros, on,
bane of sailors, Lyc.650.
nauti/s, i/dos, h(, fem. of nau/ths, gunai=kes Theopomp.Com.79.

nautiw/dhs, es, (nauti/a)
nauseous, sickening, Dsc.1.40, Antyll. ap. Orib.4.11.6, Plu.2.127a, 128d; to\ n. Gal.6.678.
disposed to nausea, dia/qesis Id.13.122,156. Adv. -dw=s, e)/xein Herod.Med. ap. Orib.5.27.22.

nauto-di/kai [i^], oi(, at Athens,
judges of the admiralty-court, IG12.41.4, Lys.17.5, Luc.DMeretr.2.2: they also took cognizance of grafai\ ceni/as, Cratin.233, cf. Ar.Fr.225.
nauto-kra/twr [a^], oros, = naukra/twr, BCH46.331 (Teos), v.l. in Th.5.97,109.

nauto-loge/w,
take on board passengers or
cargo, PLond.3.1164h19 (iii A.D.): metaph., *ku/prin n. AP9.415 (Antiphil.).

nauto-lo/gos, on,
collecting seamen, Str.8.6.15.

nauto-pai/dion, to/,
sailor boy, Hp.Epid.2.1.12.
nau/tria, h(, fem. of nau/ths, as if from *nauth/r, Ar.Fr.825.

nau-fa/gos [a^], on,
ship-devouring, wrecking, Lyc.1095.
nau/-farktos, v. nau/fraktos.

nau-fqori/a, h(,
shipwreck, loss of ships, AP7.73 (Tull. Gem.): pl., Man.1.324.

nau/-fqoros, on,
shipwrecked, n. stolh/, pe/ploi, the garb
of shipwrecked men, E.Hel.1382, 1539.

nau/-fraktos, Att. nau/-farktos Phot. (nau/f[ . . . .]os IG12.296.30), on: (fra/ssw):—
shipfenced, *)ia/nwn n. *)/arhs, of the Greeks at Salamis, A.Pers.951 (lyr.); so n. o(/milos ib.1029 (lyr.); stra/teuma E.IA1259; strato/s Ar.Eq.567; nau/farkton ble/pein to look like a
ship of war, Id.Ach.95.

nau-fu^la^ke/w,
guard a ship, Eust.1562.36.

nau-fu/lac [u^], o(,
one who keeps watch on board ship, Ar.Fr.372. = naofu/lac 1, IG42(1).402 (pl., Epid., ii A.D.).
nau/w, Aeol. for na/w (q.v.), Hsch. = i(keteu/w, Id., Phot. nauw/n, w=nos, o(, (nau=s) = new/n, new/rion, Hsch.

na/fqa^, h( (to/, Eust.700.56),
naphtha (Persian
naft), Dsc.1.73, D.C. 36.3a:—also na/fqas, o(, Str.16.1.15; acc. na/fqan LXXDa.3.64; gen. na/fqa Str.l.c., Plu.Alex.35.

nafro/n, to/,
linen thread, Hsch. naxado/n: saqro/n, Id. naxeile/s, = foreg., Id.

na/w, only pres. and impf., Att. contr. na=| S.Fr.5, part. nw=ntas Phot.:—
flow, e)n de\ krh/nh na/ei Od.6.292; kai\ frei/ata makra\ na/ousin Il. 21.197; o)/fr' a)\n u(/dwr te na/h| Epigr. ap. Pl.Phdr.264d; oi)/nw| *(axelw=|os a)=ra na=| S.l.c.; u(/dati na=e
was running with . . , A.R.1.1146; na=en fo/nw| Call.Dian.224:—Pass.,
to be watered, na_ome/noisi to/pois Nic.Fr. 74.58. [a^ in Hom. and presupposed by na=|, nw=ntas, cf. a)e/naos: a_ v.l. in Od.9.222, always in late Ep. exc. Euph.23; nai=on (so Aristarch. and some codd.) d' o)rw=| a)/ggea pa/nta is prob. correct in Od.l.c., cf. e)/naien e)n a(/lmh| (with pun on nai/w
dwell) Matro Conv.77, and naiome/noisi (neom- codd.) shd. perh. be read in Nic. l.c.] (Cf. e)/nnuqen, nau/w, no/a, Skt.
snaúti (pf. part. Pass.
snutás) 'drip', MIr.
snuadh 'river', etc.: na/w [a^] from
sn[acaron]w-w, nai/w and na/w [a_] from
sn[acaron]w-yw.）
naw/rion, v. new/rion.
ne/a, Ion. acc. of nau=s. v. neio/s.

nea/ggeltos, on,
newly or
lately told, fa/tis A.Ch.736.
nea_genh/s, f.l. for neogenh/s in E.IA1623 (unless scanned as trisyll.).

nea/zw, impf. e)ne/azon Agath.5.15: aor. 1 inf. nea/sai AP11.256 (Lucill.), elsewh. only pres.: (ne/os):—intr.,
to be young or
new, to\ nea/zon
youth, S.Tr.144; nea/zwn
thinking or
acting like a youth, E.Ph. 713; n. tw=| tro/pw| Men.749: metaph.,
to be full of youthful spirit, filei= de\ ti/ktein u(/bris palaia\ nea/zousan u(/brin A.Ag.764 (lyr.), cf. Supp. 105 (lyr.); nea/zein a)rxo/menos Alciphr.1.28.
to be the younger of two, o( me\n nea/zwn S.OC374.
grow or
be young again, APl.c.; o(/pws ghra/skwn nea/zh| toi=s a)gaqoi=s Epicur.Ep.3p.59U. Pass.,
to be renewed, ste/mma . . e)k patro\s paidi\ neazo/menon AP15.6. = nea/w, Hsch.s.h.v. nea/zomen: a)fiknou/meqa, Id.
ne/aira, v. nei/aira.

*ne/aira, h(,
Neaera, daughter of Oceanus:—hence *neairh/i+des i(/ppoi, Hsch.

ne-ai/retos, on,
newly taken, qh/r A.Ag.1063; po/lis ib.1065; bou/balis Id.Fr.330.
ne-a/khs, v. neh/khs.

ne-a^ko/nhtos, on,
newlywhetted, neako/nhton ai(=ma xeiroi=n e)/xwn S.El.1394 (lyr.); cf. ai(=ma 11 fin.

ne-aldh/s, e/s, (a)ldei=n)
newly grown or
produced, Opp.H.1.692.

ne-a/lestos [a^], on,
newly-ground, Sch.Nic.Al.410.

ne-alh/s, e/s,
newly caught, Suid., Hsch., Ammon.Diff.p.95 V.
fresh, not tired, of persons and animals, e(/ws nealh/s e)stin au)th\n th\n a)kmh/n Ar. Fr.361 ; i(/ppoi nealei=s, opp. a)peirhko/tes, X.Cyr.8.6.17; -e/steroi o)/ntes Pl.Plt.265b; freq. of soldiers, a)kmai=oi kai\ n. Plb.3.73.5, cf. 10.14.3; a)h/tthtoi kai\ n. Plu.Ant.39 (hence of
reserve troops, App.BC1.58); n. kai\ pro/qumos Plu.2.669a; -e/steros e)peiselqei=n Luc.Merc.Cond.26, cf. Alex.16. (ne/os, a(/ls A)
freshly salted, opp. tetarixeume/nos, D.25.61 (metaph.); turo/s Archig. ap. Gal.12.808; kre/as Gal.6.528; of a dead body, Luc.Nec.15; neale\s ga/la Nic.Al.364 (nearo/n cod. opt.).
young, = nearo/s, mo/sxos ib.358. [a^ only in Nic. ll.cc.]

ne-a/lwtos [a^], on,
newly caught, Hdt.9.120 (v.l. neoa/lwtos).

ne-a/mata, ta/, =
culta nova, Gloss.

ne-a^melgh/s, e/s,
newly milked, Paul.Aeg.4.1.
ne-a_me/ra, h(, Aeol., = noumhni/a, IG12(2).81.1 (Mytil.), Milet.3 No.152.37 (ii B.C.; nename/ra lapis).
ne-a/n, a=nos, o(, = ne/os, A.D.Adv. 160.8 (nea=n codd.), Suid.s.v. nea=nis, Eust.335.15; cf. cuna/n.

ne/-andros, on: a)lkh=| n. in battle
a young warrior, Lyc.1345.

ne-a_nei/a, h(,
spirited, audacious act, Ph.1.258, 2.128, cf. Hdn.Epim.265, Suid.; contr. fr. neaniei/a (q.v.).

ne-anqh/s, e/s,
new-blown, Nic.Al.609; ai)=nos IG3.716.16.

nea_n-i/as, ou, Ep. and Ion. nehni/hs, ew, o(, dat. pl. neani/ois IG9(2).205.25 (Phthiotis, iii B.C.): (nea/n):—
young man, Hom. (only in Od.) always with a)nh/r, nehni/h| a)ndri\ e)oikw/s Od.10.278; a)/ndres koimh/santo nehni/ai 14.524; pai=des nehni/ai Hdt.1.61, cf.7.99; n. gambro/s Pi.O.7.4; te/ktones kw/mwn n. Id.N.3.5: without a Subst. in Hdt.1.37,43, S.OC 335, El.750, E.Alc.698, X.Mem.3.1.2, etc. freq. with the sense of
a youth in character, i.e. either in good sense,
impetuous, active, E.Ion 1041, cf. Ar.V.1333, X.Cyr.1.3.6, D.18.313; or in bad sense,
hot-headed, wilful, headstrong, E.Supp.580; e(\n me\n toi/nun tou=to . . poli/teuma tou= neani/ou tou/tou D.18.136, cf. Pl.Sph.239d. as masc. Adj.,
youthful, neani/ai ta\s o)/yeis Lys.10.29. of things, etc.,
new, young, fresh, neani/ais w)/moisi E.Hel.1562; n. qw/raka kai\ braxi/ona Id.HF1095; a)/rtos Ar.Lys.1207; n. lo/goi
rash, wilful words, E.Alc.679. [neaniw=n is trisyll. in Ar.V.1069; cf. neaniko/s.]

nea_n-iei/a, h(,
youthful spirit, Ph.2.306; cf. neanei/a.

nea_n-i/euma, atos, to/,
youthful, i.e.
spirited or (in bad sense)
wanton, act or
word, Pl.R.390a, Luc. Herm.33, etc.; of an argument,
bold attempt, Simp.in Ph.1169.9.

nea_n-i^eu/omai (Act. only in Hsch.), fut. -eu/somai D.19.242: aor. e)neanieusa/mhn Id.21.69:—Pass. (v. infr.):—
to be a youth, Ph.1.303, Poll. 2.20. more freq.,
act like a hot-headed youth, wilfully or
wantonly, swagger, Ar.Fr.827, Lys Fr.324 S.; n. ei)s tou\s poli/tas
behave so towards . . , Isoc.20.17, cf. Hyp.Eux.27; e)n toi=s lo/gois Pl.Grg. 482c; neanieusa/menos ei)pei=n
with youthful insolence, Plu.Cic.1:— Pass., e)f' a(/pasi toi=s e(autw=| neneanieume/nois to all his
wanton acts, D. 21.18; ta\ e)n th=| boulh=| neanieuqe/nta Plu.Mar.29.
make youthful, i.e.
bold, promises, c. Adj. neut., n. toiou=ton, w(s . . D.19.194; ou)d' e)neanieu/sato toiou=ton ou)de/n Id.21.69; me/xri tou= lo/gou n. Luc.
Bis Acc. 21: c. inf.,
undertake with youthful spirit, Plu.Dem.3.
nea_n-i/zw, = foreg., Id.Flam.20, Poll.4.136.

nea_n-i^ke/w,
to be youthful, Eup. 109.

nea_n-i^ko/s, h/, o/n, (nea/n)
youthful, r(w/mh Ar.V.1067: mostly of youthful qualities : hence,
fresh, active, vigorous, fine, neanikw/tate Id.Eq.611; kre/as n. a
fine large piece, Id.Pl.1137; lopa/s Alex.188.2; of trees, Thphr.HP5.1.11 (Comp.); -w/tera a)gaqa/
more splendid, Pl.R.363c.
high-spirited, impetuous, gay, to\ neanikw/taton the
most dashing feat, Ar.V.1205; a)rxh\ kalh\ kai\ n. Pl.R.563e; gennai=on kai\ n. e)/rwta Id.Ly.204e; n. te kai\ megaloprepei=s ta\s dianoi/as Id.R.503c; me/ga kai\ n. fro/nhma D.3.32; ou) ga\r h(gei=to lampro\n ou)de\ n. Id.21.131, cf. 201. in bad sense,
headstrong, insolent, to\ n. tou= lo/gou Pl.Grg.508d; h)\ sou= tis -w/teros ib.509a; dhmokrati/a h( -wta/th Arist.Pol.1296a4. of things,
vehement, mighty, yu=cis -wta/th Hp.VM16; ai(morragi/a Id.Prorrh. 1.134; fo/bos E.Hipp.1204; bou/leuma Id.Fr.185.6: freq. in later Prose, e)piqumi/a n. Arist.EN1148a21; bronth/ Id.HA602b23; no/shma ib.602b29; xeimw/n Thphr.Ign.17. Adv. -kw=s
in a youthful manner, e)stei/lamen e(autou\s n. X.Eph.5.1.
vigorously, Ar.Pax 898; n. bohqei=n tini Pl.Tht.168c; biai/ws kai\ n. Dsc.1.56; of things, Ph.Bel.78.29: Comp. -kwte/rws, a)gaqo/s Phld.Rh.2.272 S.
violently, wantonly, tu/ptein, twqa/zein, Ar.V.1307, 1362; n. a)ko/lastos Phld.Acad.Ind.p.47 M.
excessively, n. tromw/dea Hp.Prorrh. 1.9; n. prospefuke/nai to be
firmly attached to . . , Arist.HA530a15. [neanikh/n is trisyll. in Ar.V.1067; cf. neani/as.]

nea_n-i^ko/ths, htos, h(,
youthfulness, Sext.Ps.9.1.

nea=nis, Ep. and Ion. neh=nis (contr. nh=nis Anacr.14.3, CIG7629 (vase), Kretschmer Griech.Vaseninschr.p.144, EM448.29), i^dos, h(, acc. -ida A.Pr.704, -in E.Cyc.179:—
girl, maiden, Il.18.418, Pi.P.9.31, A.l.c., Eu.958 (lyr.), S.Ant.784 (lyr.), E.l.c., al., A.R.1.843,
Lyr. Alex.Adesp.26; of a young married woman, E.Andr.192; parqenikh\ n. Od.7.20. as Adj.,
youthful, xei=res, h(=bai, E.Ba.745, Ion477 (lyr.).
new, bi/blos AP4.3b75 (Agath.).—Poet. word, but freq. in LXX, Ex.2.8, al.
nea_nisk-a/rion, to/, Dim. of neani/skos, Arr.Epict.2.16.29.

nea_nisk-arxe/w,
hold office of neaniska/rxhs, IG3.765,1098.

nea_nisk-a/rxhs, ou, o(,
official in charge of e)/fhboi, ib.1162.8, Delph.3(1).238, IPE2.440, al. (Tanais), Supp.Epigr.2.620 (Teos), BSA29.23 (Sparta, ii A.D.), Philol.11.293 (Smyrna).

nea_nisk-eu/mata, ta/, = Lat.
Juvenalia, D.C.61.19, 67.14.

nea_nisk-eu/omai, only pres.,
to be in one's youth, Eup.29, Posidipp.9; n. e)n toi=s e)fh/bois X.Cyr.1.2.15, Plu.2.12b.

nea_/nisk-os, Ion. nehn-, o(, (nea/n)
youth, young man, IG12.374.162, al., Hdt.4.72, 112, Pl.Smp.211d, Arist. Pol.1303b21, Anon.Hist.(FGrH160) p.887 J., etc.; n. to\ ei)=dos (nisi leg. neaniko/s) X.HG3.3.5; in Hdt.3.53 the same youth is called both nehni/hs and nehni/skos; but in Antipho 3.4.6 and 8 the same person is called n. and meira/kion, and the eldest son of Socrates is called neani/skos X.Mem.2.2.1, but meira/kion Pl.Ap.34d; e)/n te paisi\ kai\ n. kai\ e)n a)ndra/si Id.R.413e; pai=s ei)/kosi e)/tea, nehni/skos ei)/kosi, nehni/hs ei)/kosi, ge/rwn ei)/kosi Pythag. ap. D.L.8.10, cf. Hp.Hebd.5: more freq. than neani/as in later Gr., Wilcken Chr.30i4 (iii/ii B.C.), Plb.1.36.12, Ev.Matt.19.20, etc. o( e)mo\s n. my
young man, i.e.
servant, Luc. Alex.53; perh. also, PCair.Zen.18.6 (iii B.C.), Ev.Marc.14.51: pl., dub. sens., PCair.Zen.153 (iii B.C., written neni/skois).
nea_nisk-u/drion, to/, = neaniska/rion, Theognost.Can.126.
ne/ansis, v. ne/asis.
ne/ac (Ion. ne/hc Call.Fr.78), a_kos, o(, = neani/as, Nicopho 10, cf. Poll. 2.11.

nea^oido/s, o/n,
singing.youthfully, AP7.13 (Leon. or Mel.).

*nea/polis [a_], ews, h(,
new city, pr. n. of several cities, Neapolis: at first in two words, *ne/a po/lis, gen. *ne/hs po/lios Hdt.2.91, cf. Th. 7.50; later in one, *nea/polis, gen. *neapo/lews Str.2.5.40, dat. *neapo/lei Id.1.2.13: hence *neopoli/ths [i_], ou, o(, IG12.191.31, al., later *nea_poli/ths Tab.Heracl.1.187, Lyc.736, Plb.1.20.14, etc., cf. Pl. ap. Poll.9.26.

nea^ro-hxh/s, e/s,
sounding new, dia/lecis Philostr.VS2.8.2.

nea^ro/-pastos, on, =
praesalsus, prob. in Gloss.

nea^ro-poie/w,
make new, refresh, Plu.2.702c:—in Med.,
freshen up, th\n th=s u(/lhs su/stasin Herm. ap. Stob.1.49.44. Medic.,
freshen the edges of an ulcer by removing granulations, n. e(/lkos, koilw/mata, Antyll. ap. Orib.44.23.4, Ruf. ap.eund.8.24.48.
renew, repeat, Sor.2.41 (Pass.), Aët.15.2 (Act.).

nea^ro-preph/s, e/s,
possessing youthful charm, metaph., of style, Aristid.Rh.2p.551S.;
becoming or
natural in youth, Procl.in Alc.pp.23,47C.; to\ n. tw=n h)qw=n Id.in Cra.p.1 P., cf. Olymp.in Phlb. p.249S.

nea^ro/s, a/, o/n, poet. for ne/os (also in later Prose, v. infr.),
youthful, pai=des Il.2.289, cf. Pi.P.10.25, etc.; to\ h)=qos nearo/s, opp. ne/os th\n h(liki/an, Arist.EN1095a7; nearoi/
youths, A.Ag.359, 1504 (both anap.); n. h(/bh Ar.Fr.467; = nealh/s, n. strato/s Hdn.3.7.5; to\ n.
youthful spirit, X.Cyr.1.4.3; lo/gos n. kai\ qeatriko/s Plu.2.802e; sxhmatismoi\ polu\ to\ n. e)/xontes D.H.Comp.23. of things,
new, u(/mnoi Hes.Fr.265; neara\ e)ceurei=n Pi.N.8.20;
fresh, muelo/s A.Ag.76 (anap.); sw/mata X. Cyn.9.10; n. de/lear, opp. sapro/n, Arist.HA534b4; trofh/ Id.PA 675b29; n. turo/s, o)/strea, Dsc.2.71, Ath.1.7d; -w/teroi klw=nes Gal.12.283; kappa/rews o(/ti -wta/ths PCair.Zen.488 (iii B.C.). of events,
recent, cuntuxi/ai S.Ant.157 (anap.); of a letter, D.L.1.112. ai( nearai/ (sc. diata/ceis) title of the
novellae of Justinian; h( qei/a kai\ n. dia/tacis PGrenf.1.62.13 (vi A.D.). Adv. -rw=s
youthfully, rawly, Luc.Hist.Conscr.50: Comp., dieilegme/non -wte/rws
with more spirit, Isoc.12.229. [nea<*>- by synizesis, as one long syll., Pi.ll.cc.; cf. nhro/s.]

nea^rofo/ros, on,
newly-bearing, Gloss.
nea^r-w|do/s, o/n, = neaoido/s, IG7.1773 (Thesp.).

nea^/r-wsis, ews, h(,
rejuvenation, Poet.in PIand.78.13.
ne/as, Ion. acc. pl. from nau=s.

nea/s,
novella, Gloss.

ne-a/si^mos [a_], on,
to be ploughed up, of fallow land, Gloss.

ne/-a_sis, ews, h(, (nea/w)
breaking-up of fallow land, n. qerinh/ Thphr.CP3.20.7 (ne/ansis codd.).

neaspa/twtos [spa^], on, Boeot. for neoka/ttutos,
newly-soled, Stratt. 47.8.

nea/th [a^] (sc. xordh/), h(, Dor. nea/ta Philol.6:—
the lowest of the three strings which formed the framework of the musical scale (opp. me/sh, u(pa/th), but
the highest in pitch, Cratin.134, Pl.R.443d:— contr. nh/th Arist.Ph.224b34, Metaph.1018b28, 1057a23, Alex.Eph. ap.Theon.Sm.p.140 H., etc.: in pl., e)pi\ ta\s nh/tas . . a)nabai/nein, in declamation, Anty ll. ap. Orib.6.10.23. (Orig. fem. of ne/atos (A).)

ne/a^tos (A), Ep. nei/a^tos, h, on, poet. Sup.,
uttermost, lowest, Hom. (who uses the nei- form exc. in Il.11.712, 9.153, 295), always of Space,
the lowest part of . . , n. a)nqerew/n, kenew/n, w)=mos, Il.5.293,857, 15.341;
extreme, outermost, o)/rxos Od.7.127; a)stra/galos Il.14.466; n. pei/rata gai/hs 8.478; u(pai\ po/da n. *)/idhs the
lowest slope of Ida, 2.824; e)k n. puqme/nos ei)s korufh/n Sol.13.10; po/des n. the feet, Orac. ap.Hdt.7.140; nei/aton i)ni/on A.R.3.763, cf. 2.166: c. gen., n. a)/llwn Il.6.295; po/lis nea/th *pu/lou
on the border of Pylos, 11.712; pa=sai d' e)ggu\s a(lo\s ne/atai *pu/lou h)maqo/entos 9.153,295 (wrongly expld. ap.Sch. as 3pl. pres. ind. (like ke/atai) of nai/w,
to be situated):— rare in Prose, ta\s nea/tas pleura/s Hp.Int.27, and cf. nea/th; contr. nh=tos: e)/sxatos, Hsch.; Arc. nh/atos Schwyzer 664.10 (Orchom. Arc., iv B.C.). (The orig. form may be nh/atos; with nei/atos, ne/atos, cf. ei(/atai, e(/atai (v. h(=mai), ei(/ws, e(/ws, etc.; cf. nh/i+stos, nei/aira, neio/qen, neio/qi.）

ne/a^tos (B), h, on, poet. (post-Hom.) Sup. of ne/os,
latest, last, n. ge/nnhma S.Ant.627 (anap.); ta\n n. o(do\n stei/xousan, n. de\ fe/ggos leu/ssousan ib.807 (lyr.); ti/s a)/ra ne/atos . . lh/cei; i.e. w(/ste ne/atos gene/sqai, Id.Aj.1185 (lyr.): neut. ne/aton as Adv.,
for the last time, E.Tr.201 (lyr.).

nea_to/s, o(,
breaking-up of fallow land, X.Oec.7.20.
neau/chtos, on, gloss on nealdh/s, Sch.Opp.H.1.692.

nea/w, (neio/s)
plough up, of fallow land, h)\n nea=n bou/lhsqe . . tou\s a)grou/s Ar.Nu.1117: metaph., ta\n me/san new=n a)/rouran (in music) Pratin.Lyr.5: abs., Eup.13, Thphr.CP3.20.7: aor. 1 subj. nea/swsi ib.3.20.8:—Pass., newme/nh (sc. gh=)
land ploughed up, after lying fallow, Hes.Op.462.
nebla/rai (fort. nebla=rai）: perai/nein, Hsch.; nebla/retai Ar.Fr.241 (ap.Phot., -toi cod.).
ne/b<l>esta: <ta\> perita/lmata tw=n i(erw=n (Sicel), Hsch.

ne/brac, a^kos, o(,
cockerel, Hsch.

ne/br-eios, on,
of a fawn, o)ste/a, au)loi/, Call.Dian.244, APl.4.305 (Antip.).

nebr-h=, contr. for nebre/h (sc. dora/), h(, = nebri/s,
fawnskin, Orph.Fr.238.8; n. pardale/h Id.A.449.

nebr-i/as, ou, o(,
dappled like a fawn, galeo/s Arist.HA565a26, cf. Hsch.s.v. la/das.
nebr-i/dion [i^d], to/, Dim. of nebri/s, Artem.4.72.

nebri^do/-peplos, on,
clad in fawnskin, of Dionysus and the Bacchae, AP9.524.14.
nebri^do/-stolos, on, = foreg., Orph.H.52.10.

nebr-i/zw,
wear a fawnskin at the feast of Dionysus, or, as trans.,
robe in fawnskins (Phot. gives both explanations), D.18.259.

ne/br-inos, h, on,
of a fawn, dora/ S.Ichn.219.

nebr-i/s, h(, gen. i/dos [i^] E.Ba.136 (lyr.; late i=dos D.P.703, 946), nebri/da E.Ba.24, Thesp.1, nebri/si E. Ba.249, nebri/das ib.696:—
fawnskin, esp. as the dress of Dionysus and the Bacchae, Il.cc.

nebr-ismo/s, o(,
wearing of a nebri/s, Arignote ap. Harp.

nebr-i/ths [i_], ou, o(,
like a fawnskin, n. li/qos, a precious stone, Orph.L.748:—also nebr-i=tis, idos, h(, Plin.HN37.175.

nebro/gonos knh/mh, the bone
of a fawn's leg, i.e. a flute, Cleobulina 3 (dub.l.).

nebro/omai, Pass.,
to be changed into a fawn, Nonn.D.10.60.

nebro/s, o(,
young of the deer, fawn, Il.8.248, Od.4.336, etc.; pe/dila nebrw=n
fawnskin brogues, Hdt.7.75; a type of cowardice, Il.4.243, 21.29; prov., o( n. to\n le/onta (sc. ai(rei=), of anything strange, Luc. DMort.8.1:—also fem., Il.4.243, E.Ba.866 (lyr.), Trag.Adesp.419.

nebro-to/kos, on,
bringing forth fawns, Nic.Th.142.

nebro-fa^nh/s, e/s,
fawn-like, Nonn.D.5.363.

nebro-fo/nos, on,
preying on fawns, n. [a)eto/s], = pu/gargos, Arist.HA618b20.

nebro-xi/twn [i^], o(, h(, gen. wnos,
clad in a nebri/s, Simm.15.

nebrw/dhs, es,
fawn-like, of Dionysus, AP9.524.14.
nedi/as: ta\s ai)qui/as, Hsch. ne/es, ne/essi, v. nau=s.
nevo/statos, v. neo/statos.
ne/h (sc. h(me/ra), h(, v. ne/os.
ne/hai, v. ne/omai.

neh-genh/s, e/s, Ion. for nea_genh/s,
new-born, just born, Od.4.336.

neh-qa^lh/s, e/s, = neoqalh/s,
fresh-blown, young, E.Ion112 (lyr.).

ne-h/khs (on the accent v. Hdn.Gr.1.82), Dor. nea/khs Hsch. (-ki/s cod.), es: (a)kh/ A):—
newly whetted or
sharpened, Il.13.391.
ne-hkonh/s, e/s, (a)ko/nh) = foreg., S.Aj.820.
ne-hlai/h, h(, Ion. for neolai/a, Hsch. (ne/hlai cod.).

ne-hla/ths [a^], ou, o(, (nau=s)
rower, Id.

ne-h/la^tos, on, (ne/os, e)lau/nw III)
newly-forged, Id. (cf. e)lath/r III, e)/latron)
freshly rolled out: neh/lata, ta/,
new cakes, D.18.260 (expld. by Harp. fr. a)le/w A).

ne-hli^fh/s, e/s, (a)lei/fw)
fresh-plastered, oi)ki/ai Arist.Pr. 899b18.

ne/-hlu^s, u^dos, o(, h(, (h)/luqon)
newcomer, Il.10.434, Hdt.1.118, Pl.Lg.879d.

ne-h/melktos, h, on,
newly milked, Nic.Al.311.
nehni/hs, neh=nis, nehni/skos, Ion. for nea_n-: so ne/hc for ne/ac.

neh/-tomos, on,
cut or
castrated when young, AP6.234 (Eryc.).

neh/-fa^tos, on, poet. for neo/fatos,
newly revealed, o)/ssa h.Merc.443.
nei/, Boeot. for nh/, Ar.Ach.867,905; also Arc., IG5(2).343.42 (Orchom.).
nei=ai, v. ne/omai.

nei/aira^, acc. sg. -a^n Il.16.465, Hp.Mul.1.64, 2.137, Nat.Mul.5, 6, al. (codd. opt.), Call.Fr.106 codd., Nic.Al.270; dat. -h| Il. (v. infr.):—fem. Adj. (formed like ge/raira) with comp. sense,
lower, neiai/rh| d' e)n gastri/ in
the lower part of the belly, Il.5.539,616, cf. Hp. ll.cc.; nei/airan sa/rka Nic. l.c.:—also ne/aira, ne/airan gna/qon Simon. 244. Subst., h( nei/aira the
abdomen, ba/ros e)n neiai/rh| Hp.Coac. 579, cf. Call. l.c.; cf. neiro/s (A). (Cogn. with ne/atos (A): orig. perh. *nh/aira, whence ne/aira (lengthd. to nei/aira in text of Hom.), contr. *nh=|ra, whence nei=ra.）
neia/tios [a^], h, on, later form for nei/atos, ne/atos (A), Man.6.738.
nei/a^tos, v. ne/atos (A).
neik-ei/w, = neike/w (q.v.).

neik-esth/r, h=ros, o(,
wrangler: c. gen.,
one who wrangles with, e)sqlw=n n. Hes.Op. 716.

neik-e/w, fut. -e/sw Il.10.115: aor. e)nei/kesa, Ep. nei/kessa or nei/kesa, 3.38, 10.158: also pres. neikei/w 2.277, etc.; subj. neikei/h|si, neikei/h|, 1.579, Hes.Op.332; part. neikei/ousa Theoc.1.35: impf. nei/keion Od.22.26; iterat. neikei/eskon Il.4.241: (nei=kos):—
quarrel, wrangle with one, mh/ moi o)pi/ssw neikei/h| Od.17.189; e)/ridos pe/ri qumobo/roio neikeu=s' a)llh/lh|si
quarrel one
with another, Il.20.254; e)nei/keon ei(/neka poinh=s 18.498: c. acc. cogn., nei/kea . . neikei=n a)llh/loisin e)nanti/on 20.252; neike/skomen oi)/w, we two alone
strove with him, is prob. corrupt
in Od.11.512 (nika/skomen Aristarch.): abs. in part. neike/wn Hdt.9.55. trans.,
chide, rail at, upbraid, c. acc. pers., Il.1.521, al.; *)agame/mnona n. mu/qw| 2.224; ai)sxroi=s, o)neidei/ois, xolwtoi=sin e)pe/essin, 3.38, 21.480, Od.22.225, etc.; o(\s nei/kesse qea/s . . , th\n d' h)/|nhs' [Paris]
insulted the goddesses (Hera and Athena), but praised the other (Aphrodite), Il.24.29.—Ep. Verb, used twice by Hdt., 8.125, 9.55; not in Att.: in later Prose, LXXPr.10.12, al.
nei/k-h, h(, = nei=kos, n. a)mfi\ *molionida=n Epigr. ap. Paus.5.2.5: personified, = *)/eris, v.l. for *ni/khs in Timo 21; prob. in A.Ag.1378, E.Or.1679, Poet. ap. D.Chr. 32.82, cf. EM276.3.
neik-hth/r, o(, v.l. for neikesth/r, Hes.Op.716.
neiklhth/r: likmhth/r (Megar.), Hsch. nei=klon, to/, = li/knon, Id.; cf. ni/klon.

nei=kos, eos, to/,
quarrel, strife, feud, n . . . o)/rwren *(/ektoros a)mfi\ ne/kui Il. 24.107; n. pro/s tina Hdt.8.87; n. kresso/nwn a)poqe/sqai Pi.O.10(11).39, cf. N.6.51; to\ n. eu)= qe/sqai S.OT633; to\ n. e)gkalw=n imputing the blame of the
quarrel, ib.702; n. qe/sqai Call.Iamb.1.202.
strife of words, railing, abuse, nei=kos a)/riste Il.23.483; nei/kei o)neidi/zwn 7.95; e)s nei/kea a)pike/sqai Hdt.9.55.
strife at law, dispute before a judge, kri/nwn n. polla\ dikazome/nwn ai)zhw=n Od.12.440, cf. Il.18.497;
challenge to authority, Hdt.3.62. also in Hom. not seldom for
battle, fight, n. o(moi/ion Il.4.444, al.; n. pole/moio 13.271; n. o(moii/ou pole/moio Od.18.264; e)/ridos me/ga n. Il.17.384; n. fulo/pidos 20.140; po/lemos kai\ n. 12.361; e)/rides kai\ nei/kea 2.376; po/nos kai\ n. 12.348; nei/kea kai\ dh=rin Hes.Op.33; po/lemos kai\ n. Ar.V.867 (anap.), cf. X. Cyn.1.17; nei/kea neikei=n Il.20.251; of
hostilities between whole nations, nei=kos pro\s *karxhdoni/ous Hdt.7.158, cf. 225. in the philosophy of Emp., the
separative principle in the ko/smos, opp. *filo/ths, 17.8, al., cf. Pl.Sph.243a, Arist.Metaph.985a24, etc. (Mostly poet., found in Hdt. and OGI335.119 (Pergam., ii B.C.).) v. ni=kos.
*neilaieu/s, e/ws, o(, = sq., AP9.353 (Leon. Alex.).

*neilei=on, to/,
temple of *nei/lews or *neileu/s (*nhleu/s) (founder of Miletus), IG12.94.27 (written *nel-).

*neilo-broxe/w, in Pass.,
to be inundated by the Nile, POxy.1502v. 6 (iii A.D.).

*neilo/-broxos, on,
inundated by the Nile (i.e. not artificially irrigated), PRyl.208.30 (ii A.D.), etc.

*neilo-genh/s, e/s,
Nile-born, AP9.355 (Leon. Alex.), Epigr.Gr.982 (Philae).

*neilo-qerh/s, e/s,
burnt by the Nile, i. e. by the sun and air of Egypt, pareia/ A.Supp.71 (anap.; ei(loqerh/s Emperius).

*neilo-ka^la/mh [la^], h(,
bulrush, PMag.Lond.121.490, BGU633.20 (iii A.D.).

*neilo-me/trion, to/,
Nilometer, a rod graduated to show the rise and fall of the Nile, Str.17.1.48, Hld.9.22, POxy.43 VVI (iii A.D.):—Adj. *neilo-metriko/s, h/, o/n,
used in the graduation of the Nilometer, ph=xus ib.669.36 (iii A.D.).

*neilo/-ru^tos, on, (r(e/w)
watered by the Nile, probolh/ AP9.350 (Leon. Alex.).

*nei=los, o(,
Nile, Hes.Th.338, etc.
*neiloskopei=on, to/, = *neilome/trion, D.S.1.36.

*neil-wi/+s, i/+dos, h(,
situated on the Nile, purami/des AP9.710.

*neil-w=|os, a, on, = *neilai=os, Luc.Nav.15, PMasp.2 ii 21 (vi A.D.); ta\ *neilw=|a
festival on the inundation of the Nile, Hld.9.9.

*neil-w/ths, ou, o(,
in or
on the Nile, Ath.7.309a: fem., *neilw=tis xqw/n the land
of the Nile, A.Pr.814.
nei=men, nei=man, nei=mon, Ion. aor. of ne/mw.

nei-o/qen, Ion. Adv. (cf. ne/atos A)
from the bottom, a)nestena/xize n. e)k kradi/hs he heaved a sigh
from the bottom of his heart, Il.10.10; [e)la/thn] n. e)/llabe xersi/n A.R.1.1197: c. gen., Arat.234; n. e)ceme/sai Cerc.4.55; [bl?]u/se n. Epic.in Arch.Pap.7.10:—also neio/qe, n. d' e)cane/hken . . phgh/n Supp.Epigr.4.467.25 (Didyma, iii A.D.); in late Prose, n. dra=n
heartily, Luc.Peregr.7. Cf. neo/qen 11.

nei-o/qi^, Ion. Adv. (cf. ne/atos A)
at the bottom, da/ken de/ e( n. qumo/n it stung him
to his heart's
core, Hes.Th.567: c. gen., n. li/mnhs Il.21.317.
under, beneath, opp. u(yo/qi, A.R.2.355;
in stooping posture, Id.3.706: c. gen., n. gai/hs Id.1.63, cf. Arat.89. [i is rarely elided, as in Nic.Al.520.]
neio-ko/ros, o(, h(, Ion. for newko/ros, AP6.356 (Pancrat.).

neio-poie/w,
take a green crop off a field, by which it is freshened and prepared for corn, X.Oec.11.16.

neio/s, h(, also neo/s X. (v. infr.), SIG963.8 (Amorgos, iv B.C.),
fallow-land, neioi=o baqei/hs Il.10.353; n. tri/polos a thrice-ploughed
fallow, 18.541, Od.5.127, Hes.Th.971, cf. Call.Dian.175, etc.; mh\ karpi/zesqai th
 gh=n a)lla\ neio
 poiei=n
rejuvenate it, Thphr.CP4.8.1, cf. 4.8.3, HP8.7.2; neio
 a)/rouran Hes.Op.463; of a mare, e(/na e)niauto
 . . a)na/gkh dialei/pein kai\ poiei=n w(/sper neio/n Arist.HA577a2.
ploughing and sowing of land
to reinvigorate it, neio\s a)mei/nwn h( xeime/rios th=s e)arinh=s Thphr.HP8.6.3; h( a)ri/sth neio\s a)po\ tw=n kua/mwn prob. cj. ib.8.7.2; ei)s neio
 a)rou=n Gp.3.6.7, 3.11.8; tw=| spo/rw| neo
 dei= u(perga/zesqai X.Oec.16.10, cf. SIGl. c.:—also ne/a, h(, Thphr.CP3.20.7, IG 22.334.17; also paraska/yei th
 gh=n neia/n SIG963.46. (Cf. OSlav.
njiva 'field'.)
nei=os (A), h, on, Ion. for ne/os, A.R.1.125, Hsch.
nei=os (B), a, on, (nau=s) Att. for nh/i+os, IG22.1610.27, 1629.1000, 1003, al. (in neut. pl. as Subst.), Theognost.Can.121.

neiotomeu/s, e/ws, o(,
one who breaks up a fallow, AP6.41 (Agath.).
neio/faton: neo/kraton, Hsch. nei=ra, v. sq. 2 and nei/aira.

neiro/s (A), a/, o/n,
lowest, e)n xqono\s neiroi=s muxoi=s Lyc.896 (v.l. nhroi=s), cf. Hsch. s. vv. neiro/n, nhro/n. Subst. neirh/, h(, = nei/aira 11, Id.s.v. neirh\ koi/lh (s. v. l.), but acc. sg. nei=ran as Adj., nei=ran e)s pleura/n prob. cj. in E.Rh.794 (nei/airan, nei/eran codd.); dat. sg. nei/ra| prob. in A.Ag.1479 (lyr.; nei/rei codd.); cf. nei/aira.

neiro/s (B), a/, o/n,
strong, vehement, Hsch.
nei/ssomai or nei/somai, v. ni/ssomai.

nei/fw, fut. nei/yw Epic. ap. Plu.2.949b: aor. e)/neiya (kat-) Ar.Ach. 138:—Pass. (v. infr.), aor. e)nei/fqhn (kat-) D.H.12.8:—
snow, sts. person., o(/te w)/reto *zeu\s neife/men (Ep. inf.) Il.12.280; o(/tan nei/fh| o( qeo/s X.Cyn.8.1; e)/neifen o( *zeu/s Babr.45; imper. nei=fe (sc. *zeu=) AP 5.63 (Asclep.); o(po/tan sxola/zh|s, nei=yon Pherecr.20: metaph., xrusw=| nei/fwn
falling in a shower of gold, Pi.I.7(6).5. impers., nei/fei
it snows, Ar.Ach.1141, cf. V.773; neife/tw a)lfi/tois
let it snow with barley-meal, Nicopho 13. Med. = Act., nifa/dos neifome/nas when the snow
is falling, A.Th.213 (lyr.); also u(ri/xous neifome/nous su/kwn o(mou= te mu/rtwn Ar.Fr.569.5. Pass.,
to be snowed on, Hdt.4.31, Ar.Ach.1075, X.HG2.4.3, Plb.16.12.3; xio/ni pollh=| nei/fetai D.S.5.25: metaph., poliw=| gh/rai+ neifo/menos AP6.198 (Antip. Thess.); *panaqhnai/oisin e)lai/ouneifo/menon dw/rois Inscr.Cos58.10.
rain, Nonn.D.22.283:—Pass.,
to be rained on, tw=n u(pe\r *me/mfin mhde\ neifome/nwn para/pan Ph.2.99. trans., qeo\s n. trofa\s a)p' ou)ranou= Id.1.617:—Pass., to\ neifo/menon, i.e. manna, Id.2.114. [ni/fw, e)/niya, etc. (makra\ h( prw/th sullabh/ Phot.) freq. in codd., but the true early spelling is nei/fw, e)/neiya, etc., Inscr.Cosl.c., Hdn.Gr.2.430, 554, sts. in codd., as Nicophol. c.; nif- is correct in derivs., which have short i.] (I.-E.
sneig[uglide]h- and
sn[icaron]g[uglide]h-, cf. Lat.
nix, nivis, ninguit, Lith.
sni[etilde]ga 'it snows', Goth.
snaiws 'snow', etc.)

neka/s, a/dos, h(, (ne/kus)
heap of slain, e)n ai)nh=|sin neka/dessin Il.5.886, cf. Ps.-Luc.Philopatr.10. simply, = ta/cis, in pl.,
ranks, Call. Fr.231. in pl., the
dead, a)/nac neka/dwn *)ai+dwneu/s AP15.40.43 (Cometas), cf. EM600.9.

nekr-a/ggelos, on,
messenger of the dead, Luc.Peregr.41.

nekr-a^gwge/w,
conduct the dead, of Hermes, Id.Cont.2.

nekr-a^gwgo/s, o/n,
conducting the dead, Epigr.Gr.258 = Sammelb.5629 (Alexandria, iii B.C.).

nekr-a^ka^dh/meia, h(,
school of the dead, Luc.VH2.23.

nekr-epa/rths, ou, o(,
remover of corpses, Cat.Cod.Astr.8(3).110, 8(4).215, prob. l. ib.7.117.

nekr-hgo/s, o/n,
for conveyance of corpses, ploi=on PHamb.74.3 (ii A.D.).

nekr-i/a, h(,
cemetery, Mitteis Chr.31i20 (pl., ii B.C.), UPZ19.16 (ii B.C.), Sammelb.5216.5 (pl., i B.C.).

nekr-iko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for the dead, Luc.DDeor.24.1; nekrika/, ta/,
inheritances, legacies, Vett. Val. 37.15, al.
deathlike, xei/lh Luc.DMeretr.1.2. Adv. -kw=s Id.Peregr.33, Philops.32.
nekr-i^mai=os, a, on, = qnhsimai=os, of animals, Aq.De.14.8, Sch.Ar.Av.538, OGI629.158 (Palmyra, ii A.D.), Erot. and Hsch. s.v. kene/breia; also of a human being, to\ n. LXX 3 Ki.13.25.
nekro-a/rths, ou, o(, = nekrepa/rths, AJP34.448 (Egypt).

nekro-ba^rh/s, e/s,
laden with the dead, a)/katos APl.4.273 (Crin.).

nekro-basta/c, a/gos, o(, h( (on the accent v. Hdn.Gr.1.43, 2.740),
bearing the dead, EM270.30.

nekro-bo/ros, on,
corpse-devouring, Cyran.17.

nekro-de/gmwn, on, gen. onos,
receiving the dead, *(/aidhs A.Pr.153 (lyr.).

nekro-derkh/s, e/s,
looking like the dead, Man.4.555 (s.v.l.).

nekro-do/kos, on, = nekrode/gmwn,
receiving the dead, klinth/r AP7.634 (Antiphil.).

nekro-do/ths, ou, o(, =
uspinio (fort.
vespillo), Gloss.

nekro-doxei=on, to/,
burialplace, mausoleum, Luc.Cont.22.
nekro-do/xos, on, = nekrode/gmwn, Eust.1903.63.

nekro-qa/pths, ou, o(,
grave-digger, Antioch.Astr. in Cat.Cod.Astr.7.117, Sch.Ar.Nu.844, Gloss.

nekro-qh/kh, h(,
coffin or
urn, E.Fr.472.17 (anap.);
place for a coffin or
urn, prob. in Rev.Bibl.39.532 (pl., Palmyra, ii A.D.).

nekro-kau/sths, ou, o(,
one who burns corpses, Gloss.

nekro-komi/zw,
take care of the dead, Eust.1080.51.

nekro-kori/nqia, ta/,
vases dug out of the tombs of Corinth, Str.8.6.23.

nekro-ko/smos, on,
laying corpses out for burial, Plu.2.994e (fort. -ko/mois).

nekro-mantei/a, h(, gloss on nekuomantei/a,
necromancy, Hsch.
nekro-mantei=on, to/, = nekuomantei=on, Id. s.v. neku/wron.

nekro/-mantis, ews, o(, h(,
necromancer, Lyc.682.

nekro-nw/mhs, ou, o(,
corpsebearer, Man.4.192.

nekro-pe/rnas, ou, o(,
one who sells corpses, i. e. Achilles, Lyc.276.

nekro-poio/s, o/n,
killing, Sch.Ar.Pl.263, EM541.55.

nekro/-polis, ews, h(,
city of the dead, a name given to a suburb of Alexandria, Str.17.1.10 and 14.

nekro-pompo/s, o/n,
conducting the dead, of Charon, E.Alc.441 (lyr.); of Hermes, Luc.DDeor.24.1.

nekroru/kths, ou, o(,
body-snatcher, Phleg.Fr.36.1 J. (pl.).

nekro/s, o( (of a woman, Diph.129),
corpse, Hom., etc.: as Subst., in early writers always of mankind, nekrou\s sulh/sete teqnhw=tas Il. 6.71; n. e)/ruon katateqnhw=tas 18.540: freq. of those killed in battle, tou\s n. u(pospo/ndous a)nei/lonto Th.4.44, etc.: in sg., nekrw=| e)ou/sh| *meli/ssh| Hdt.5.92.h'; kei=tai n. peri\ nekrw=| S.Ant.1240, etc.; *patro/klw| n. o)/nti Pl.R.391b: the Art. is freq. omitted even of a particular corpse, esp. when a gen. is added, n. gunaiko/s, a)nqrw/pou, Hdt.2.89, 90, cf. A. Ag.659, Th.1018; later, of a fish, n. i)xqu/os M.Ant.6.13: neut. pl. nekra/, ta/, Plu.2.773d: metaph., nekra\ kai\ kapno/s M.Ant.12.33.
dying person, muxqismo\s nekrw=n E.Rh.789; n. a)spai/rontes Antipho 2.4.5; n. a)poqnh/|skontes Th.2.52. metaph., o( ui(o/s mou n. h)=n kai\ a)ne/zhse Ev.Luc.15.24; o)/noma e)/xeis o(/ti zh=|s kai\ n. ei)= Apoc.3.1; n. th=| a(marti/a| Ep.Rom.6.11. in pl.,
the dead, as dwellers in the nether world, kluta\ e)/qnea nekrw=n Od.10.526, cf. 11.34, etc.; e)n nekroi=s LXXPs.87(88).5; e)k nekrw=n e)gei=rai Ev.Jo.12.1; h( a)na/stasis h( e)k n. Ev.Luc.20.35: metaph., zwh\ e)k n. Ep.Rom.11.15. as Adj. nekro/s, a/, o/n,
dead, first in Pi., n. i(/ppos Fr.203; n. sw/mata Mitteis Chr.31 ii 22 (ii B.C.), Ach.Tat.3.5, cf. Nic.Dam.58 J., Plu.2.685b, X. Eph.5.1, POxy.51.8 (ii A.D.), BGU1024vii26 (iv/v A.D.) (but also ta\ tw=n n. sw/mata Pl.Lg.959b; sw=ma . . nekrou= E.Hec.679); n. xelw/nh Luc.DDeor.7.4: Comp. -o/teros AP11.135 (Lucill.).
inanimate, inorganic, opp. e)/myuxos, Plot.3.6.6; ou)xi\ n., w(/sper li/qon h)\ cu/lon,
a)lla\ zw<*>n Id.4.7.9; ou)rano\s . . w)\n pro\ yuxh=s sw=ma n., gh= kai\ u(/dwr Id.5.1.2; h( n. qa/lassa the Dead Sea, Paus.5.7.4, Gal.11.690, Orph.A. 1082. metaph., n. plou=tos Philostr.VS2.1.1.

nekro-stole/w,
ferry the dead, of Charon, Luc.Cont.24.

nekro-sto/los, on,
layer-out of corpses, Artem.4.56 (pl.).

nekro-su_li/a, h(,
robbery of the dead, Pl.R.469e.

nekro/-ta_gos, o(,
judge of the dead, of Minos, Lyc. 1399.

nekro-ta^fe/w,
bury the dead, Tz.H.4.154.
nekro-ta/fh [a^], h(, = nekrotafi/s, PGrenf.2.75.1 (iv A.D.).

nekro-ta^fiko/s, h/, o/n,
pertaining to burial, khdeia ib.68.6 (iii A.D.).
nekro-ta^fi/s, i/dos, h(, fem. of sq., ib.76.2 (iv A.D.).

nekro-ta/fos [a^], o(, = nekroqa/pths, PRyl.65.3 (i B.C.), Ostr.Bodl. iv 51 (i A.D.), PGrenf.2.73.7 (iii A.D.), AJP34.439 (Egypt),
Cat.Cod. Astr.7.117, Man.4.192.

nekro-fa^ge/w,
eat corpses or
carrion, Str.17.3.5.

nekro-fa/gos [a^], on,
eating corpses or
carrion, o)/rniqes D.C.47.40.

nekro-fore/w,
bear as a dead body to the burial: metaph., of soul bearing body, Ph.2.540, cf. 1.100.

nekro-fo/rion, to/,
sandapila, Gloss.

nekro-fo/ros, on,
burying corpses, burying the dead, Plu.Cat.Ma. 9, Gloss.

nekro-fu/lac [u^], a^kos, o(,
guardian of the dead, Ph.1.417, Vett.Val.68.14, Cat.Cod.Astr.8(4).139.
nekro/-xrws, xrwtos, o(, h(, gloss on e)nero/xrwtes, EM340.10.

nekro/-yu_xos, on,
spiritless, Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).139, Vett.Val.68.17.

nekr-o/w,
make dead, mortify, mo/rio/n ti Gal.11.265:—Pass., nenekrw=sqai to\ mo/rion Id.18(1).156: metaph., ta\ do/gmata . . du/natai nekrwqh=nai M.Ant.7.2; ou) yuxh\ kuri/ws, a)lla\ nenekrwme/nh tis Simp.in Ph. 1066.27;
to be dead, nekrwqei/s IG14.1976; nenekrwme/nos, of the body of Abraham, Ep.Rom.4.19. metaph.,
mortify, nekrw/sate ta\ me/lh Ep.Col.3.5.

nekr-w/dhs, es,
corpse-like, Luc.Ep.Sat.28, Aret. SA2.11; n. pro/swpon, 'facies Hippocratica', Gal.9.917: esp.
mortified, Id.18(1).156.

ne/kr-wma, atos, to/,
lifeless, inorganic body, a)/toma o(/sa nekrw/mata Simp.
in de An.318.9.

nekr-w/n, w=nos, o(,
burial-place, IG 5(2).176 (Tegea, ii B.C.), AP7.610 (Pall.).
