current coin, n. ko/yai or ko/yasqai, coin
money, Hdt.3.56, 4.166; ta)rxai=on n. Ar.Ra.720; n. su/mbolon th=s a)llagh=s e(/neka Pl.R.371b, cf. Arist.EN1133b11, Pol.1257a11, D.L.6.20; ta/lanta nomi/smatos And.3.8; n. h(medapou= IG12.91.4; to\ e)pixw/rion n. PCair.Zen.21.12 (iii B.C.): pl. nomi/smata
pieces of money, coins, Hdn.1.9.7.
full legal measure, tou= xow=s h)\ tw=n kotulw=n to\ n. dialumai/netai Ar.Th.348.
nom-isma/tion, to/, Dim. of no/misma, Poll.9.72,92, Sch.Ar.V.213; as name of a coin, Sammelb.6259 (v/ vi A.D.), al.

nomisma^to-pw/lhs, ou, o(,
money-changer, Poll.7.170.

nomisma^to-pwliko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for a money-changer's trade: h( -kh/ (sc. te/xnh) Pl.Sph. 223b.

nom-iste/os, a, on,
to be enacted (nomi/zw 1.2), Pl.R.608b. nomiste/on,
one must account, deem, Id.Sph.230d, Men.550, LXXEp.Je. 40, Porph.Abst.1.12, etc.

nom-isteu/omai, Pass.,
to be current, para/ tisi Plb.18.34.7, cf. S.E.M.1.178.

nom-isti/ or nom-ei/, Adv.
conventionally, opp. kat' a)lh/qeian, Diog.Oen.6, cf. Gal.1.417.

nom-isto/s, h/, o/n,
customary, Orac. ap. Phleg.Fr.36.10J.
conventional, n. pa/nta kai\ pro/s ti S.E.P.3.232.
nomi^teu/omai, = nomi/zw 1.3, me/trois oi(=s h( po/lis n. OGI579 (Cilicia); a)straga/lois n. Phld.Sto.339.14. Pass., = nomisteu/omai, OGI 339.44 (Sestos, ii B.C.), PFlor.1.6 (ii A.D.), etc.

nomo-ai/olos, on, (no/mos 11)
of varied melody, dub. in Telest. 2.

nomo-gra^fe/w,
draft written laws, D.S.16.70, SIG344.54 (Teos, Epist. Antigoni), 684.18 (Dyme, ii B.C.).

nomo-gra^fi/a, h(,
legislation, Call. Aet.Oxy.2080.93 (of Rhadamanthys), Str.6.1.8;
drafting of laws, SIG563.17 (Teos, iii B.C., pl.).
duties of a nomogra/fos 11, PTeb. 397.34 (ii A.D.).

nomo-gra^fiko/s, h/, o/n,
drawn up by a nomogra/fos 11, e)pistolh/ BGU1135.7 (i B.C.).

nomo-gra/fos [a^], o(,
one who drafts laws, Pl.Phdr.278e, IG4.679.23 (Hermione), 42(1).73.2 (Epid., iii B.C.), 5(1).7 (Sparta), (2).433 (Megalopolis).
notary, PHamb.4.15 (i A.D.), POxy.34 i 9 (ii A.D.), etc.; n. a)gora=s BGU 888.4 (ii A.D.).

nomo-dei/kths, ou, Dor. no/mo-tas, o(,
one who explains laws, legal adviser, IG5(1).1390.114 (Andania, i B.C.), BSA26.166 (Sparta), IGRom.4.468.19 (Pergam.), Plu.TG9.
nomo-di^da/kths, ou, o(, = sq., Id.Cat.Ma.20, Artem.2.29.

nomo-di^da/ska^los, o(,
teacher of the law, Ev.Luc.5.17, al.

nomo-di/fas [i_], ou, o(,
searcher into law,
Gloss.

nomo-do/ths, ou, o(,
lawgiver, Sm.Ps.75(76).12.

nomo-qesi/a, h(,
legislation, Pl.R.427b, Lg.684e: pl., Arist.Rh.1354b2, Wilcken Chr. 6.11 (v A.D.).
code of laws, Lys.30.35, Com.Adesp.110.2, LXX 2 Ma.6.23, Plu.2.240b. metaph., of the
order of nature, Vett. Val.344.1, Luc.Am.22. pl.,
arbitrary principles, Epicur.Ep.2p.36U.

nomo-qe/smws, Adv.
lawfully, LXXPr.31.27(26).

nomoqet-e/w, pf. nenomoqe/thka Alex.126.13:—
frame laws, Lys.15.9, Pl.R.534d, etc.; *lakedaimoni/ois X.Ap.15; tai=s monarxi/ais Isoc.2.8; peri/ tinos Id.11.40; peri/ tinwn Arist.Pol.1294a37; u(pe\r o(/lou tou= e)mpori/ou D.56.48:—Med.,
frame laws for oneself, Pl.R.398b, Tht.177e, etc.:—Pass., of a state,
to be furnished with laws, have a code of laws, Id.Lg.701d, 962e, cf.Ep.Hebr.7.11.
ordain by law, ti Pl.Lg.628d, R.417b; e)nanti/a tw=| o(/rkw| tou= dh/mou n. And.4.3: c. inf.,
enact, tw=n zw/|wn e)sti\n a(\ se/besqai e)nomoqe/thse Isoc.11.26, cf. POxy.1119.16 (iii A.D.): —in Med., Pl.Lg.736c:—Pass.,
to be ordained by law, Ep.Hebr.8.6; ta\ kalw=s nenomoqethme/na h(mi=n u(po\ tw=n basile/wn OGI329.13 (Aegina, ii B.C.), cf. Luc.Pr.Im.18: impers., peri\ tau=ta ou(/tw sfi nenomoqe/thtai
it has been so
ordained by law, Hdt.2.41; n. kalo\n [ei)=nai] to\ xari/zesqai Pl.Smp.182b; h)=n nenomoqethme/non Arist.Pol.1319a11.

nomoqe/t-hma, atos, to/,
law, ordinance, Pl.Plt.295e, R.427b, etc. in pl.,
conventions, Hp.de Arte2.

nomoqe/t-hs, ou, o(,
lawgiver, Antipho 5.15, Th.8.97, Pl. R.429c, Ep.Jac.4.12, etc. in pl., at Athens, a committee charged with the revision of the laws, Decr. ap. And.1.83, IG22.140.8, D.3.10, Lex ap.eund.24.21, etc.
nomoqe/t-hsis, ews, h(, f.l. for nouqe/thsis, Pl.Lg.701b.

nomoqet-hte/os, a, on,
to be settled by law, Id.R.459e. nomoqethte/on,
one must make laws, Id.Lg.747d; n. tw=| nomoqe/th| Arist. Pol.1283b37. trans.,
one must enact, ib.1336b20.

nomoqet-iko/s, h/, o/n,
relating to legislation, legislative, Pl.Lg.657a: h( -kh/ (sc. te/xnh)
legislation, Pl.Grg.464c, 520b, al. Adv. -kw=s Cod.Just.1.4.34.14, Just.Nov.4.3 Intr., Poll.4.26. of persons,
fitted for or
skilled in legislation, Arist.EN1180b24; a)/ndres Jul.Caes.320b.
nomo/qet-is, idos, h(, fem. of nomoqe/ths, coined as expl. of qesmoqe/tis, Corn.ND 28.
nomo-qh/kh, h(, poet. for nomoqesi/a, Timo 9.4.

nomo-i/+stwr, oros, o(, h(,
learned in the laws, Hsch.
nomo-ma^qh/s, e/s, = foreg., Id.s.v. nomoi/+stores, Gloss.

nomo-ma^xe/w,
fight with laws, coined on analogy of naumaxe/w, Lollianusap.Philostr.VS1.23.2.

nomo/nde, Adv., (nomo/s)
to pasture, Il.18.575, Od.9.438.

nomo-poie/w,
make laws, Hsch. s.v. nomoqetei=.

nomo-poio/s, o/n, (no/mos 11)
composing music, D.L.2.104.
nomo-rh/twr, oros, o(, = yhfismatopw/lhs, Sch.Ar.Av.1038.

nomo/s, o(, (ne/mw)
place of pasturage, Il.2.475, Od.9.217, etc.; n. u(/lhs a woodland
pasture, 10.159; n. *perida/i+os
pasture of Ida, Pi.Pae.4.51.
herbage, pasture, h.Merc.198: generally,
food, Hes.Op.526; e)pe/tonq' . . e)pi\ nomo/n Ar.Av.1287, cf. 239 (lyr.). metaph., e)pe/wn polu\s n. e)/nqa kai\ e)/nqa a wide
range for words (but expld. by Sch. as = ne/mhsis,
apportionment), Il.20.249; pa/nth| . . no/mos （nomoi\ Barnes) beblh/atai w)|dh=s h.Ap.20; but, e)pe/wn n.
expenditure of words, Hes. Op.403.
habitation, Pi.O.7.33, S.OC1061 (lyr.), etc.; nomo\n e)n qala/ssh| e)/xein to have their
dwelling-place, Hdt.5.92.a/; dendre/wn n. *dio/nusos au)ca/noi Pi.Fr.153.
district, sphere of command, province, Hdt.5.102, etc.;
satrapy, Id.1.192, 3.90; of the
regions of Scythia, Id.4.62,66; esp. of the
districts of Egypt, Id.2.4, al., D.S. 1.54, Str.17.1.22, etc.

no/mos, o(, (ne/mw)
that which is in habitual practice, use or
possession, not in Hom. (cf. J.Ap.2.15), though read by Zenod. in Od.1.3.
usage, custom, [*mou=sai] me/lpontai pa/ntwn te no/mous kai\ h)/qea kedna/ Hes.Th.66; n. a)rxai=os a)/ristos Id.Fr.221; e)/nqa n. (sc. e)sti/) c. inf., where it is
the custom . . , Alc.Supp.25.5; n. pa/ntwn basileu/s
custom is lord of all, Pi.Fr.169.1; n. despo/ths Hdt.7.104, Pl. Lg.715d; n. tu/rannos tw=n a)nqrw/pwn Id.Prt.337d; i)/hsis o)qoni/oisi kata\ to\n n. to\n a)rqritiko/n Hp.Art.18; w(s no/mos Id.Mochl.37: hence,
law, ordinance, to/nde . . n. die/tace *kroni/wn . . qhrsi\ . . e)sqe/men a)llh/lous Hes. Op.276; tre/fontai pa/ntes oi( a)nqrw/peioi n. u(po\ tou= qei/ou Heraclit. 114; a)/fqoggon ei)=nai to\n palamnai=on n. [e)sti/] A.Eu.448; n. ka/lliston e)ceuro/nta, peiqarxei=n patri/ S.Tr.1177; n. koino/s, = o)rqo\s lo/gos, Zeno Stoic.1.43: pl., e)/rgwn . . w(=n no/moi pro/keintai u(yi/podes S.OT865 (lyr.); neoxmoi=s n. *zeu\s kratu/nei A.Pr.150 (lyr.). in
VT, of the
law of God, e)n tw=| no/mw| *kuri/ou to\ qe/lhma au)tou= LXXPs.1.2, al., cf. Is.2.3; no/mon o(\n e)netei/lato u(mi=n *mwu+sh=s ib.De.33.4; so in
NT, o( n. *mwu+se/ws Ev.Luc.2.22, etc.; but also o( n. tou= *xristou= Ep.Gal.6.2; o( n. tou= *pneu/matos th=s zwh=s, opp. o( n. th=s a(marti/as kai\ tou= qana/tou, Ep.Rom.8.2; n. te/leios o( th=s e)leuqeri/as Ep.Jac.1.25. with Preps., kata\ no/mon according to
custom or
law, Hes.Th.417, Hdt.1.61, etc.; ka\n no/mon Pi.O.8.78; oi( kata\ n. o)/ntes qeoi/ the
established deities, Pl.Lg.904a; kata\ no/mous A.Supp.241; para\ no/mon contrary to . . , Id.Eu.171 (lyr.); para\ tou\s th=s fu/sews n. Pl.Ti.83e; e)n *panella/nwn no/mw| Pi.I.2.38; e)n *)adrastei/w| no/mw| by
the law of Adrastus, i.e. at the Nemean games, Id.N.10.28: esp. in dat. no/mw|
by custom, conventionally, opp. fu/sei, Hdt. 4.39, Philol.9, Arist.EN1094b16, etc.; n. gluku/, n. pikro/n, Democr.9; ei) mh/ tis le/goi n. o(ra=n kai\ ta\s legome/nas poio/thtas mh\ e)n toi=s u(pokeime/nois ei)=nai Plot.4.4.29; o(/son no/mou xa/rin just for
form's sake, Diph.43.14, Arist.Metaph.1076a27.
statute, ordinance made by authority, [*so/lwn] no/mous e)/qhken a)/llous, toi=s de\ *dra/kontos qesmoi=s e)pau/santo xrw/menoi plh\n tw=n fonikw=n Id.Ath.7.1 (but to\n *dra/kontos n. to\n peri\ tou= fo/nou IG12.115.5), etc.; no/mon tiqe/nai, ti/qesqai, v. ti/qhmi; basiliko\s n. OGI483.1 (Pergam., ii A.D.), Ep.Jac.2.8: freq. of
general laws, opp. yhfi/smata (special decrees), Pl.Tht.173d, etc.; o(/tan ta\ yhfi/smata ku/ria h)=| a)lla\ mh\ o( n. Arist.Pol.1292a7: generally,
law, a)/neu o)re/cews nou=s o( n. e)sti/n ib. 1287a32; a)/grafos n. Lex ap. And.1.85, etc.; opp. gegramme/nos, Arist.Rh.1373b6; n. i)/dios, opp. koino/s, ib.4; o( n. freq. as subject, oi( n. dido/asi timwri/as D.18.12; w(=n o( n. a)goreu/ei Inscr.Magn. 92b16 (ii B.C.); mh\ o( n. kri/nei to\n a)/nqrwpon e)a\n mh\ a)kou/sh| prw=ton; Ev.Jo.7.51. c. gen. rei, ou(=to/s toi pedi/wn pe/letai n. Hes.Op.388; *(ulli/dos sta/qmas e)n no/mois Pi.P.1.62; to\n farma/kwn di/dace malako/xeira n. Id.N.3.55; n. e)mbolh=s kai\ diorqw/sios Hp.Mochl.38; o( n. tou= kriou=, tou= a)ndro/s, tw=n e)ranistw=n, LXXLe.6.31 (7.1), Ep.Rom.7.2, SIG 1198.14 (Arcesine, iii B.C.); e)s xeirw=n no/mon a)pike/sqai to come
to blows, into action, Hdt.9.48; e)n xeirw=n no/mw| a)po/llusqai, peripesei=n, die
in action, Id.8.89, Plb.1.57.8; metalla/cai to\n bi/on e)n x. n. Id.3.63.5, cf. 3.116.9; *)asdrou/bas . . e)n x. n. kate/streye to\n bi/on Id.11.2.1; tou\s me\n e)n x. n. die/fqeire Id.1.82.2; tou\s e)n x. n. ta\s politei/as katalu/ontas by 'direct
action', Aeschin.1.5; but ktei=nai e)n tai=s polemikai=s e)co/dois e)n xeiro\s no/mw|
under martial law, Arist.Pol.1285a10; tw=| tou= pole/mou no/mw| kthsa/menos Aeschin.2.33. *no/mos personified, oi( qeoi\ sqe/nousi xw( kei/nwn kratw=n N. E.Hec.800, cf. Orph.Fr.105, 160.
melody, strain, oi)=da d' o)rni/xwn no/mws pa/ntwn Alcm.67; n. i(/ppios Pi.O. 1.101; *)apo/llwn a(gei=to pantoi/wn n. Id.N.5.25; n. polemikoi/ Th.5.69; e)phla/lacan *)arai\ to\n o)cu\n n. A.Th.952 (lyr.); krektoi\ n. S.Fr. 463, cf. AP9.584: metaph., tou\s *(/aidou n. S.Fr.861. esp. a type of early
melody created by Terpander for the lyre as an accompaniment to Epic texts, n. o)/rqios Hdt.1.24; n. *boiw/tios S.Fr.966; n. kiqarw|dikoi/ Ar.Ra.1282, cf. Pl.Lg.700d, Arist.Po.1447b26, Pr.918b13, etc.; also for the flute, n. au)lw|diko/s Plu.2.1132d; without sung text, n. au)lhtiko/s ib.1133d, cf. 138b, Poll.4.79; later,
composition including both words and melody, e.g. Tim.Pers. = nou=mmos (q. v.), Epich.136, Sophr.162, Inscr.Délos407.21 (ii B.C.); n. shste/rtioi, = Lat.
nummi sestertii, Inscr.Prien.41.13 (ii B.C.). Archit.,
course of masonry, IG12(2).11.17 (Mytil.).

nomofu^la^k-iko/s, h/, o/n,
observant of law, ge/nos Hierocl.in CA11p.440M.; n. e)pisth/mh ibid.

nomofu^la^/k-ion (nomofu^la^k-ei=on Suid.), to/,
office of the nomofu/lakes, Poll.8.102, Hsch.s.v. *xarw/nion.

nomofu^la^k-i/s, i/dos,
containing the law, kibwto/s Ph. 1.584. epith. of Aphrodite at Cyrene, Rendic.Linc.1925.420 (i B.C.).

nomofu/lac [u^], a^kos, o( （h( LXX 4 Ma.15.32),
guardian of the laws, title of officials appointed to watch over the laws and their observance, Pl.Lg.755a, 770c, etc.; oi( n. a)ristokratiko/n Arist.Pol.1323a8, cf. Cic.Legg.3.20.46; at Athens, Philoch.141b, etc.; at Sparta, Paus.3.11.2, IG5(1).31, al.; at Thasos, BCH52.55 (iv/iii B.C.); at Alexandria, PHal.1.42 (iii B.C.), prob. in Mitteis Chr.369 i 33 (iii B.C.); at Priene, SIG282.17 (iv B.C.); at Cyrene, Abh.Berl.Akad. 1925(5).7 (iii B.C.).
observer of the law, su\ h( n. LXX l.c. minor official under control of village elders, with police and fiscal duties, PAmh.2.108.8, BGU759.20, PRyl.122.7, POxy.1440.7 (all ii A.D.).

nom-w/dhs, es, (nomh/ 1.3b)
like a spreading ulcer, e(/lkos Alex.Aphr. Pr.1.92, cf. Gal.13.860; shpedw/n Id.10.702.
full of shreds as from such sores, diaxwrh/mata Id.14.754.

nom-w|do/s, o(,
one who chants or
proclaims the law, Str.12.2.9.

nom-w/nhs, ou, Boeot. nom-w/nas, o(,
official who leases public pasture, IG7.3171.43 (Orchom. Boeot.).

no/nnos, o(, = path/r (cf. ne/nnos), tou= no/nou (sic) a)delfoi\ o(mopa/trioi Cumont
Fouilles de Doura-Europos 310.

noo-ga/stwr, oros, o(, h(,
living by one's wits, Tz.H.10.774.

noo-eidh/s, e/s,
having the form of Intelligence, of intelligible character, Plot.5.1.3, 5.3.8, Procl.in Ti.1.247,407 D.
noo/-plagktos, on, = sq. 1, Nonn.D. 9.255.

noo-pla^nh/s, e/s,
wandering in mind, deranged, ib.4.197. Act.,
distracting the mind, ib.29.69.

noo/-plhktos, on,
palsying the mind, me/qh AP6.71 (Paul. Sil.).
noo-plh/c, h=gos, o(, h(, = foreg., a)tasqali/ai Tryph.275.

noo-poio/s, o/n,
creating Intelligence, du/namis Plot.6.8.18, cf. Procl.in Ti.1.311 D., in Prm.p.543 S., Dam.Pr.90.

no/os, no/ou, o(, Att. contr. nou=s, gen. nou=: Hom. uses the contr. form once, in nom., Od.10.240, cf. Hes.Fr.205 (Hdt. never): Trag. use contr. form, exc. in A.Ch.742 (iamb.), S.Ph.1209 (lyr.): Aeol. gen. nw= Alc.Supp.9.1; acc.nw=n Sapph.ib.25.2; no/on Ead.70 (s.v.l.): heterocl. forms are found in NT and later writers, gen. noo/s Ep.Rom.7.23, LXX 4 Ma.1.35; dat. noi/+ 1 Ep.Cor.1.10, [Aristid.] Or.35(9).26; nom. pl. no/es Ph.1.86, Plot.6.7.17, Dam.Pr.96; acc. pl. no/as Plu. Fr.7.27, Iamb.Myst.1.15, Ammon.in Int.243.3 (v.l.), Dam.Pr.103: Att. pl. noi=, acc. nou=s, gen. no/wn ib.122, dat. noi=s ibid., is rare in early writers, as Ar.Fr.471, but freq. in later philosophy:
mind, as employed in perceiving and thinking,
sense, wit, ou) lh=qe *dio\s pukino\n n. Il.15.461; n. polukerde/a Od.13.255; n. o(rh=| kai\ n. a)kou/ei, ta)/lla kwfa\ kai\ tufla/ Epich.249, cf. S.OT371; no/w|
prudently, Od.6.320; pare\k no/on
senselessly, Il.20.133; su\n no/w|
wisely, Hdt.8.86, 138; cu\n nw=| with play on cunw=|, Heraclit.114 (no/w| codd. Stob.); cu\n nw=| e(lome/nw| Pl. R.619b; ou)deni\ cu\n nw=| Id.Cri.48c; mhdeni\ cu\n nw=| Ar.Nu.580; tou= nou= xwri/s S.OT550; tou= n. keno/s Id.OC931; no/w| labei=n ti to apprehend it, Hdt.3.51; no/w| sxei=n, e)/xein,
recall, remember, Id.5.92.h/, Pl.R.490a; koino\s n. Phld.Rh.1.37 S., Arr.Epict.3.6.8; a)gaqo\s n., spoudai=os n., Phld.Rh.2.61, 1.252 S. nou=n e)/xein in two senses, to have
sense, be
sensible, S.Tr.553, El.1013, 1465, Ar.Ra.535, etc.; o( nou=s o(/d' au)to\s n. e)/xwn ou) tugxa/nei E.IA1139; so n. o)li/gon kekthme/nos
Ar.Ec.747; smikro\n nou= kekth=sqai Pl.Lg.887e; impers., to\ ga\r perissa\ pra/ssein ou)k e)/xei n. ou)de/na S.Ant.68, cf. Pl.Ti.68b; cf. nounexo/ntws. nou=n or to\n n. e)/xein to have
one's mind directed to something, a)/llos' o)/mma, qhte/ra| de\ n. e)/xein S.Tr.272, cf. Sapph.Supp.25.2; to\n n. pro\s au(to\n ou)k e)/xwn, e)kei=se de/ E.Ph.1418; deu=ro n. e)/xe Id.Or. 1181; oi)/koi to\n n. e)/xein Id.Ion 251; pou= to\n n. e)/xeis; Ar.Ec.156; to\n n. e)/xein pro/s tina or ti (like prose/xein to\n n.) Th.7.19, Pl.Grg.504d; pro/s tini Id.Prt.324a, etc.; peri/ tinos Id.R.534b; e)n pe/rdicin AP7.206 (Damoch.): conversely, e)pi\ nou=n e)lqei=n tini to
occur to one, D.H.3.15, Arr.An.7.24.3.
mind, more widely, as employed in feeling, deciding, etc.,
heart, xai=re no/w| Od.8.78; keu=qe no/w| Il.1.363; [xo/los] oi)da/nei no/on 9.554; e)ni\ sth/qessin a)ta/rbhtos n. e)sti/ 3.63; n. e)/mpedos, a)kh/lhtos, a)phnh/s, 11.813, Od.10.329, 18.381; n. eu)menh/s, a)/gnamptos, etc., Pi.P.8.18, A.Pr.164 (lyr.), etc.; pollw=n a)nqrw/pwn no/on e)/gnw Od.1.3; e)k panto\s no/ou with all his
heart and soul, Hdt.8.97; tw=| nw=| . . ka)po\ th=s glw/sshs in
heart as well as tongue, S.OC 936: freq. in phrase kata\ no/on according to one's
mind, Hdt.1.117, 7.104; ei) ta/d' e)/xei kata\ nou=n kei/nw| S.OC1768 (anap.); pra/ceias kata\ n. to\n e)mo/n Id.Fr.469 (anap.); kata\ n. pra/cas Ar.Eq.549; xwrei= kata\ n. Id.Pax940, cf. Pl.Euthphr.3e.
mind, resolve, purpose, a)gaqw=| no/w|, i.e. kindly, Hdt.1.60; ti/ soi e)n no/w| e)sti\ poie/ein; what do you
intend to do? ib.109; h(mi=n e)n n. e)ge/neto ei)pei=n Id.9.46; e)n n. e)/xein c. fut. inf.,
to intend . . , Id.1.10 (v.l.): c. pres. inf., ib. 27, Pl.R.344d; poie/ein ti e)pi\ no/on tini/ to put into his
mind to do . . , Hdt.1.27; e)pi\ no/on tre/pein tini/ . . Id.3.21; tau/th| <o(> n. e)/fere Id.9.120.
reason, intellect, no/ou freni/ Xenoph.25, cf. Parm.16.2, etc.; qei=os n. Democr.112, cf. Id. ap. Arist. de An.404a28; opp. do/ca, Pl.Ti.51d, cf. Arist. de An.428a5. Mind as the active principle of the Universe, Anaxag. 12, etc.; *qalh=s nou=n tou= ko/smou to\n qeo/n Placit.1.7.11; h( tou= ko/smou ge/nesis e)c a)na/gkhs kai\ nou= susta/sews Pl. Ti.48a, cf. Sph.249a, Phlb.30c, Arist.Metaph.1072b20, de An.430a17, Zeno Stoic.1.28, Plot.5.1.4.
act of mind, thought, h(mi=n d' ou)/ tis tou=de no/os kai\ mh=tis a)mei/nwn Il.15.509; ou) ga/r tis no/on a)/llos a)mei/nona tou=de noh/sei 9.104; ou) ga\r dh\ tou=ton me\n e)bou/leusas no/on au)th/ Od.5.23.
purpose, design, no/on telei=n tini Il.23.149; sa/fa oi)=sq' oi(=os n. *)atrei/+wnos 2.192.
sense, meaning of a word, etc., ou(=tos o( no/os tou= r(h/matos Hdt.7.162, cf. Ar.Ra.1439, Plb.5.83.4, Phld.Rh. 1.106 S., etc.; o( no/os th=s qusi/hs cj. for no/mos in Hdt.1.216;
meaning of a work of art, Philostr.VA4.28; polu\s n. e)n o)li/gh| le/cei sune/staltai Plu.2.510e; pro\s to\n au)to\n nou=n to the same
effect, Str.15.3.7; pro\s nou=n ou)de\n le/gontes to the
point, Phld.Mus.p.96K.; ou)de\ nou=n e)/xon
senseless, Id.Po.5.29. Pythag. name for mona/s, Theol.Ar.6. (Etym. dub.; the pr.n. *poluno/va IG9(1).870 hardly proves no/vos.）
noosfa^lh/s, e/s, （sfa/llw） = nooplanh/s 11, Nonn.D.17.277.

noo/ths, htos, h(,
intellectuality, th=s noo/thtos w(s a(plouste/ras ou)/shs tou= nou= kai\ oi(=on e(/cews tou= noei=n Procl.in Prm.p.863S., cf. Dam.Pr.58.

noo/w,
convert into pure Intelligence, in Pass., nou=s genome/nh [h( yuxh\] au)th\ qewrei= oi(=on nowqei=sa Plot.6.7.35, cf. 6.8.5; h)\ nou=s e)stin h)\ neno/wtai Procl.in Prm.p.491 S.; to\ de\ e)/nnoun yuxh/ e)sti nenowme/nh Dam.Pr. 100.
norba/: kalh/, Hsch. norbei=: e)ntamei=tai, Id. noreia/, v. no/rros.
norqakinoi/: a)sqenei=s, Id. no/rros: a)/nqos mh/linon lwtou=, Id.: also a tree growing by the sea (also called noreia/), Id. noru/ein: gh=n o)ru/ein (sic), Id.
noru/h, h(, a plant, = stru/xnon, tiqu/mallos, Thphr. ap. Phot., cf. Hdn. Gr.1.306.

nos-a/zw, (no/sos)
to be ill, Gal.15.302:—also in Med., opp. u(gia/zomai, Arist.Ph.229b3. causal,
produce sickness, ta\ nosa/zonta ai)/tia Gal.1.208, cf. 140.

nos-a^kero/s, a/, o/n,
liable to sickness, sickly, Arist.Pol.1279a15, PA670b7.—Vulgar word, acc. to Poll.3.105.

no/s-ansis, ews, h(, (as if from *nosai/nw)
falling sick, opp. u(gi/ansis, Arist.Ph.230a22, Plot.6.3.22 and 23; v.l. for no/swsis, Arist. Ph.229a26.

nos-ero/ths, htos, h(,
infirmitas, dub. in Gloss.

no/s-euma, atos, to/,
sickness, Hp.
Aër.7 (pl.).

nos-eu/omai, Pass.,
to be sickly, [e)/mbrua] nenoseume/na Id.Septim.2.

nos-e/w (no Ion. form nouse/w is found),
to be sick, ail, whether in body or mind, Hdt.1.105, etc.; th=s po/lews . . ou)/pw nenoshkui/as not yet
having suffered from the plague, Th. 2.31; nenoshko\s ai(=ma
diseased, Arist.HA521a18; no/sw| n. A.Pr.386: c. acc. cogn., nou=son nosei=n Hdt.3.33, cf. E.Andr.220; teleutai/an no/son n. Antipho 1.30; ti tw=n a)porrh/twn kakw=n E.Hipp.293: c. acc. partis, nosei=n kw=lon S.Ph.41; n. o)fqalmou/s Pl.Grg.496a; nefrou/s Arist. PA671b11, etc.; to\ nosou=n, = no/sos, S.Ph.675, Pl.Smp.186b: freq. in aor. nosh=sai,
fall sick, Hdt.1.19, Th.1.138, Arist.Rh.1392a11, Luc. Macr.22, etc.; of things, gh= nosei= X.Ath.2.6; of plants, Thphr.CP5.9.9:—Pass., h(me/rai ai( nosou/menai days
on which one is ill, Hp.Septim. 7. of passion, n. ma/tan
to be mad, S.Aj.635 (lyr.); qolerw=| xeimw=ni nosh/sas ib.207 (anap.); e)c a)lasto/rwn n. Id.Tr.1235; nosw=n alone, opp. sw/frwn, ib.435; n. ta\s fre/nas Cratin.329; n. peri\ do/can
to have a morbid craving for fame, Plu.2.546f; yuxh=s nosou/shs e)sti\ fa/rmakon lo/gos Men.Mon.550. generally,
suffer, nosei= ta\ tw=n qew=n E.Tr.27; toi=sin oi)kei/ois kakoi=s S.OC766; a)paidi/a| E.Ion620; ponhri/a| X.Mem.3.5.18; e)kei= nosou=men o(/ti . . E.Hel.581: c. acc. cogn., to/d' a)/lgos S.Ph.1326; esp. of states,
suffer from faction and the like , h( *mi/lhtos nosh/sasa sta/si Hdt.5.28; nosei= po/lis S.Ant.1015, cf. Pl. Mx.243e; nosou=si kai\ tetaragme/nois D.2.14; nosou=ntas e)n au(toi=s Id.9.50; a)po/lwle kai\ neno/shken h( *(ella/s ib.39; ai( de\ po/leis e)no/soun Id.18.45; ta\ pra/gmata nosou=nta Arist.Ath.6.4; nosw=n ga/mos Ael. NA8.20.

noshl-ei/a, h(,
care of the sick, nursing, J.AJ4.8.33, Plu.Lyc.10, Gal. 5.48, D.C.76.7.
sickness which needs tending, Lysimach. ap. J. Ap.1.34, Plu.2.110c (pl.), 788f, Sor.1.79 (pl.).
matter discharged from a sore, S.Ph.39.

noshl-eu/w,
tend a sick person, tina Isoc.19.25, Anaxil.19, Phylarch.61 J., Babr.13.8; oi( noshleu/ontes
physicians, IGRom.1.1228 (Egypt). Pass.,
need medical attendance, to be sick, J.BJ4.1.9, App.BC2.28, Gal.8.291, Asp.in EN26.17; n. trufhlw=s Jul.Or.6.181d.

nosh/l-ios, a, on,
of or
for sickness: nosh/lia (sc. siti/a), ta/,
food for sick persons, Opp.H.1.301.

noshl-o/s, h/, o/n,
morbid, u(gro/n Hp.Loc.Hom.10;
diseased, v.l. for noshro/s (q.v.). Adv. Comp. -o/teron
with a sickly tendency, Id.Epid.6.6.8, Aph.6.2 (v.l. noshr-).

no/s-hma, Ion. nou/s-, atos, to/, (nose/w)
disease, Hp.Flat.1, S.Ph. 755, E.El.656, Th.2.49,53, etc.; ta\ peri\ to\ sw=ma n. Isoc.8.39; nosh/masi peripi/ptein X.Cyr.6.2.27; nosh/mata tw=n sperma/twn Thphr.HP 8.10.1; [tw=n futw=n] ib.4.14.1. metaph., of
passion, vice, etc., e)/nesti ga/r pws tou=to th=| turanni/di n. A.Pr.227; n. ga\r ai)/sxiston ei)=nai/ fhmi sunqe/tous lo/gous ib.685; nosoi=m' a)/n, ei) n. tou\s e)xqrou\s stugei=n ib.978; of love, S.Fr.149.1; to\ n. th=s a)diki/as Pl.Grg.480b, cf. Chrysipp.Stoic.3.103. of any
grievous affliction, S.OT1293; esp. of
disorder in a state, turanni/da . . e)/sxaton po/lews n. Pl.R.544c, cf. D.19.259, etc.

nos-hma^tiko/s, h/, o/n,
morbid, diseased, Arist.GA725a11; n. ta\ peri\ th\n kefalh/n Id.Pr.881b8; ta\ n. Id.HA521a28; n. tw=| sw/mati Plu.2.245c. Adv. -kw=s Thphr.CP6.10.5.
nos-hma/tion, to/, Dim. of no/shma, Ar.Fr.90.
nos-hma^tw/dhs, es, = nosw/dhs, Arist.GA727b28, EN1149a6, Ptol.Tetr.188. Adv. noshmatwdw=s, e)/xein Arist.EN1148b33.
nos-h/mh, h(, = no/shma, Theognost.Can.112 (-i/mh cod.).

nos-hth/rios, a, on,
unhealthy, Hsch.s.v. khre/sion.

nos-hfo/ros, on,
disease-bringing, Marc.Sid.58.

nos-i/zw,
make sick, Arist.Pr.859a15.

*no/sios, o(,
Healer, title of Zeus, Schwyzer725.9 (Milet., vi/v B.C.).
noso-ba^rh/s, v. nouso-.

noso-gnwmoniko/s, h/, o/n,
skilled in judging of diseases by their symptoms: h( -kh/ (sc. te/xnh), the physician's art,
diagnostic, Pl. ap. D.L.3.85.

noso-ergo/s, o/n,
causing sickness, Poet.
de herb.39.

noso/-qu_mos, on,
sick at heart, Man.4.540.

noso-komei=on, to/,
infirmary, hospital, Cod.Just.1.2.15.1, Suid.: late word for cenw/n, acc. to Sch.Poll.1.79.

noso-kome/w,
tend the sick, D.S.14.71, D.L. 4.54, Iamb.VP30.184:—Pass.,
to be under medical treatment, D.S. 37.27.

noso-komi/a, h(,
care of the sick, Arr.Epict.3.22.70 (pl.), Iamb.Protr.21.kb' (pl.), Sch.S.Ph.39.

noso-ko/mos, o(,
sick-nurse, hospital superintendent, Poll.3.12, Cod.Just.1.3.41.13, Just.Nov.7.1.

noso-loge/w,
explain a disease, to\ ai)/tion ou(/tws -logei= Meno Iatr.11.40.
noso-lu/ths, v. nouso-.
noso-melh/s, v. nouso-.

noso-poie/w,
cause sickness, Hp.Acut.35, Arist.Pr.865b25, Alex.Aphr.in Top.4.27, f.l. in Plu.2.918d. n. [tina/]
infect one
with a disease, Ceb. 19; n. ta\s yuxa\s tw=n a)ri/stwn D.S.12.12:—Pass., Herophil. ap. Sor. 2.3.

noso-poio/s, o/n,
causing sickness, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath.3.80e; n. ai)/tia Gal.1.158. metaph.,
causing disturbances, D.H.8.90.

no/sos, Ep. and Ion. (not Dor., cf. Berl.Sitzb.1927.156 (Cyrene)) nou=sos, h(,
sickness, disease, plague, nou=son a)na\ strato\n w)=rse kakh/n (sc. Apollo), o)le/konto de\ laoi/ Il.1.10; nou=so/n g' ou)/ pws e)/sti *dio\s mega/lou a)le/asqai Od.9.411; dolixh\ n. 11.172; nou=soi a)rgale/ai Hes. Op.92:— Phrases: e)s n. pesei=n A.Pr.473; e)s n. e)mpi/ptein Antipho 1.20; no/son e)mpeptwke/nai toi=s kth/nesin X.Cyr.8.3.41; moi n. e)ph/luqen Od.11.200; no/sw| lhfqe/nti S.Tr.445; ka/mnein no/son, u(po\ no/sou, v. ka/mnw; a)sqenei=n tau/thn th\n no/son Isoc.19.24; e)k th=s nou/sou a)ne/sth Hdt.1.22; qh/lea n. ib.105, cf. Hdn.4.12.2; i(era\ no/sos, v. i(ero/s IV. 8: n. defined, Gal.7.43. generally,
distress, anguish, Hes.Th.527, S.OC544 (lyr.), etc.
disease of mind, esp. caused by madness, passion, vice, etc., n. frenw=n A.Pers.750 (troch.); qei/a n., i.e.
madness, S.Aj.185 (lyr.); mania/sin n. ib.59; lussw/dh n. ib.452; of love, Id.Tr.491; *)afrodi/tas n. E.Hipp.767 (lyr.); a)ko/laston e)/sxe glw=ssan, ai)sxi/sthn n. Id.Or.10; th=s megi/sths n., a)noi/as Pl.Lg.691d; n. kai\ sta/sin ou) tau)to\n neno/mikas; Id.Sph.228a.
plague, bane, mischief, e.g. a whirlwind is qei/a n. S.Ant.421, cf. 1141 (lyr.); of the trident of Poseidon, A.Pr.924 (s.v.l.); pentesu/riggos n., of the pillory, Polyeuct. ap. Arist. Rh.1411a23; ktei/nein tina\ w(s no/son po/lews Pl.Prt.322d.

noso-trofi/a, h(,
nursing of disease, Pl.R.407b; h( tou= sw/matos n. ib.496c, cf. Ael.VH4.15.

noso-tu_fe/w, (tu=fos)
to be ostentatious in sickness, Jul.Or.6.181d.
nossa/kion, to/, Dim. of sq., PMag.Leid.V.1.35,36.

no/ssac, akos, o(, (nosso/s)
chick, cockerel, Dsc.2.49.
nosseu/w, nossia/, nossi/on, nossi/s, nossopoie/w, nosso/s, nossotrofe/w, v. neoss-.

nost-e/w,
go or
come home, return, n. e)s patri/da gai=an Od.1.290, Epic. ap. Plu.2.297b; n. oi)/kade, oi)=ko/nde, o(/nde do/monde, Il.4.103, 5.687, Od.1.83: c. acc., n. *)/argos, oi)=kon, S.OC1386, E.IT534: pleon., o)pi/sw n. Hdt.3.26; n. pa/lin Ar.Av.1270: c. dat. modi, n. keinh=|si xersi/ Hdt.1.73:—Med., nosth/sato pa/trhn Q.S.1.269. abs.,
return safe, Il.10.247;
return, h)\ eu)= h)=e kakw=s nosth/somen 2.253; ka/llion a)\n . . e)no/sths' a)ntipa/lwn Pi.N.11.26, etc.
go or
come, kei=se Od.4.619; deu=ro E.Hel.474; gh=n th/nde ib.891; ei)s e)kklhsi/an Ar.Ach.
29. c. acc. cogn., u(po\ gh=s nosth/santi porei/an Pl.Ep.335c. (cf. no/stos II, no/stimos II) e)no/sthse to\ u(/dwr the water
became drinkable, Paus.7.2.11.

nost-i/zw, Elean inf. nosti/tthn,
propose recall from exile, Schwyzer 424.7 (iv B.C.).

no/st-i^mos, on, （no/stos）
belonging to a return (not in Il.), n. h)=mar the day
of return, i. e.
the return itself, Od.1.9, 168, 3.233, etc. ; n. fa/os A.Pers. 261 ; n. swthri/a ib.797 ; n. h)=tor AP 5.231 (Paul. Sil.).
able or
likely to return, e)pei/ r(' e)/tin. e)sti Od.4.806 ; a)po/lwle kai\ ou)ke/ti n. e)sti 19.85, cf. A.Ag.618 ; n. kinei=n po/da, v. pou/s. (no/stos II) of plants and fruit,
yielding a high return, productive, Thphr.CP4.13.2 (Comp. and Sup.) ; fe/re d' a)gro/qi no/stima pa/nta all things
in abundance, Call.Cer.136 ; to\n. tw=n karpw=n S.E.M. 7.17.
succulent, nutritious, trofh/ Sor.1.54 (Comp.) ; of fish, Aët. 9.30 (Sup.) ; to\ liparo\n kai\ n. Plu.2.684d ; to\ -w/taton o( kapno\s paralabw\n e)s to\n ou)rano\n oi)/xetai Luc.Luct. 19.
wholesome, u(/dwr J.BJ 4.8.3 (Comp.) ; ge/noito au)tw=| . . ta\ n. a)/nosta BCH51.148 (Tab. Defix., Cyprus) ;
palatable, Phld.D.3.13, Hsch. s.v. e(/smion :—in this sense expld. dia\ to\ h(du\ tou= *(omhrikou= no/stou Eust. 1383.40. to\ n., of resin obtained from galbanum, starch from wheat, the
valuable part, Dsc.3.83, 2.101 ; so to\ i)luw=des kai\ n. Id.5.75. metaph., to\ n. [tou= legome/nou] the
substance, kernel, M.Ant.2.15. in literary criticism,
succulent, ei)/ ti n. th=s poih/sews, th=s i(stori/as, Eust.ad D.P. Prooem.pp.70,71 : generally, o(/per h)=n -w/taton e)n soi\ a)panqisa/menos Luc.Merc.Cond.39.

no/st-os, o(, （ne/omai）
return home, Hom., esp. in Od., no/stoio te/los glukeroi=o 22.323 ; n. melihde/a 11.100, al. : freq. c. gen. pers., *)axaiw=n n. 1.326, al. : c. gen. objecti, w)/lese . . no/ston *)axaii/dos lost his
chance of returning to Greece, 23.68 ; gh=s patrw/|as n. E.IT1066 ; e)p' eu)re/a nw=ta qala/sshs Od.3.142 ; n. e)s do/mous S.OC 1409 : in pl., no/stoi e)k pole/mwn A. Pers.861 (lyr.); w)/moi e)mw=n n. S.Aj. 900 (lyr.); oi)ktra\ no/stois au)da/ Id.El.193 (lyr.) : generally,
return, nh=as e)/pi Il. 10.509. generally,
travel, journey, e)pimai/eo no/stou gai/hs *faih/kwn
to the land of the P., Od.5.344 ; e)pi\forbh=s n.
journey after (i. e. in search of) food, S.Ph.43 ; n. pro\s *)/ilion, *)ili/ou pu/rgous e)/pi, E. IA966, 1261. as pr. n. *no/stoi,
the homeward journeys of the Greek heroes after the taking of Troy, title of Cyclic Epic, Paus. 10.28.7, etc. ; of a work by Anticlides, Ath.11.466c.
yield or
produce of grain when ground, Trypho ap.Ath.14.618d ; = geu=sis, Gloss., cf. Hsch.
no/sfi^, before a vowel or metri gr.

no/st-fi^n, though i may also be elided, as Il.20.7. Adv. of Place,
aloof, apart, aside (cf. a)pono/sfi), no/sfin a)eira/sas after carrying the corpse
aside, Il.24.583 ; n. i)dw/n having looked
aside, Od.17.304 ; no/sfin a)po/ . .
aloof from, Il.5.322, 15.244, Hes.Th.57 ; n. a)/ter . . Id.Sc. 15 ; n. h)/ . .
besides, except, Theoc. 25.197 ; n. me/n . . n. de/
separately, Coluth.105.
aside, secretly, n. a)kou/wn Il.17.408. as Prep., c. gen.,
aloof or
away from, far from, n. pole/moio, fi/lwn, 6.443, 14.256 ; n. po/lhos Od.16.383, etc. ; n. no/swn peni/as te B.1.60.
without, apart from, unaided by, mostly of persons, n. despoi/nhs Od.14.9 ; n. *)axaiw=n Il.5.803 ; ou)/te kako\s n. dai/monos ou)/t' a)gaqo/s Thgn.166 ; n. h(ghtw=n A.Supp.239 ; of things, n. a)/ter te kakw=n kai\ a)/ter . . po/noio Hes.Op.91 ; n. a)/ter te po/nwn kai\ o)i+zu/os ib.113 ; ou)/t' ei)pei=n e)sti/ ti n. po/qwn AP12.18 (Alph.). of mind or disposition, toi/ ken *)axaiw=n n. bouleu/ws'
apart from, i.e.
differently from, the (rest of the) Achaeans, Il.2.347 ; n. *dh/mhtros
without her
knowledge and consent, h.Cer.4 ; n. e)mei=o ib.72.
beside, except, n. *poseida/wnos Od.1.20 ; no/sf' *)wkeanoi=o Il.20.7 ; n. *no/tou Hes.Th. 870.—Ep. and Lyr. word, once in A., l.c., never in S. or E.

nosf-i/dios, a, on,
clandestine, Hes.Fr.187.

nosf-i^do/n, Adv.
by stealth, Eust.894.50.

nosf-i/zw, Att. fut. nosfi^w= S.Ph.1427, E.Alc.43 : aor. I e)no/sfisa Pi.N.6.62, etc. :—Med., fut. nosfi/somai IG12(7).515.93 (Amorgos, ii B.C.) ; Ep. nosfi/ssomai A.R.4.1108 : aor. e)nosfisa/mhn, Ep. nosfisa/mhn, nosfissa/mhn (v. infr.) : pf. neno/sfismai PCair.Zen.484.4 (iii B.C.), Str.2.3.4, Plu.Luc.37 :—Pass., aor. e)nosfi/sqhn Od.11.73, etc. : Hom. only Med. and Pass.,
turn away, shrink back, nosfisqei/s ibid., Thgn.94 ; nosfi/sat' Od.11.425 : metaph., yeu=do/s ken fai=men kai\ nosfizoi/meqa ma=llon Il.2.81, 24.222. c. gen.,
turn away from, ti/fq' ou(/tw patro\s nosfi/zeai; Od.23.98. c. acc.,
forsake, abandon, pai=da/ t' e)mh\n nosfissame/nhn qa/lamo/n te po/sin te 4.263 ; elsewh. in Hom. of places, *krh/ths o)/rea nifo/enta nosfisa/mhn ib.19.339 ; nosfissame/nh to/de dw=ma ib.579, 21.77,104 ; nosfisqei=sa qew=n a)gorh/n h.Cer.92 ; o(/rkon e)nosfi/sqhs Archil.96 ; ei)/ se nosfi/zomai if I
forsake thee, S.OT693 (lyr.). after Hom. (a)ponosfi/sseien first in h.Cer.158) in Act.,
set apart, separate, remove, tina\ e)k do/mwn E.Hel.641 (lyr.) ; bre/fos mate/ros a)popro/ Id.IA1286 (lyr.) ; tina\ a)po/ tinos Lyc.1331 ; tina A.R.2.793 : metaph., n. tina\ bi/ou
separate him from life, i. e.
kill him, S.Ph.1427 ; tw=| nu/ m' . . e)k bio/toio nosfi/sat' (imper.) e)ssume/nws Q.S.13.282 ; n. tina/ alone, A.Ch.438 (lyr.), Eu.211 ; n. tina\ e)rwmani/hs AP5.292 (Paul. Sil.).
deprive, rob, tina/ ti one
of a thing, Pi.N.6.62 ; also n. tina/ tinos A.Ch.620 (lyr.), E.Alc.43 ; tou\s qano/ntas nosfi/sas w(=n xrh=n laxei=n Id.Supp.539 ; ge/ront' a)/paida nosfi/sas, i. e. w(/ste a)/paida ei)=nai, Id.Andr.1207 (lyr.). Med.,
put aside for oneself, appropriate, purloin, nosfi/sasqai o(po/sa a)\n boulw/meqa X.Cyr.4.2.42, cf. SIG993.21 (Calauria, iii B.C.), Plb.10.16.6, *(ellhnika/ 1.18 (Gytheum, i A.D.) : in pf. Pass., nenosfisme/nos polla/ Str.l.c., cf. Plu. l. c. : n. a)po\ tw=n a)mfita/pwn, a)po\ tou= a)naqe/matos, a)po\ th=s timh=s,
appropriate part of . . , PCair.Zen.l. c., LXX Jo.7.1, Act.Ap.5.2 ; e)k tou= xrh/matos Ath.6.234a : abs., PPetr.3p.162 (iii B.C.), Ep.Tit.2.10. Med. in act. sense,
deprive, rob, sf' a)delfo\s xrhma/twn nosfi/zetai E.Supp.153, cf. A.R.4.1108. in later poets,
remove, tou\s . . a)po\ *ca/nqoio . . pnoiai\ nosfi/ssanto D.P.684 ; nosfi/sat' e)k qumoi=o kai\ h(de/os e)k bio/toio Q.S.10.79.—Rare in Att. Prose.

nosf-ismo/s, o(,
absence, h)/lgei to\n n. th=s w)mo/thtos J.BJ5.10.4.
appropriating, stealing, Plb.32.5.8 ;
peculation, Ph.2.336, Plu.2.843f : pl., Vett.Val.40.29.

nosf-isth/s, ou=, o(,
peculator, xrhma/twn a)llotri/wn Id.48.26, cf. Cat.Cod.Astr.2.194 ; tw=n dhmosi/wn Sch.Luc. JTr.48, cf. Sch.Ar.V.832.

nos-w/dhs, es,
sickly, ailing, Hp.Aph.7.67 (Comp.) ; ta\ n., opp. ta\ u(gieina/, Pl.R.438e ; of persons, ib.406a ; n. sw=ma, bi/os, ib.556e, Lg. 734d ; to\ n.
sickly condition, Plu.2.662f. Act.,
unwholesome, pestilential, h)h/r Hp.
Aër.6 ; qe/ros Arist.Pr.859b22 ; xwri/on Isoc.19.22 ; to/poi Arist.Top.115b20 ; of plants, Thphr.HP7.9.4 ; to\ n. Pl. Cri.47d : metaph.,
baneful, nosw=des tou=to toi=s a)mei/nosin E.Supp.423 ; dra/kwn sti/lbei nosw/deis a)strapa/s Id.Or.480. Adv. -wdw=s Gal.9.393, 408 : correctly used only in Comp. acc. to Poll.3.105.
no/s-wsis, ews, h(, v. no/sansis.

nota^phli-w/ths, ou, o(,
south-east wind, Ptol.Tetr.60, Vett.Val.145.15, PMag.Par.1.1647.

nota^phli-wtiko/s, h/, o/n,
south-easterly, Str.Chr. 11.9, Ptol.Tetr.40, Vett.Val.8.24.

not-ero/s, a/, o/n, （no/tos）
damp, moist, dro/sos Simon. 183.9 ; ble/faron, u(/dwr, E.Alc.598, Ion149 (both lyr.) ; a)nemw/nh AP5.73 (Rufin.) ; xeimw\n n. a storm
of rain, Th.3.21 ; pneu=ma Porph.Antr.II (Comp.) ; to/pos Thphr.HP5.9.8, cf. Epicur. Ep.2p.50U. ; xwri/a Onos.8.2 ; to\ n.
moisture, Pl.Ti.60c.

not-e/w,
to be wet or
damp, drip, mu/roisi Call.Epigr.52 ; [zw=nai] u(/dati note/ousai Eratosth.16.10; note/wn i(drw/s, note/ousan e)lai/hn, Nic.Al.24, 494.

not-i/a, h(,
damp, moisture, noti/ai ei)arinai/ spring
showers, Il.8.307 : abs.,
wet weather, Arist. HA551a3, Thphr.HP7.14.1. n. fusikh/ natural
moisture of the body, Paul.Aeg.6.24. a
meteorite supposed to fall in wet weather, Plin.HN37.176.

not-iai=os, a, on,
southern, oi( n. tw=n a)nqrw/pwn Herm. ap. Stob.1.49.45 ; to\ n. Phlp.in Ph.894.19.
not-i^a/w, = note/w, Arist.Pr.928a14.

not-i/zw,
moisten, water, A. Fr.44, Ar.Th.857 :—Pass.,
to be wetted or
wet, Heraclit. 126, Pl.Ti. 74c, A.R.1.1005, AP7.26 (Antip. Sid.), Str.4.4.1 ;
perspire, Gal.18 (2).6, al. ; nenotisme/na oi)/nw| ei)/ria Hp.Fract.29 ; nenotisme/na xei=te da/krua
wet tears, AP12.92 (Mel.) ; nenot. gh= Arist.Mu.394b14. intr.,
to be wet, notizou/shs th=s gh=s Id.Mete.361b2 ; [o( no/tos] noti/zein poiei= to\ qe/ros Id.Pr.942a14. = ou)re/w, Heliod. ap. Orib.50.9.12.
perspire, Agathin. ap. eund.10.7.22.
no/t-inos, h, on, = sq. II, PRyl.157.5 (ii A.D.), POxy.729.9 (ii A.D.), etc. = sq. I, kata/stasis Aët.8.31.

no/t-ios, a, on, also os, on A.Pr.402 (lyr.), Str.2.1.22, etc. :—
moist, damp, rainy, n. i(drw/s
damp sweat, Il.11.811, 23.715 ; n. qe/ros Pi.Fr.107.13 ; e)/ar Hp.Aph.3.11, cf. Arist.Pr.860a36 ; pagai/ A. l.c. ; u(you= d' e)n noti/w| th/n g' o(/rmisan [nau=n] well out in
the water, opp. the beach, Od.4.785, 8.55 ; n. di=nai a(/lmas E.Hipp.150 (lyr.) : Comp., Str.4.4.1.
bringing rain, a)ste/res Arat.238, cf. 490 (both Comp.).
to the south, southern, n. qa/lassa Hdt.4.13, 6.31 ; esp. of the Indian Ocean, Id.3.17, cf. 2.11,158 ; to\ tei=xos to\ n., at Athens, And.3.7 ; n. a)h/ths a
south wind, A.R.4.1538 ; no/tia (with or without pneu/mata)
southerly winds, Arist.Mete.364a19, Pol.1290a14 ; noti/ois
during southerly winds, Id.HA574a1 ; no/tia pnei= Thphr. CP1.13.5 ; e)a\n h)=| no/tia Id.HP4.14.9 ; o( n. a)h/r Arist.Mete.377b27 ; ta\ n. u(/data
southerly rains, ib.358a28 ; n. [u(/dwr] water
from southern slopes, Id.HA596a28 ; n. *)ixqu=s, the constellation
Piscis Australis, Eudox. ap. Hipparch.2.1.21 (no/teios *)i. PLond.1.130.148 (i/ii A.D.)) : Comp. -w/teros Porph.Antr.21 : Sup. -w/tatos Str.13.1.68.

not-i/s, i/dos, h(,
moisture, A.Fr.481, E.Ph.646 (lyr.), Pl.Ti.60d, Thphr.CP 5.6.1, etc. ; ponti/a n. E.Hec.1259 ; of perspiration, Arist.Pr.866a21, Gal.10.541.

not-ismo/s, o(,
wetting, Dam.Isid.92.
moisture, Sor.1.118.

not-iw/dhs, es, = notw/dhs,
moist, Alex.Aphr.Pr.2.13 ; fantasi/a Gal.17(1).874.

not-o/qen, Adv.
from the south, Pl. ap. D.L. 3.41, Thphr.Sign.11,21 : c. gen., prob.l. in IG12.4.9.

notoli^bu^ko/s, h/, o/n,
south-westerly, Str.Chr.11.14, Ptol.Tetr.41.

noto/nde, Adv.
southward, Aq.Ge.12.9.

no/tos, o(,
south wind (opp. *bore/as, Arist.Mete.363b15, cf. Od.5.331), eu)=t' o)/reos korufh=|si *n. kate/xeuen o)mi/xlhn Il.3.10 ; o(/ te n. kai\ o( li/y, a)ne/mwn u(etiw/tatoi Hdt.2.25 (but o( n. ou)k a)rxo/menos a)lla\ lh/gwn u(e/tios Arist.Pr. 942a29) ; e)te/gxqh kra=t' . . plhgh=|si no/tou S.Ph.1457 (anap.) ; xeimeri/w| no/tw| Id.Ant.335 (lyr.) ; u(gro\s kai\ baru/s Arist.HA597b11 ; u(datwde/steros Id.Pr.943a5 ; o(/tan me\n e)la/ttwn h)=|, ai)/qrio/s e)stin, o(/tan de\ me/gas, nefw/dhs ib.942a34 ; kaumatw/dhs Id.Mete.364b23 : in pl., Id.HA612b6. N. personified as god of the South wind, Hes.Th.380, 870.
south or
south-west quarter, pro\s mesambri/hs te kai\ no/tou Hdt.2.8 ; pro\s no/ton kei=tai th=s *lh/mnou Id.6.139 ; th=s de\ gh=s to\ pro\s n. S.Fr.24.6 ; to\ pro\s n. th=s po/lews Th.3.6 ; ble/pein pro\s n. IG22.1227.18 ; o( toi=xos o( pro\s n. ib.12.372.51 ; pro\s no/tou a)ne/mou ib.56 ; basi/lissa no/tou Ev.Matt.12.42 ; a)po\ no/tou c. gen., to the
south of, PTeb. 164.17 (ii B.C.), etc. ; later e)k no/tou c. gen., PStrassb.29.8 (iii A.D.), etc. : gen. no/tou
to the south, PTeb.105.13 (ii B.C.), etc.

entryFree.sense: 'moist' (?) pulse, term invented by Archigenes, Gal.8.662.

div0.entryFree: notw/dhs, = es, notiw/dhs, Hp.Morb.Sacr.13.

nou-bustiko/s, h/, o/n, (nou=s, bu/w)
chock-full of sense, shrewd, pra=gma n. a
clever thing, Ar.Ec.441. Adv. -kw=s Id.V.1294, Cratin.Jun.7.5.
nou-qesi/a, Ion. -ih, h(, = nouqe/thsis, Ar.Ra.1009, Hp.Ep.17, AP 11.32 (Honest.), Plu.Lyc.25, Diog.Oen.33, Aret.CA1.2.
nouqet-ei/a, h(, = foreg., Phld.Hom.p.12 O., Lib.p.31 O., Pl.(?)ap. Poll.9.139 (perh. to be read in E.HF1256 (pl.)) :—also nouqet-i/a, h(, Phryn. PSp.35 B.

nouqet-e/w, (ti/qhmi)
put in mind : hence,
admonish, warn, re- buke, c. acc. pers., Hdt.2.173 ; parainei=n n. te to\n kakw=s pra/ssonta A. Pr.266 ; ou)de\ nouqetei=n e)/cesti/ se S.El.595 ; ka)=|ta nouqetei=s e)me/ Id.Ph.
1283 ; *)/erwta Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 8（
a) : c. acc. rei, n. ta/de S.El.1025, cf.Ar.V.732 (lyr.) ;
advise concerning, mhxanh/mata E.HF855 (troch.): c. dupl. acc., toiau=t' a)/nolbon a)/ndr' e)nouqe/tei S.Aj.1156 ; a(/per me nouqetei=s E.Supp.337, cf. Or.299 ; n. tina\ w(s . . X.Cyr.8.2.15 :—Pass., S. OC1193, E.Med.29, etc. ; pri\n u(po\ sou= tau=ta nouqethqh=nai Pl.Hp.Ma. 301c. metaph.,
chastise, n. tina\ kondu/lois, plhgai=s, Ar.V.254, Pl.Lg.879d :—Pass., coupled with kola/zesqai, Id.Grg.478e.

nouqe/t-hma, atos, to/,
admonition, warning, A.Pers.830 (pl.), E.Fr.962 (pl.), Pl. Grg.525c (pl.), etc.; ta)ma\ nouqeth/mata given [by you] to me, S.El. 343.

nouqe/t-hsis, ews, h(,
admonition, warning, Eup.66 ; didaxh\ kai\ n. Pl.R.399b, Epicur.Nat.72 G. ; r(a/bdou n. Pl.Lg.700c, etc.
nouqet-hsmo/s, o(, = foreg., Men.1042, censured by Poll.9.139 and Phot. (-ismo/s in both Gramm.).

nouqet-hte/os, a, on,
to be admonished, E.Ba.1256, Ion 436. nouqethte/on,
one must warn, Arist.Pol.1260b6.

nouqet-hth/s, ou=, o(,
monitor, Ph.2.519 : as Adj., n. lo/gos Id.1.171.

nouqet-htiko/s, h/, o/n,
monitory, didactic, lo/goi Pl.Lg.740e, Phld.Po.5Fr.1 ; to\ n. ei)=dos th=s paidei/as Pl.Sph.230a.
nouqet-i/a, v. nouqetei/a.
nouqet-iko/s, h/, o/n, = nouqethtiko/s, lo/goi X.Mem.1.2.21 ; to\ n. Demetr.Eloc.298.
nouqet-ismo/s, v. nouqethsmo/s.

nou=qos, o(,
tramp of feet, n. de\ podw=n u(po/doupos o)rw/rei Hes.Fr.48.

noumhn-i/a, h(, Att. contr. for neomhni/a (which occurs in Pi.N.4.35, Hdt.6.57 (pl.), PMag.Leid.W.1.28,9.43 (pl.), Gal.14.298):—also neumhni/a, SIG1106.19 (Cos, iv/iii B.C.) ; nemonhi/+a, GDI5015.28, al. (Crete) ; nomeni/a, PCair.Zen.167.5 (iii B.C.):—
new moon : the first of the month, Pi.l. c., Antipho Fr.58 (pl.), Ar.Eq.43, Ach.999 (pl.), etc. ; n. kata\ selh/nhn to denote the
true or
natural new moon, as opp. to the noumhni/a of the calendars, Th.2.28 ; also h( kata\ qeo\n n. PMag.Par.1.787, 2389 ; n. tou= e)/tous, of the spring equinox, Ptol.Tetr.91.

noumhn-iasth/s, ou=, o(,
one who celebrates the new moon, Lys.Fr.53.

noumh/n-ios, on, Att. contr. for neomh/nios,
used at the new moon, a)/rtoi Luc.Lex.6. as Subst., perh. a kind of
curlew : prov., cunh=lqen a)ttaga=s te kai\ n. 'birds of a feather flock together', D.L.9.114.

nou=mmos, o(, Western Dor. = no/mos,
current coin, esp. of the Tarentine stater, Arist.Fr.590. = li/tra, the silver equivalent of the bronze pound, ib.589. = Lat.
nummus (sc.
sestertius), Plu. Sull.1.

noune/x-eia, h(,
good sense, discretion, Plb.4.82.3, Andronic.Pass. p.578 M., Stoic.3.64.

nounex-h/s, e/s, (e)/xw)
with understanding, sensible, discreet, Ps.-E.Fr.1132.48, Plb.6.48.8 (Sup.) ; logismo/s Id.3.105.9, cf. Ptol.Tetr.164 ; to\ nounexe/s, = foreg., Anon. ap. Suid. s.v. a)nei=to. Adv. -xw=s Arist.Rh.Al.1436b33, Plb.1.83.3, al., Agatharch.63, Ev.Marc.12.34, Gal.10.267.

nounex-o/ntws, Adv. of nounexh/s, as if from Adj. noune/xwn (i.e. nou=n e)/xwn),
sensibly, Isoc.5.7(divisim), Men.1043 (Pl. has e)xo/ntws nou=n, Lg.686e).
nou=s, o(, v. no/os.

nousaxqh/s, e/s,
affected with disease, Opp.H.1.298.
nou/shma, Ion. for no/shma.

nouso-ba^rh/s, e/s,
caused by grievous disease, qa/natos Supp.Epigr. 2.479 (Olbia).

nouso-lu/ths [u^], ou, o(,
freeing from illness, *paia/n Epigr.Gr.1026.

nouso-melh/s, e/s,
with diseased limbs, Man.4.476.
nou=sos, h(, Ion. for no/sos.
nousofo/ros, on, Ion. for nosofo/ros, gh=ras AP6.27 (Theaet.).
noxele/s, v. nwxelh/s.

nu, v. nu=n 11. nu=, to/, indecl., the letter n, Achae.33.3, Pl. Cra.414c, IG2.4321.21 (iv B.C.), BCH29.483 (Delos), BGU153.16 (ii A.D.). (Cf. Hebr.
nūn.）

nu/g-dhn, Adv.
by pricking, A.D.Adv.198.9.

nu/g-ma or nu/xma (Nic. Th.271, al. codd. opt.), atos, to/,
prick, Nic.ll.cc., Aret.SD2.7, Tryph.365.
lesion of a neu=ron, opp. e(/lkos (of flesh) and ka/tagma (of bone), Gal.13.651,883, cf. Steph.in Hp.2.439 D. pl., nu/gmata
solicitations of the senses, Epicur.Fr.413.

nug-ma^tiko/s, h/, o/n,
suitable for nu/gmata 1.2, e)/mplastros Androm. ap. Gal.13.650.

nug-ma^tw/dhs, es,
punctuated, of heart-beats, Arist.Pr.947b31.
pricking, po/nos Archig. ap. Gal.8.92, cf. Aret.SA1.10. Adv. nug-dw=s Gal.19.7.

nug-mh/, h(, = sq., Plu.Ant.86.
dot, in punctuation, Dosith.p.380 K.

nug-mo/s, o(,
pricking sensation, irritation, Ruf. ap. Orib.8.24.62 : in pl., of gout, Luc.Ocyp.30. metaph., of the
prickings of conscience, tw=n paranomhma/twn n. ei)s th\n yuxh\n lamba/nein D.S.13.58 ; but also, = nu/gma II, u(po\ nugmw=n kai\ gargalismw=n th=s ai)sqh/sews Plu.Phil.9.
nu/g-w, = nu/ssw, Hsch.

nu^qo/s, h/, o/n,
dumb, Hsch.
dark, Id. :—also nu^qw/dhs, es, Id.
nuktai/etos, o(, = e)rw|dio/s, Hsch.

nuktairodu/teira [du^], h(,
she that rises and sets by night, of the moon, PMag.Par.1.2546.
nukta^lo/s, h/, o/n, f.l. in D.L.6.77 codd. Suid., for nustale/os (or -los).
nukta^l-wpa/w, = nusta/zw, Eust.1392.35.

nukta^l-wpi/asis, ews, h(,
night-blindness, Orib.Eup.4.18.3.

nukta^l-wpia/w,
suffer from night-blindness, Gal.12.802.

nukta^l-wpiko/s, h/, o/n, in neut. pl. -ika/, ta/,
attacks of night-blindness, Hp.Epid.6.7.1.

nukta^/l-wy, wpos, o(, h(, (nu/c, w)/y) = o( th=s nukto\s o(rw=n, i.e.
suffering from day-blindness, Id.Prorrh.2.33, cf. Gal.19.435, 14.776 ; e)n oi)ki/a| tuflw=n kai\ o( n. o)cuderkh/s Prov. ap. Jo. Sic.in Rh.6.293 W. ; but also, = o( th=s nukto\s a)lao/s,
night-blind, Gal.19.124, cf. Plin.HN8.203, Aët.7.48, etc. n.
ubi homo neque matutino tempore videt neque vespertino, Ulp. in Dig.20.1.10.4. as Subst.,
incapacity to see except in bright light, night-blindness, Hp.Epid.6.7.1, Arist.GA780a16 (pl.), Gal.10.84, Id. ap. Orib.Syn.8.48.1.
day-blindness, Dem.Ophth. ap. Simon.Jan. s.v.
nictilopa.

nukt-augh/s, e/s,
shining by night, Cat.Cod.Astr.1.173.

nukt-egersi/a, h(,
waking by night, Ph.1.155 (pl.) : with reference to Il.10,Str.9.5.18, Ps.-Plu.Vit.Hom.209,Arg. ii E.Rh. ; cf. nukthgresi/a.

nukt-egerte/w,
watch by night, Plu.Caes.40.

nukte/lios, on, (nu/c)
nightly, epith. of Dionysus, from his
nightly festivals, AP9.524.14, Plu.2.389a, Paus.1.40.6. nukte/lion, to/,
night-festival, *)/isidos POxy.525 (ii A.D.): in pl.,
festival of Dionysus *nukte/lios, Plu.2.291a.

nukte/parxos, o(, = Lat.
praefectus vigilum, Just.Nov.13.1 Intr.

nukterei/a, h(,
hunting by night, taking game asleep, Pl.Lg.824.
nukte/reia, ta/, = foreg., Eun.VSp.485 B.
nukterei/sios, on, (nu/c, e)rei/dw) Com. Adj. formed like nukterh/sios, sens. obsc., e)/rga Ar.Th.204.

nuktere/ths, ou, o(,
one who rows or
fishes by night, AP6.11 (Satyr.).

nukte/r-euma, atos, to/,
night-quarters, Plb.12.4.9.

nukter-euth/s, ou=, o(,
one who hunts or
fishes by night, Pl.Lg.824.

nukter-eutiko/s, h/, o/n,
fit for hunting by night, ku/nes X.Mem.3.11.8.

nukter-eu/w, (nu/kteros)
pass the night, Id.Cyr.4.2.22 ; n. a)qli/ws Timocl.16.1 ; of troops,
bivouac, X.An.4.4.11 ; e)n toi=s o(/plois n. ib.6.4.27 :—so in Med.,
pass a sleepless night, Timachid. ap. Ath.15.699e.

nukter-h/sios, on,
nightly, Luc.Alex. 53 (v.l. -eis-, -is-), S.E.M.10.188.

nukter-i^nei/a, h(,
office of commander of the night-watch, Supp.Epigr.4.515.9 (Ephesus, i A. D., written -h/a).

nukter-i^no/s, h/, o/n, (nu/c)
by night, nightly, fulakh/ Ar.V.2 ; cu/nodoi Id.Eq.477 ; a)ei/smata Eup.139 ; pureto/s Hp.Epid.1.5 ; strathgo/s ( = nuktostra/thgos) Str.17.1.12, CIG2930 (Tralles) ; fri/c POxy.924.4 (iv A.D.) ; a)naxw/rhsis Th.4.128 ; su/llogos Pl.Lg.909a, cf. Arist. HA592b8 ; fe/ggos Aen.Tact.10.25 ; n. su/sshma Id.4.5 ; n. gene/sqai to happen
by night, Ar.Ach.1162 ; -w/tato/n ti tolma=n
at dead of night, Luc.Icar.21. Astrol.,
potent by night, Ptol.Tetr.20. Subst., nukterino/s, o(, a kind of musical composition for the flute, used in Dionysiac worship, BCH50.235 (Thasos, iii B.C.).
nukte/r-ios, a, on, also os, on Luc.Peregr.28 :— = foreg., Orph.H.49.3 ; glau=c Arat. 999 ; e)/rgon AP9.403 (Maec.).
nukteri/rembos, v. nukti/rembos.

nukter-i/s, i/dos, h(,
bat, Od.12.433, 24.6, Hdt.2.76, etc. ; applied to a person, *xairefw=n h( n. Ar.Av.1564 (lyr.). a fish, = kalliw/numos, Opp.H.2.205. a plant, = mu/ron *(ele/nhs, Aët.12.1.
nukter-i=tis, idos, h(, = a)nagalli\s h( kuanh=, Ps.-Dsc.2.178.

nukter-o/bi^os, on,
feeding by night, zw=|a Arist.HA488a25.
nukter-oeidh/s, v.l. for nuktoeidh/s, S.E.M.10.184.

nu/kteros, on, = nukterino/s, mh/nh A.Pr.797 ; o)nei/rata Id.Pers.176 ; a)/strwn . . nukte/rwn o(mh/gurin Id.Ag.4 ; nauklhri/a S.Fr.143 ; dei=ma Id.El.410 ; n. a)pelwbh/qh
by night, Id.Aj.217 (anap.); fu/lakes E.Rh.87 : also in late Prose, n. koi/th Luc.Am.39 : neut. as Adv., nu/kteron a)ei/dousa Arat.1023.

nuktero-feggh/s, e/s,
shining by night, muh/nh Man.3.393.
nuktero/-foitos, on, = nukti/foitos, Orph.H.36.6.

nukterwpo/s, o/n, (w)/y)
appearing by night, do/khma nukterwpo\n o)nei/rwn E.HF112 (lyr.), cf. Plu.2.1066c.

nukt-hgore/w,
debate or
plan by night, E.Rh.89 :—in Pass., A.Th. 29.

nukt-hgori/a, h(,
nightly speech, debate by night, E.Rh.19 (anap.), Arist.Fr.159, Lib.Decl.26.23.

nukt-hgresi/a, h(, written -egresi/a, =
excubiae, Gloss. ; nyctegresia, Fest. s.v.
egretus.
nukt-hgrete/w, = nuktegerte/w, Them.Or.21.260b, Aristaenet.2.13, Sch.B Il.18.495.
nukt-h/greton, to/, Oriental plant, said to be luminous at night, Plin.HN21.62.

nukt-h=mar, Adv.
day and night, PLond.3.981.12 (iv A.D.).
nukt-h/meron, to/, = nuxqh/meron, Gloss.

nukt-hrefh/s, e/s,
covered by night, murky, gloomy, A.Ag.460 (lyr.).

nukti^-ba/ths [a^], ou, Dor. nukti^-ba/ta_s,
walking by night, Lyr.Alex. Adesp.19.7.
nukti^-bau=, indecl., = nuktiko/rac, PMag.Berol.1.223 ; but gen. -baou=tos PMag.Osl.1.264.
nukti^/-bi^os, on, = nuktero/bios, Hsch., Phot.
nukti^-bo/as, ou, o(, = stri/glos, Hsch. (nuktobo/a cod.).

nukti^-bo/h,
calling by night, epith. of the moon, PMag.Par.1.2808.

nukti^/-bromos, on,
sounding by night, su=rigc E.Rh.552 (lyr.).

nukti^/-ga^mos, on,
wedding by night, secretly, Musae.7.

nukti^-gene/twr, oros, o(,
father of night, of *)/erws, PMag.Par.1.1795.

nukti^-die/codos, on, of stars,
rising above the horizon after sunset and setting below it before sunrise (so that their whole course above the horizon is visible), Ptol. Phas.pp.9,10 H.: wrongly expld. by Gem. 14.12 of stars
setting before sunset and rising after sunrise.

nukti^-dro/mos, on,
running by night, Orph.H.9.2, cf. Hymn. in Sammelb.4127 (Talmis).

nukti^-kle/pths, ou, o(,
thief of the night, AP11.176 (Lucill.).

nukti^-ko/rac, a^kos, o(, = w)=tos,
long-eared owl, Arist.HA592b9, 597b23, 619b18, LXXPs.101 (102). 6, al., Str.17.2.4, Zopyr. ap. Orib.14.45.4, Gal.12.801, Ant. Lib.15.4 ; n. a)/|dei qanathfo/ron AP11.186 (Nicarch.).

nukti^-kru^fh/s, e/s,
hidden by night, Arist.Metaph.1040a31.

nukti^-laqraiofa/gos [fa^], on,
eating secretly by night, Epigr. ap. Hegesand. I.

nukti^-la/los [a^], on,
nightly-sounding, kiqa/rh AP7.29 (Antip. Sid.).
nukti^-lamph/s, e/s, (la/mpw) epith. of the ark of Danae, dou/rati nuktilampei= dub. l. in Simon.37.8.

nukti^-lo/xos, on,
lying in wait by night, Theognost.Can.84, Hsch.

nukti^-ma^nh/s, e/s,
raging by night, *)aparki/as Ath.Mitt.12.262 (Erythrae).

nukti^-me/dousa, h(,
ruling by night, of the moon,
Cat.Cod. Astr.1.173.

nukti^-no/mos, on,
feeding by night, Arist.HA616b25, Plu. 2.286b, etc.

nu/ktios, a, on, (nu/c)
of the night, qh/r AP6.221 (Leon.).

nukti^-pa^taipla/gios [pla^], on,
nightly-roaming-to-and-fro, Epigr. ap.Hegesand.I.

nukti^-ph/dhkes, oi(, (phda/w) a sort of
slippers, Herod. 7.59, Poll.7.94.

nukti^/-plagktos, on,
causing to wander by night,
rousing from bed, po/nos A.Ag.330 ; dei/mata Id.Ch.524 ; keleu/mata ib. 751 ; n. eu)nh/
restless, uneasy bed, Id.Ag.12.
nukti^-pla^nh/s, e/s, = sq., nuktiplanh= tele/qousan Opp.C.3.268 (vv. ll. nuktiplanh=tin t. (sic), nuktipla/nhton e)ou=san).

nukti^/-pla^nos, on,
roaming by night, Orac. ap. Luc.Alex.54.

nukti^-ploe/w,
navigate by night : hence, metaph.,
to be exact, Chrysipp. ap. Zen.5.32.

nukti^/-ploia, h(,
voyage by night, Str.16.2.24.
nukti^-po/leutos, on, = sq., Orph.H.79.7.

nukti^-po/los, on, (pole/w)
roaming, by night, *ba/kxai E.Ion718 (lyr.) ; e)/fodoi, of Persephone, ib.1049 (lyr.) ; epith. of Zagreus, Id.Fr.472.11 (anap.) ; of Artemis, Corn.ND 34 : as Subst., coupled with *ma/goi, *ba/kxoi, *lh=nai, Heraclit.14.

nukti^-po/ros, on,
prowling by night, lu/kaina Opp.C.1.441, cf. 3.268 : as pr. n. of a river, Luc.VH2.33.

nukti^/-rembos, on,
strolling, wandering about by night, Vett.Val.16.11 : wrongly spelt nukteri/rembos in Ptol.Tetr. 161.

nukti^/-semnos, on,
solemnized by night, dei=pna A.Eu.108.

nukti^-fa^h/s, e/s,
shining by night, fw=s Parm.14, cf. Orph.H.54.10.
nukti^-fa^nh/s, e/s, = foreg., *mh/nh Herm. ap. Stob.1.5.14, cf. PMag.Par.1.1794.

nukti^/-fantos, on,
appearing by night, o)nei/rata A.Pr.657 (cod. Med., cf. sq.) : generally,
nightly, nukti/fanton pro/polon *)enodi/as E.Hel.570.

nukti^/-foitos, on,
night-roaming, v.l. for foreg. in A.Pr.657 ; n. dei/mata Lyc. 225 (perh. to be read in A.) ; qeo/s, of Artemis, Ant.Lib.15.2.

nukti^-fo/ros, on,
bringing darkness, a)frosu/nh Ph.1.335.

nukti^-frou/rhtos, on,
watching by night, qra/sos A.Pr.861.

nukti^-xa^rh/s, e/s,
rejoicing in the night, PMag.Par.1.1795.

nukti^-xo/reutos, on,
belonging to nightly dances, Nonn.D.12.391.
nukto/-bas, gloss on glau=c, Hsch.

nukto-ba^ti/s, h(,
night-walking, in pl., Hp.Vict.3.68.
nukto/-bi^os, on, paraphr. of nukti/rembos, Procl.Par. Ptol.226.
nukto-bo/a, v. nuktibo/as.

nukto-gra^fi/a, h(,
writing by night, Plu.2.634a, 803c(pl.).

nukto-dro/ma (voc.),
running by night, epith. of a demon in Rev.Phil.1930.249 (Egypt, Tab. Defix.).

nukto-dromi/a, h(,
running by night, Hp.Vict.3.68 (v.l. kuno-).

nukto-dro/mos, on, =
noctivago, Gloss.

nukto-eidh/s, e/s,
like night, offog, Hp.
Aër.8 ; xro/nos e)sti\n h(meroeide\s kai\ n. fa/ntasma Epicur.Fr.294 (p.353 U.) ; sko/tos Iamb. Protr.21.kq'.

nukto-qh/ras, ou, o(,
one who hunts by night, X.Mem. 4.7.4.

nukto-la/lhma [la^], atos, to/,
spell for making a woman talk in her sleep, PMag.Lond.121.411.

nukto/-mantis, ews, o(, h(,
one who prophesies by night, Poll.7.188.

nukto-ma^xe/w,
fight by night, Plu.Cam. 36, App.BC5.35, etc. : metaph., n. th=| parqe/nw| e)rwtikw=s Aristaenet.1.10.

nukto-ma^xi/a, Ion. -ih, h(,
night-battle, Hdt.1.74, Th.7.44, Chor. p.30 B.

nukto-peripla/nhtos [a^], on,
roaming about by night, Ar.Ach. 264 (lyr.).
nukto-pla^nh/s, e/s, = nuktiplanh/s, Man.1.311.

nukto-ploe/w,
sail by night, Hipparch.1.7.1 (prob. for pukno-).

nukto-ploi+ko/s, h/, o/n,
given to sailing by night, Str.Chr.16.28.

nukto-pore/w,
go or
travel by night, X.Cyr.5.1.20, Str.15.2.6, etc.

nukto-pori/a, h(,
night-march, Plb. 5.7.3, D.S.18.40, Plu.Alex.22.

nukto-po/tion, to/,
night-cup, Sm.1 Ki. 26.11.

nukto-stra/thgos [a^], o(,
commander of the night-watch, POxy. 933.24 (ii A. D.), PLips.39.3 (iv A. D.).

nukt-ourgo/s, o/n,
working by night : to\ n. Plu.2.376e.

nukt-ou=ros, o(, = nuktofu/lac, name of the planet
Saturn, ib.941c.
nukto-fa^h/s, = nuktifah/s, dub. in Nonn.D.44.218.

nukto-fai/nousa, h(, =
Nocticula, i.e.
Noctiluca, Gloss.

nukto-fa/neia [fa^], h(,
shining by night, epith. of the moon, PMag.Par.1.2523.

nukto-fu^la^ke/w,
guard, watch by night, n. ta\ e)/cw X.Cyr.4.5.3 ; n. nuktofulaka/s Supp.Epigr.4.535.18 (Ephesus, ii/iii A. D.) :—impers. in Pass., Aen.Tact. 22.1. o(-kw=n, = Lat.
praefectus vigilum, D.C.52.33.
nukto-fu^la^kh/, h(, = sq., v. foreg.

nukto-fu^la^ki/a, h(,
night-watch, PCair.Zen.329.6(iii B. C.), Gloss.

nukto-fu/lac [fu^], a^kos, o(,
night-watchman, guard, X.An.7.2.18,7.3.34, Onos.10.10tit., Luc.Peregr.27 ; in Egyptian towns, Ph. 2.534, PIand.33.8 (ii A. D.), Theb.Ostr.139 ; at Rome, = Lat.
vigiles, J.BJ4.11.4, D.C.58.9 ; also, =
praefectus vigilum, Id.52.24.

nukto-fu^la/cia, ta/,
guard-house, IG11(2).145.30 (Delos, iv B. C.), al.
nukt-w/dhs, es, contr. for nuktoeidh/s, Eust.1951.57.

nukt-w=|on, to/, (*nu/c)
temple of Night, Luc.VH2.33.
nukt-wpo/s, o/n, (w)/y) = nukterwpo/s, laqosu/na E.IT1279 (lyr.).

nu/kt-wr, Adv., (nu/c)
by night, Hes.Op.177, Archil.46, S.Aj.47, Ar.Nu.173, Th.258, Antipho 5.26,44, Lys.1.14, 3.6, Pl.Grg.471b, PHal.1.194(iii B. C.), etc. :—the only Adv. of this form, Hdn.Gr.2.952.
nukxa/zw, = nu/ssw, Hsch.
nu/mfa^, poet. voc. for nu/mfh ; but nu/mfa_, Dor. for nu/mfh.

numfa_-genh/s, e/s,
nymph-born, Telest.1.5 ; of Pan, as
reared by Nymphs, Euph. 109.

numfa_-ge/ts, ou, o(,
leader of the Nymphs, epith. of Poseidon, Corn.ND 22; of Pan, IG42(1).130.15 (Epid.) ; cf. numfhge/ths.

numfa^gwg-e/w, pf. nenumfagw/ghka Plb.25.4.10 :—
lead the bride to the bridegroom's house, n. tini/ tina Plb.l.c. ; ta\s tw=n politw=n qugate/ras oi( tu/rannoi meta\ masti/gwn -ou=sin D.H.11.41 ; ga/mous n.
premote a marriage, Plu.Sol.20. of the bridegroom,
lead home a bride, Charito 2.1.

numfa^gwg-i/a, h(,
bridal procession, Plb.25.4.8, Plu.2.329e.

numfa^gwg-o/s, o/n,
leader of the bride, E.IA610 ; esp.
one who leads her from her home to the bridegroom's house, Luc.DDeor.20.16 ; esp. in case of a second marriage, Poll.3.41, Eust.652.45 : metaph., of the Argo, as bearing Medea, n. tro/pin Lyc.1025. generally,
friend, LXXGe.21.22,Jd.14.20.
one who negotiates a marriage for another, Plu.2.329f. Cf. numfeuth/s.

numf-ai/a, h(, = madwna/i+s,
yellow water-lily, Nuphar luteum, Thphr. HP9.13.1, Dsc.3.132.
white water-lily, Nymphaea alba, ibid. pr. n., a name of Ariadne, BMus.Cat.Vasesiii p.234.

numf-ai=os, a, on, (nu/mfh)
of or
sacred to the Nymphs, skopiai/ E.El.447(lyr.) ; na=ma AP14.71 ; drues Tryph.324 ; numfai/a liba/s
pure spring water, prob.l. in Antiph.52.13. numfai=on, to/,
sanctuary of the Nymphs, IG 11(2).144A91 (Delos, iv B. C.), CIG4616 (Syria, ii A. D.), Plu.Alex.7, etc. : Boeot. nunfh=on Schwyzer 485.6 (Thespiae, iii B. C.) ; esp.
fountain with architectural background, Philostr.VA8.12. n. pte/ris, = qhlupteri/s, Dsc.4.185 ; = druopteri/s, Ps.-Dsc.4.187. [numfai^on is doubtful in E.IT216 (lyr.) : fort. nu/mfan.]
numf-a/s, a/dos, h(, pecul. fem. of foreg., pu/lai Paus.1.44.3.

numf-a/smata, ta/,
bride's ornaments, Orac. ap. Phleg.Fr.36.10J.cod.

numf-ei=os, a, on, also os, on E.IA131 (lyr.), AP7.188 (Thall.) :—
bridal, nuptial, le/xh Simon. 124 B ; eu)na/ Pi.N.5.30, cf. E. l.c. ; pasta/s APl.c., cf. Supp.Epigr. 2.874 (Egypt) : hence as Subst. numfei=on (sc. dw=ma), Ep. numfh/i+on Call.Del.118 : to/ :—
bridechamber, S.Ant.891, 1205 : in pl., Id.Tr.920. numfei=a (sc. i(era/), Ep. numfh/i+a Mosch.2.159 : ta/ :—
nuptial rites, marriage, S.Tr.7 ; but numfei=a tou= sautou= te/knou thine own son's
bride, Id.Ant.568.

nu/mf-euma, atos, to/,
marriage, espousal, in pl., ta\ mhtro\s n. Id.OT980, cf. E.IT365, al. in sg.,
the person married, kalo\n n. tini/ 'a good
match for him', Id.Tr. 420.

nu/mf-eusis, ews, h(,
bridal, marriage, LXXCa.3.11.
numf-euth/r, h=ros, o(, = numfeuth/s II, Opp.C.1.265,3.356.

numf-euth/rios, a, on,
nuptial, ta\ n., = nu/mfeuma, E.Tr.252.

numf-euth/s, ou=, o(,
groomsman, = paranu/mfios, Poll.3.40. metaph., of a herdsman, Pl.Plt. 268a.
bridegroom, husband, E.Ion913 (lyr.).

numf-eu/tria, h(,
she who escorts the bride, bridesmaid, Ar.Ach.1056, Plu.Lyc.15. = promnh/stria, Lib.Decl.26.13.
bride, Phot.

numf-eu/w,
give in marriage to one,
betroth, Pi.N.3.56, E.Alc.317, IA461, 885 (troch.):— in Med., numfeuome/nh, epith. of Hera, Paus.9.2.7.
marry, of the woman, c. dat., S.Ant.654, 816 (lyr.) ; of the man, c. acc., E.Med. 625, Ion819, Isoc.10.59 ; n. le/xh Eub.67.1 : abs., of both parties, numfeu/et', eu)= pra/ssoite E.Med.313. Pass., with fut. Med. numfeu/somai Id.Tr.1139, Supp.455 (but aor. Med. in act. sense, e)numfeusa/mhn Id.Hipp.561 (lyr.)) : aor. Pass. e)numfeu/qhn Id.Med.1336, Ion 1371 :—
to be given in marriage, marry, of the woman, E. ll. cc. ; numfeu/esqai numfeu/mata Id.IT364 ; numfeu/esqai/ tini
to be wedded to a man, Id.Andr.403 ; para/ tini Id.Med.1336 ; n. e)/k tinos
to be wedded by him, Id.Ba.28 : metaph., yuxw=n ei)s ge/nesin numfeuome/nwn Porph. Antr.19. Med., of the man,
take to wife, numfeu/ou de/mas *)hle/ktras E.El.1340 (anap.).

nu/mf-h, h( (Ep. voc. nu/mfa^ Il.3.130, Od.4.743 (Aeol. acc. to Choerob. in Theod.1.304) ; later also as nom., AP14.43 ; but Dor. nu/mfa_),
young wife, bride, Il.18.492, Hdt. 4.172 ; n. a)/gesqai Ar.Pl.529 ; *)aeli/oio Pi.O.7.14 ; opp. numfi/os, Pl. Lg.783e ; opp. parqe/nos, Praxill.5, Com.Adesp.1215 ; always relatively young, as Iris calls Helen, or as Eurycleia calls Penelope, nu/mfa fi/lh Il.3.130, Od.4.743, cf. E.Med.150, Andr.140 (both lyr.).
marriageable maiden, Il.9.560, Hes.Th.298.
daughter-in-law, LXX1 Ki.4.19, Ev.Matt.10.35.
young girl, pentae/ths n. IG14.2040.2. Nymph or goddess of lower rank, qeai\ *nu/mfai Il.24.616, cf. Hes.Th.130, Fr.171.5, al., IG12(8).358 (Thasos, V B.C.) ; N. kou=rai *dio\s ai)gio/xoio Od.6.105 ; N. a(/liai S.Ph.1470 (anap. ; cf. *nai+a/s, *nhrhi/+s) ; N. *)orestia/des, *)oreia/des, Il.6.420, Bion 1.19, cf. Ar.Av.1098 (lyr.) ; N. *meli/ai Hes. Th.187, cf. *)adrua/des, *(amadrua/des, *drua/des ; N. u(a/des, u(dria/des, Id.Fr.180, Porph.Antr.18 ; N. leimwnia/des, petrai=ai, S.Ph.1454 (anap.), E.El.805. esp. of
springs, o)noma/zesqai ta\s phga\s N. Ath.11.465a, cf. Lib.Or.11.28 : hence, poetically,
water, AP9.258 (Antiphan.), 331 (Mel.), cf. Plu.2.147f. in mystical theology, *zeu\s a)/mbrotos e)/pleto n. Orph.Fr.21a4. applied to souls seeking birth, Porph.Antr.18 ; cf. numfeu/w.
doll, puppet, AP6.274 (Pers.), Jul.Caes.332d.
young bee or
wasp, in the pupa stage, Arist.HA551b2, 555a3.
winged male of the ant, Hsch. kind of
mollusc, Speusipp. ap. Ath.3.105b.
point of the ploughshare, Poll.1.252, Procl.ad Hes. Op. 425.
hollow between the under-lip and chin, Ruf.Onom.42, Poll.2.90, Hsch. depression on the shoulder of horses, Hippiatr. 26.
opening rosebud, Phot.
clitoris, Ruf.Onom.112, Gal.UP15.3.
niche, Callix.2.
numf-hge/ths, ew, o(, = numfage/ths (q. v.), *)apo/llwn IG12(8).358 (Thasos, V B.C.).

numf-ia/w,
to be in a frenzy, a disease of mares, Arist.HA604b10.

numf-i/des, ai(,
weddingshoes, Hsch.

numf-i/dios [i^], a, on, also os, on E.Alc.885 (lyr.) :—
bridal, le/ktrwn a(/milla, eu)nai/, Id.Hipp.1140 (lyr.), Alc.l.c. ; w)|dai/ Ar.Av. 1729 (lyr.) ; qa/lamoi A.R.1.1031, cf. IG12(8).441.1 (Thasos).

numf-iko/s, h/, o/n, = foreg., A.Ch.71 (lyr.), S.OT1242, E.Med.378 ; n. i(ma/tion, kli/nh, da=|des, Plu.2.755a, Luc.Herod.5, Poll.3.43 ; ta\ n. Pl.Lg.783d. Adv. -kw=s Ach.Tat.3.7.
of the Nymphs, oi)=koi S.Ichn.149 ; mh=la AP7.703 (Myrin.). -ka/, ta/, dub. sens. in POxy.1740.9 (iii iv A.D.).

numf-i/os, o(,
bridegroom, paido\s o)du/retai o)ste/a kai/wn <*>fi/ou Il.23.223 ; to\n me\n a)/kouron e)o/nta ba/l' . . numfi/on e)n mega/rw| mi/an oi)/hn pai=da lipo/nta Od.7.65 ; a(rmo/zwn ko/ra| n. a)/ndra Pi.P.9.118, etc. ; zh=te numfi/wn bi/on Ar.Av.161 ; opp. nu/mfh, Pl.Lg.783e : in pl., toi=s newsti\ numfi/ois to the
bridal pair, E.Med.366, cf. A.Th.757 (lyr.) ; numfi/oisi parqe/nois occurs in Ps.-E.IA741.
son-in-law, LXXJd. 15.6. as Adj. nu/mfios, a, on,
bridal, tra/peza numfi/a Pi.P.3.16 ; le/ktra Epigr.Gr.373 (Aezani).

numfo/-bas, o(,
nymphas iniens, Achae.52.
numfo-genh/s, e/s, = numfagenh/s, Epigr. ap. Arist.Mir.843b31, APl.1.8 (Alc.).
numfo-ge/nnhtos, on, = foreg., S.Ichn.35.

numfo/-klautos, on, *)erinu/s, i. e.
a bride bringing woe as vengeance, A.Ag.749(lyr.).

numfo-kome/w,
adorn as a bride, to\ ge/ras APl.4.147 (Antiphil.).
make ripe for marriage, e)pei\ de/ m' a)kmh=s a)/nqos e)numfoko/mei Supp.Epigr.1.570.6 (Egypt, Augustan). intr.,
dress oneself as a bride, E.Med.985 (lyr.).

numfo-ko/mos, on, (kome/w)
dressing a bride, h( n.
bridesmaid, Hsch. : generally,
bridal, ga/mos E. IA1087 (lyr.) ; qa/lamoi IG12(8).600 (Thasos) ; stoli/des Sammelb.
6178.3 ; pa/lh Nonn.D.48.183.

numfo/-lhptos, on,
caught by nymphs : hence,
raptured, frenzied, IG12.788, Pl.Phdr.238d, Arist.EE1214a23, Plu<*>.Arist.II.

numfo-po/nos, on,
busied with the bride, title of a poem by Sophron, Ath.8.362c.

numfo-stole/w,
escort the bride or
bridegroom, Ph.1.529, 2.36, Ach.Tat.1.18, al., AP9.203 (Phot. or Leo Phil.) :— Med., of the bridegroom, Ph.1.323 :—Pass., Str.6.1.8 (-isqei/sas codd.).

numfo-stolikw=s, Adv.
like one escorting a bride, Sch.E.Hec. 388.

numfo-sto/los, on,
escorting the bride, J.AJ5.8.6 : generally,
bridal, a)/stron e)rw/twn Musae.10.
numfo-terei=s: a)/rxonte/s tines, Hsch. (-th/reis Meineke).

numfo/-ti_mos, on,
honouring the bride: me/los n.
bridal song, A.Ag.705 (lyr.).

numfo-tome/w,
remove the clitoris, Aët.16.116 (Pass.).

numfo-tomi/a, h(,
removal of the clitoris, Philum. ap. Aët.16.115 tit., Paul.Aeg.6.70tit.

numfo-trofe/w,
bring up for marriage, ta\s qugate/ras Them.Or.34p.467D.
numfo-fo/ros, on, dub. sens. in POxy.434.

numf-w/dhs, es,
of marriageable age, Sammelb.6178.4(dub.).

numf-w/n, w=nos, o(,
bridechamber, LXXTo.6.14, Ev.Matt.9.15, D.Chr.7.145, Hld.7.8, PLond.3.964.19 (ii/iii A.D.). temple of Dionysus, Demeter, and Persephone, Paus.2.11.3. a kind of numfai/a, Ps.-Dsc.3.132.

nu=n (for nun, nu, v. infr. II), Adv.
now, both of the
present moment, and of the
present time generally, oi(\ n. brotoi/ ei)sin mortals
of our day, Il.1.272 ; so in Ion. and Att., oi( n. [a)/nqrwpoi] men
of the present day, Hdt.1.68 ; oi(/ ge n. Pi.O.1.105, B.5.4, cf. Arist.Metaph.1069a26 ; o( n. tro/pos, to\ n. barbariko/n, Th.1.6 ; *boiwtoi\ oi( n. ib.12 ; o( n. parw\n xro/nos S.Tr.174, al., Pl.Prm.141e ; h(me/ra h( n. S.OT351 ; nu\c h( n. Id.Ant.16 ; h( n. o(do/s Id.El.1295 ; to\ n.
the present, Arist.Ph.218a6, al. ; a)po\ tou= n. Pl.Prm.152c, LXXGe.46.30, etc. ; a)po\ n. AP5.40 (Rufin.) ; e(/ws tou= n. LXXGe.46.34 ; me/xri n. (v.l. m. tou= n.) D.S.17.110 ; ta\ n. simply, = n., Hdt.7.104, E.Heracl.641, etc. ; to/ per n. Pi. N.7.101 ; ta\ de\ n. S.OC133 (lyr.) ; to\ n. ei)=nai Pl.R.506e, X.Cyr.5.3.42, Arist.Ath.31.2 ; to\ n. e)/xon Act.Ap.24.25. of the immediate past,
just now, but now, n. *mene/laos e)ni/khsen Il.3.439, cf. 13.772, Od. 1.43, S.OC84, X.Cyr.4.5.48 ; n. gou=n e)pexei/rhsas Pl.R.341c ; h(li/ka n. e)tragw/|dei D.18.13. of the future,
presently, n. au)=t' e)gxei/h| peirh/somai Il.5.279, cf. 20.307, Od.1.200 ; n. feu/comai, to/q' a(gno\s w)/n E.El.975 ; cf. nu=n dh/, nuni/. sts. opp. to what might have been under other circumstances,
as it is (or
was), as the case stands (or
stood), as a matter offact, n. d' o( me\n w(\s a)po/lwle Od.1.166 ; ei) me\n u(pw/pteuon, ou)k a)\n . . e)poiou/mhn: n. de\ ktl. Th.4.126, cf. 1.122, 3.113, Pl. Cra.384b, D.18.195, etc. ; kai\ n. even
so, X.An.7.4.24,7.7.17. coupled with other Particles, ta\ n. ge S.Ph.245, etc. ; n. ge ma/n Pi. P.1.50 ; n. dh/, v. h. v. : with other expressions of Time, n. . . sh/meron, n. h(me/rh h(/de, Il.7.29, 13.828 ; n. h)/dh
henceforth, S.Ant.801 (anap.), etc. ; n. . . a)/rti
but now, Pl.Cra.396c. enclit. (but see below) nun, nu. [nu only Ep., Boeot., and Cypr. (also Arc. in o(/nu, q. v.) ; nu^n twice in Hom., Il.10.105, 23.485 : u_^ in Trag. (u_ A.Th.242,246, S.Ant.705, E.Or.1678, etc. ; u^ S.Tr.92, E.Andr.91, etc.), u_ in Com. (Ar.V.1381, Pl.975, al.), exc. Cratin.144, Ar.Th.105 (lyr., citing Agatho), and perh. Nu.141 ; both quantities in toi/nun, q.v.] rarely of Time,
now, perh. so used in Il.10.105, cf. Parm.19.1, Pi. P.11.44, al., Epich.170.6. in Ep. mostly as a particle of emphasis, h(=ke d' e)p' *)argei/oisi kako\n be/los: oi( de/ nu laoi\ qnh=|skon Il.1.382, etc. : freq. coupled with other Particles or Conjs., h)= r(a/ n. 4.93 ; kai/ nu/ ken 3.373 ; ou)/ n., mh/ nu/ toi, 10.165, 1.28 ; e)pei/ nu/ toi ib.416 ; w(/s nu/ per 2.258. in commands or entreaties, mh/ n. moi nemesh/set' 15.115 : freq. with other Advbs., deu=ro/ n. come
now ! 23.485 ; e)ntau=qa/ n. u(/brize A.Pr.82, cf. Ar.Th.1001, V.149, Pl.724 ; ei)=a/ n. Id.Pax467, V.430, Pl.316 : freq. with imper., fe/re n. ib.789 ; a)/ge n. Id.Pax1056, V.381 ; speu=de/ n. Id.Pl.414 ; si/gan. S.Aj.87, Cratin.l.c. ; peri/dou n. Ar.Nu.644, cf. X.Cyr.5.3.21, etc. ; u(/faine/ n. B.18.8 ; so in Boeot., n. e)/nqw IG7.3172.88 (Orchom.) ; also in Cypr. with opt. in commands, duva/noi n., dw/koi n., Inscr.Cypr.135.6,16 H. (Idalion). in questions, ti/s n. ; ti/ n. ; who, what, why
now? Il.5.373, 1.414,4.31 ; h)= nu . . ; Od.6.125. [In signf. I always perispom. In signf. II perispom. exc. when short, Hdn.Gr.2.39, al. ; enclit. when short, sts. in codd., as Il.23.485 (Pap. in AJP21.304, etc. ; oxyt. when = dh/, Tyrannioap.Hdn.Gr.2.27 ; kaq' o(malismo/n or kat' e)/gklisin when=dh/, Sch.Ar.Pl.414, Sch.A.R.1.664). In codd. usu. perispom. in both senses, A.Pr.82, Th.242, 246, S.Ant.705,El.324, Ar.Pl.414, V.758,922, etc. ; even nu^n is written nu=n in codd. vett. Pi.
passim, also in S.Aj.87, Tr.92, etc. ; hence nun may freq. be restored where the sense requires it. The accent of toi/nu_^n perh. shows that both nu^n and nu_n could be enclitic.—Position : in signf. I nu=n can occupy any position ; in signf. II it prefers (like other enclitics, but also like a)/n, de/, ga/r, etc.) the second place in the sentence, e.g. pro/s nu/n se patro/s S.Ph.468, cf. OC1333 ; a)po/ nu/n me lei/pet' h)/dh Id.Ph.1177 (lyr.) ; meta/ nun do/s E.Supp.56 (lyr.) ; nu (always enclitic) precedes other enclitics and allows only de/ to precede.] (Cf. Skt.
nú, n[umacracute], nūnám, OE.
nū 'now', etc.)
nu/namai [u^], Cret. for du/namai, Leg.Gort.8.20,12.32.
nu^na^to/s, a/, o/n, Cret. for dunato/s, GDI4992aiii 3, al.

nu=n dh/, stronger form of nu=n, with pres.,
now, even now, Pl.Grg. 462b, al., Com.Adesp.597, etc. with past tenses,
just now, a(\ n. d. e)gw\ e)/legon Pl.Prt.329c, cf. Phd.61e, Grg.448a. with fut.,
now, without further delay, n. d. su\ dhlw/seis X.Cyr.4.1.23. n. d. me\n . . , n. de\ . . , E.Hipp.233 (anap.), Pl.Lg.683e.

nu_ni/, Att. form of nu=n, strengthd. by -i_ demonstr.,
now, at this moment, mostly of
the present, IG12.98.3, etc. : freq. in Com., Ar. Ach.325, Ra.290, Pherecr.41, Men.Her.27, etc. : less freq. with past tenses, w(=n n. die/balle D.18.14 ; n. sunelhlu/qamen Isoc.6.7 ; n. e)boulh/qh Is.1.20 ; n. bohqh/santes sunkateta/ttonto IG22.237.11 (iv B. C.) : also with fut., n. de\ peira/somai Aeschin.2.25, cf. Isoc.18.35 : c. aor. imper., n. metagnw/tw Th.4.92 : rarely in the sense,
as the case stands (cf. nu=n 1.4), D.21.129, Lycurg.Fr.31.—Never in Trag. (E.Supp.306 is corrupt) : Com. also have nunmeni/, for nuni\ me/n, Ar. Av.448 ; nundi/, for nuni\ de/, Id.Eq.1357, Antiph.190.16 ; cf. nungari/, for nuni\ ga/r, Eust.45.3.

nu/nnion, to/, and nu/nnios, o(,
lullaby, Hsch.

nu/c, nukto/s, h(,
night : either generally,
mght-season (opp. day), or
a night, n. a)mbrosi/h Il.24.363 ; n. a)/mbrotos Od.11.330 ; but n. o)loh/ ib.19, Il.16.567, cf. infr. Il. 3, III ; nukto/s
by night, as Adv., Od. 13.278, etc. ; ou)/te n. ou)/t' e)c h(me/ras S.El.780 ; nukto\s e)/ti
while it was still
night, Hdt.9.10 ; also th=s nukto/s Alex.78.3, 148 ; n. th=sde S. Aj.21 ; a)/kras n. at dead of
night, ib.285 (but a)/krh| nukti/ at
night-fall, Arat.775, a)kro/qi nukto/s on the verge of dawn, Id.308) ; a)wri\ nukto/s, tw=n nuktw=n, v. a)wri/ : in pl., tw=n nuktw=n
at nights, Ar.Ec.668 : rarely, nukti/ Hdt.7.12 ; n. th=|de S.El.644 ; nu/kta
the night long, nu/kta fula/ssein to watch
the night through, Il.10.312, Od.5.466 : pl., nu/ktas i)au/ein Il.9.325, Od.5.154, etc. ; du/w nu/ktas, trei=s n., ib.388, 17.515 : in Att., o(/lhn th\n n. Pherecr.177, Amphis20.4 ; th\n nu/xq' o(/lhn Eub.3 ; ta\s nu/ktas Diph.32.14 ; o(/las ge kai\ pa/sas ta\s n. X.Smp.4.54 ; nu/ktas te kai\ h)=mar Il.5.490 ; nu/ktas te kai\ h(me/ras Pl.Tht.151a ; ou)/te nu/kt' ou)/q' h(me/ran E.Ba.187 ; th\n nu/xq' o(/lhn th/n q' h(me/ran Eub.53.1 ; nu/kta h(me/ran poiou/menos a)po/steilon （kata/pemyon）, i. e. without delay, PCair.Zen.314.7, PSI5.514.3 (both iii B. C.) ; me/sai nu/ktes
midnight, Sapph.52, Pl.R.621b ; peri\ m. nu/ktas X.An.7.8.12 ; e)n me/sw| nuktw=n Id.Cyr.5.3.52 ; prwi/+teron me/swn nuktw=n Th.8.101 ; e)/cw me/swn n. D.54.26. freq. with Preps., a)na\ nu/kta by
night, Il.14.80 ; a)na\ pa=san n. all
night through, Paus.1.32.4 ; dia\ nu/kta Od.19.66, etc. ; ei)s nu/kta, ei)s th\n n., towards
night, X.Cyn.11.4, HG4.6.7 ; e)n nutti/ （nukti/）, opp. ped' a)me/ran, Leg.Gort.2.14, SIG527.40 (Dreros, iii B.C.) ; kata\ nu/kta Ar.Fr. 561 (lyr.) ; u(po\ nu/kta to wards
nightfall, Th.4.67, X.Ages.2.19 ; meta\ nu/ktas by
night, Pi.N.6.6 ; meq' h(me/ran kai\ dia\ nukto/s all through
the night, Pl.Criti.117e ; e)k nukto/s after
nightfall, X.Cyr.1.4.2, LXXIs. 26.9, etc. ; e)k pollh=s e)/ti nukto/s D.H.6.67 ; e)k nuktw=n Thgn.460, A. Ch.287, E.Rh.13, 17 (both anap.) ; e)k nukto\s ei)s nu/kta Pl.Ax.368b ; po/rrw tw=n nuktw=n far into
the night, Id.Smp.217d, Prt.310c ; e)pi\ nukti/ by
night, Il.8.529 ; e)f' h(me/rh| ai( d' e)pi\ nukti/ Hes.Op.102 ; e)n nukti/ A. Ag.653, X.Smp.1.9, etc. ; o)yi/a| e)n n. Pi.I.4(3).36 ; e)n n. th=| nu=n S.Ant. 16 ; nu/ktessin e)/n q' a(me/rais Pi.P.4.130. in pl.,
watches of the night, ib.256 ; three such, paroi/xwken de\ ple/wn nu\c tw=n du/o moira/wn, trita/th d' e)/ti moi=ra le/leiptai Il.10.252 ; tri/xa nukto\s e)/hn, for tri/ton me/ros th=s nukto\s h)=n, it was the third watch, i. e. next before morning, Od.12.312. metaph. of darkness, nukti\ kalu/yai Il.5.23, cf. Od. 20.351, etc. metaph. of death, a)mfi\ de\ o)/sse kelainh\ n. e)ka/luye Il.5.310, al. ; n. *(/aidhs te S.Aj.660. in Comparisons, of anything dark and direful, nukti\ e)oikw/s like
night, of Apollo in his wrath, Il.1.47, cf. 12.463, Od.11.606 ; ta/de nukti\ e)i/+skei what is here he like ns
to night, 20.362 ; o)leqri/a n., of a great calamity, S.OC 1684(lyr.). *nu/c as pr. n.,
the goddess of Night, Il.14.259, Hes.Op.17,Th.123,211 ; N. o)loh/ ib.224.
the night- or
evening-quarter of heaven, the West, pro\s nukto/s ib.275. (Cf. Lat.
nox, Lith.
naktis, Goth.
nahts, etc.)

nu^o/s, h(,
daughter-in-law, Il.22.65, Od.3.451, h.Ven.136 ;
daughter-by-marriage of the race of which the husband is a son, Il.3.49.
bride, wife, Theoc.18.15 ; cj. in AP12.53.5 (Mel.) :—e)nuo/s is f.l. in Poll.3.32. (I.-E. snu^so/s, cf. Skt.
snusā, OHG.
snur, Lat.
nurus, etc.)
nuri/zei: nu/ssei, cu/ei, and nurw=n: nu/sswn, cu/wn, Hsch., cf. Suid.

*nu=sa, hs, h(,
Nysa, name of several mountains sacred to Dionysus, h.Hom.26.5, etc. :—Adj. *nu/sios [u_], a, on, h.Cer.17, S.Aj.699 codd. (lyr.) (n., o(, = kisso/s, Ps.-Dsc.2.179) ; *nu_sh/i+os, Ar.Ra.215 (lyr.) :— fem. *nu_sa_i/+s, i/+dos, Str.12.8.17 ; *nu_sai=oi, oi(,
inhabitants of N., Id.15.1.8. nu/sa, h(, = de/ndron, Pherecyd.178 J.
nu=sos, = xwlo/s, Syrac. word, Nonn.D.9.22, EM280.16.

nu/ssa, hs, h(, in a race-course, = kampth/r,
turning-post, Il.23.332,344 ; e)n nu/ssh| e)gxrimfqh/tw, of the near horse, ib.338, cf. Theoc.24.119 : metaph.,
turning-point of the recurrent nerve, Gal. UP16.4.
starting-and
winning-post, toi=si d' a)po\ nu/sshs te/tato dro/mos Il.23.758, Od.8.121 : metaph., n. a)oidh=s i)qu/nein Opp.H.3.11.
nusshi/+tas, o(, Pythag. name for 9, Theol.Ar.58 (dub. l.).

nu/ssw, Att. nu/ttw, Pass., pf. ne/nugmai Gal.10.221 : aor. 1 e)nu/xqhn D.L.2.109, Gal.10.390 : aor. 2 e)nu/ghn [u^], 3sg. opt. nugei/h ib.401 ; part. nu^gei/s Chrysipp.Stoic.2.233, Gal.13.565, App.Anth.3.129.6 (D.L.) :—
touch with a sharp point, prick, stab, pierce, e)/gxei+ nu/ce Il.5.579 ; xei/ressi . . a)spi/da nu/sswn 16.704 ; xqo/na . . i(/ppoi nu/ssontes xhlh=|si
dinting the earth with their hoofs, Hes.Sc.62 ; a)gkw=ni nu/cas
having nudged him with the elbow, Od.14.485, cf. Theoc.21.50, Plu.2.79e, etc. ; gnwmidi/w| gnw/mhn n.
prick it (and see what is in it), Ar.Nu.321 ; ge/ontan. 'beard the lion in his den', Diogenian.1.52. metaph.,
sting, Phld.Lib.p.64O. ; nu/cas o( lo/gos Luc.Herm.71, cf. Porph.Abst. 1.49.
impinge upon, esp. of sense-impressions, Plot.4.5.1, 6.6.12 :—Pass., Chrysipp. l. c., Alex.Aphr.de An.130.15. Pass., of the neu=ra,
suffer lesion (nu/gma 1.2), Gal.ll.cc.

nu/st-agma, atos, to/,
nap, short sleep, LXXJb.33.15.

nust-agmo/s, o(,
drowsiness, Hp.VM10, LXXPs.131(132).4, al. : in pl., Porph.Abst.I.
28.

nust-a/zw, fut. -a/cw LXXIs.5.27 : aor. e)nu/staca Thphr.Char.7.8, LXX 2 Ki.4.6, al. ; e)nu/stasa Dionys.Com.2.43, AP12.135 (Asclep.) :— mostly pres.,
to be half asleep, doze, nusta/zonta ou)de/na a)\n i)/dois X.Cyr. 8.3.43 ; w(/sper oi( nusta/zontes e)geiro/menoi Pl.Ap.31a ; o)fqalmoi\ ple/ontes w(/sper tw=n nustazo/ntwn Hp.Epid.7.17 ; ou)xi\ nusta/zein e)/ti w(/ra <*>sti/n Ar.Av.639, cf. Xenarch.2.1, Com.Adesp.185 ; nusta/zontos dikastou= Pl.R.405c : metaph., n. te kai\ a)porei= Id.Ion533a ; to\n nusta/zonta kai\ a)maqh= fu/sei Id.Lg.747b ; e)/n tini
in a thing, Plu.2.675b.
hang the head, e)da/krusen kai\ e)nu/stase APl.c. (Cf. Lith.
snústi (stem
snúd-) 'grow drowsy'.)

nust-akth/s, ou=, o(,
drowsy, u(/pnos Ar.V. 12, Alciphr.3.46.

nust-aktikw=s, Adv.
in a drowsy way, Gal.19.91.

nust-a^le/os, a, on,
drowsy, Aret.SD2.6, Hsch.

nu/st-a^los, on,
drowsy, gero/ntion Com.Adesp.875 (-le/on Kock), cf. D.L.6.77 :— written nustalogero/ntion in EM609.38.

nu/st-acis, ews, h(,
drowsiness, Hsch.s.v.nw=kar.
nu/ttw, Att.for nu/ssw.
nu/xa^ [u^], Adv.,=nu/ktwr, Hsch.
nu^x-ai=os, a, on,=nu/xios, Theognost.Can.52.

nu^x-augh/s, e/s,
shining by night, Orph.H.3.7,71.8.
nu^x-egresi/a, h(, = nukthgresi/a, AP5.263 (Paul. Sil.).
-<e>i/a, h(, = nu/xeuma, Hsch.
nu^/x-eios, a, on, = nu/xios, Orph.H.9.6 (nuxi/a codd.).

nu^/x-euma, atos, to/,
nightly watch, pou= nuxeuma/twn xa/ris; E.Supp.1136 (lyr., dub. l.).

nu^x-eu/w, fut. -eu/sw Nic.Fr.74.8 :—
watch the night through, pass the night, da/krusi n. E.El.181 (lyr.), cf. Rh.520, Hyps.Fr.10, 11.13 (lyr.) ; *nu/mfh|sin
with them, Nic.l.c.

nu^xhbo/ros, on,
devouring by night, v.l. for mul-, mux-, Nic.Th. 446.
nuxq-hmerh/sios, a, on, = sq., Tz.ad Hes.Op.412.
nuxq-hmerino/s, h/, o/n, = sq., dia/sthma Cleom.1.6.

nuxq-h/meros, a, on,
lasting a day and night, dro/moi Peripl.M.Rubr.15 ; plou=s Scymn.957. as Subst. nuxq-h/meron, to/,
a night and a day, the space of 24 hours, 2 Ep.Cor.11.25, Gal.7.508, Cleom.1.6, Ptol.Alm.3.9, Herm. ap. Stob.1.21.9, Gp.5.8. S, etc.

nu/xios [u^], a, on, also os, on E.IT1273 (lyr.), Tim.Fr.II, parodied by Macho ap.Ath.8.341d :—
nightly, i.e. of persons,
doing a thing
by night, n. katale/cetai Hes.Op.523 (v.l.), cf.Th.991, A.Ag. 588, etc. ; a)nh\r d' e)kte/tatai n.
as in nightly sleep, S.Ph.857 (lyr.).
belonging to night, n. fqe/gmata Id.Ant.1147 (lyr.) ; e)nopai/, go/oi, E.IT 1277, El.141 (both lyr.) : in late Prose, n. qeo/s Dam.Pr.273. of places,
dark as night, gloomy, nuxi/an pla/ka A.Pers.953 (lyr.) ; di' a(/la n. E.Med.211 (lyr.) ; a)/ntra Id.Andr.1224 (lyr.) ; u(po\ me/laqra nu/xia, i.e. into the nether world, Id.Hel.177 (lyr.) ; xa/os Ar.Av. 698 : in later Prose, to\ tw=n a)/ntrwn n. Porph.Antr.9.
nu/xma, to/, = nu/gma (q. v.). = o)/neidos, Hsch. ; cf. nw=xma.
nu/xos, eos, to/, = nu/c, S.E.M.1.243, Hsch., Phot., etc.
nw/, v. e)gw/ III. nw=|, dat. of nou=s.

nw/ga^l-a, ta/,
dainties, sweetmeats, eaten after dinner,
dessert, like trwga/lia, Antiph.65, Ephipp.24.
nwga^l-e/os: lampro/s, Zonar. Adv. -e/ws Id.
nwga^/l-euma, atos, to/, in pl., = nw/gala, Arar.8.

nwga^l-eu/w,
munch dainties or
sweetmeats, Suid.
nwga^l-i/zw, = foreg., Alex.275 : pf. Pass. e)nwga/listai in Eub.15.7 is f.l. for nenwg-.
nwga^/l-isma, atos, to/, in pl., = nw/gala, Poll.6.62.

nwdoge/rwn, ontos, o(,
toothless old man, Com.Adesp.1090.

nwdo/s, h/, o/n, (neg. Particle
n(ě)-, o)dou/s)
toothless, Ar.Ach.715, Pl.266, Phryn.Com.79, Eub.146, Arist.Metaph.1068a7, Phoen.5.3 (dub. l.), Theoc.9.21.

nwdo/ths, htos, h(,
toothlessness, Porph.in Cat.137.3.

nwdu^n-i/a, h(,
relief from pain, te/ktona nwduni/as Pi.P.3.6, cf. Theoc. 17.63.

nw/du^n-os, on, (
n(ě)-, o)du/nh) = a)nw/dunos (q. v.),
painless, nw/dunon ka/maton tiqe/nai Pi.N.8.50. Act.,
soothing pain, fu/llon ti n. S.Ph.44.
nw=e, v. e)gw/ III.

nw/q-eia, h(,
slowness, sluggishness, Pl.Phdr.235d, Tht.195c, Luc. Ind.22, Babr.95.70, Poll.3.122, Ael.NA16.21.

nwq-h/s, e/s,
sluggish, slothful, o)/nos Il.11.559 ; n. kw=lon E.HF819 ; i(/ppos -e/steros Pl.Ap. 30e ; n. ki/nhsis Arist.HA503b8 ; ta\ go/nata nwqh/s Luc.Luct.16 ; of fire,
dull, opp. o)cu/s, Thphr.HP5.9.3 (Comp.) ; of earth, opp. water, etc., Pl.Ti.86a (Sup.). of the understanding,
dull, stupid, katefai/neto ei)=nai -e/steros (sc. o( pai=s) Hdt.3.53 ; nwqh\s to\n no/on Hp. Ep.17, cf. A.Pr.62, Pl.Plt.310e (Comp.). neut. nwqe/s as Adv., Poll.4.81 : Sup. -e/stata D.C.59.4.
nwq-ouri/s, i/dos, h(, = ballwth/, Ps.-Dsc.3.103.

nw/q-ouros, on, (ou)ra/ 1.2)
frigidus in venerem, Com.Adesp.1352.
nwqr-a/s, a/dos, h(, = ballwth/, Ps.-Dsc.3.103.

nwqr-ei/a, h(,
sluggishness, torpor, indolence, Erot. s.v. blakeu/ein, Aristid.Quint.2.3, v.l. in Poll.3.122.

nwqr-epiqe/ths, ou, o(,
slow to begin, Arist.Phgn.813a3.

nwqr-eu/w,
to be sluggish or
torpid, Poll.1.159, Aq.Jd.19.8 :—also in Med., of persons, Hyp.Lyc.Fr.5 ; nenwqreume/noi Hp.Coac.600 ; of tumours, nenwqreume/na
accompanied by torpor, ib.60.
to be poorly, indisposed, PGiss.17.6 (ii A. D.) :—Med., PSI6.717.5 (ii A. D.).
nwqr-i/a, lon.

nwqr-i/h, = nwqrei/a, Hp.Prorrh.1.141,Coac.205, Herod.4.53, Ptol. Tetr.141 ;
indisposition, PAmh.2.78.15 (ii A. D.).
nwqr-i^a/w, = nwqreu/omai I, Dsc.Alex.Praef.

nwqro-ka/rdios, on,
slow of heart, LXXPr.12.8, Hsch.

nwqro-poio/s, o/n,
making sluggish, Eust.1395.31.

nwqr-o/s, a/, o/n, = nwqh/s, Hp.VM10, Prorrh.1.102,117, etc. ; n. sfugmoi/ Id.Coac.136, Aret.SA2.9 ; kataforh\ n. falling into a
heavy sleep, Hp.Epid.3.6, cf. Nic.Th.165 ; n. kinh/seis Arist.PA696b6 ; n. su/nesis Demetr.Lac.Herc.1014.58 ; th=| kinh/sei n. Arist.HA622b32 ; n. o(di/ths Call.Fr.275 ; nwqro/teros th\n a)koh/n Hld.5.1. Adv. -qrw=s Archyt. I ;
leisurely, gradually, Hp.Aph.2.7 : neut. as Adv., o)/mmasi nwqra\ ble/pousa AP5.54（Diosc.). of the mind, n. kai\ lh/qhs ge/montes Pl. Tht.144b, cf.
